properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A complete, cast, copper alloy Medieval buckle and plate, dating to 1350-1400. The buckle loop is D shape and in cross section. Front bar is round and the arms taper narrowly inwards before connecting to the strap bar that is rectangular in section. The strap bar is comprised of two arms of a two-layered copper alloy plate comprised of a single thin folded sheet. Attached to the strap bar, between the two arms of the plate, is a sub rectangular-sectioned pin and complete. The frame, plate and pin all have mid-green patination. Weight 3.5 grams, Length 31.33mm, Thickness 3.53mm and Width 16.52mm. Ref; Buckles by Ross Whitehead, No 138.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Venetian Soldino of unknown Doge. Mint Venice. Large part of coin missing. Obverse; Doge standing left, holding standard. Reverse; winged nimbate lion of St Mark facing. Legend; S MARCVS VENETI. Weight 0.2 grams, diameter 15.18mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Venetian Soldino of Doge Michele Steno. [ AD 1400-1413 ] Minted in Venice. Obverse; Doge standing left, holding standard. Star over D left. Legend; D MICHAEL STEN DVX. Reverse; winged and nimbate lion of St Mark facing. Legend S MARCVS VENETI. Weight 0.4 grams, diameter 14.66mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Edward 1 or 11. [ AD 1272-1327 ] Durham mint. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward. Reverse; long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend; CIVI TAS DVR EME. Weight 1.1 grams, diameter 18.97mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Silver Medieval Edwardian penny of Edward 1/11/111 [ AD 1272-1377 ] Initial mark cross pattee. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward. Reverse; long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend; CIVI TAS LONDON. weight 1.1 grams, diameter 17.47mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Henry V [ AD 1413-1422 ] Coin is clipped. Initial mark cross pattee. Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward with Mullet to left and Trefoil to right of hair. Legend; HENRIC DI GRA REX ANGL. Reverse; Long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter and quartrefoil to centre. Legend; CIVI TAS EBO RACI. Weight 0.9 grams, diameter 15.85mm. Spink 1788.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval Halfpenny of Henry V [ AD 1413-1422 ] Coin is clipped. Initial mark cross pattee. Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward, annulet to left and trefoil to right of hair. Legend; HENRIC xREX:ANGL. Reverse; Long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend; CIVI TAS LONDON. Weight 0.5 grams, diameter 12.33mm. Spink 1796.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Edward 111 [ AD 1327-1377 ] Initial mark; Cross Pattee [ AD 1369-1377 ] Fourth coinage. Coin is clipped with small section missing and slight fold. Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward. Legend; EDW.... Reverse; Long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Weight 0.7 grams. Diameter 16.21mm.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy medieval official seal matrix dating from AD 1200 - 1400.It is of pointed oval form (vesica shaped) and has a central rib on the reverse, with a pieced loop at one end. Part of the loop is now missing. The central design is composed of a bust in profile facing left, with long hair or possibly a veil, suggesting it may be female. A series of lines across the area of the hair could represent a form of decorative headgear or the elaborate edges of a veil. The bust sits on elaborately dressed shoulders which appear to be wearing a form of puffed shouldered sleeved gown. Below the bust is a sheaf of wheat, with a crescent facing outwards to either side of this. The inscription reads: "S'CON[...]VILLA" although it is incomplete and worn. The name Constance or derivatives are recorded on seals on the database, including on DENO-9328B6, SWYOR-78EE93 and KENT-A8A044 attesting to the use of the name during the period. Villa may reference the town of origin. Seals such as this were popular during the medieval period, and a number of examples show busts, including female busts, such as YORYM-184BC8, and tonsured busts, such as LIN-D25B96 and DUR-A3C735.The reverse of the seal matrix has a faint shine to its copper alloy surface, suggesting either a higher tin concentration in the alloy or a light silvering coating for decorative purposes. Measurements: 40.1mm length 21.5mm width, 3.7mm thickness, weight 10.29g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to AD 350-353.Reece Period 18. GLORIA ROMANORUM reverse type depicting soldier on horseback riding down a captive, right. Mint unknown.Measurements: 11.2mm diameter, 1.7mm thickness, weight 1.03g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman dupondius or as, possibly of Faustina the Elder, dating to AD 140-161, Reece Period 7.Unclear reverse type, mint of Rome. Measurements: 28.1mm diameter, 3.9mm thickness, weight 16.93g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete very attractive modern enamel work brooch dating from AD 1850-1920. The brooch pin is missing, the circular plate survives. It is inspired by earlier Limoges and Mosan champlevé enamel work of the medieval period and likely dates to the late 19th century Arts and Crafts revival of these designs. It is composed around a cruciform shape, with a central floreate cross lying within a white enamel squared lozenge. These are overlain by a knotwork design which divides the enamel into multiple cells. Traces of red and royal blue enamel can be seen, while the white lozenge is placed on a black background. The entirety of the design is set within a bright turquoise enamel border, divided into multiple cells, each of which has a tiny lozenge at its centre.Although this object is of a more modern date, it has been recorded due to its similarity to earlier enamel working.Measurements: 31.9mm diameter, 1.3mm thickness, weight 5.52g.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: An early post medieval book clasp, dating to AD 1500-1600. The object is rectangular in shape, with a curving pointed broad clasp extending outwards and curving downwards beneath the main sheet of the clasp. The opposite end to this has a decorative terminal with a rectangular centre,  and two small rounded triangular knops which extend at either side. It is decorated with a series of quite complex designs, beginning with a a raised circular rivet placed within a border of two concentric circles which lies adjacent to the decorative terminal. Moving towards the clasp,  there is an unclear incised design which is more figurative, possibly developed from vine scroll, which is ended by a defined band created from two thick lines. Between these are further pellets, but this aspect of the design is badly worn. FAKL-9EFF8D is a relatively similar example with a raised rivet design, but lacks the more flaring terminal.Measurements: 44.9mm length, 11.1mm width, 1.9mm thickness, weight 5g.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A copper alloy post medieval thimble dating to AD 1500-1700.The thimble is dome shaped, with a large aperture for insertion of the finger to be protected and a domed protective top. It is decorated wish a series of impressed pellets which revolve in a spiral design emanating froma single pellet at the apex of the dome. Measurements: 18.1mm diameter, 19.3mm height, 1.4mm thickness, weight 7.70g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval- post Medieval silver coin of unknown ruler. No detail left. Slight bending to coin and may have been used as a love token. Coin is very thin. Weight 0.6 grams, diameter 15.58.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post Medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Coin has been damaged on one section. Obverse; crowned bust facing left, rose behind head. Legend; ELIZABETH D G ANG FR ET HI REGINA. Reverse; long cross fourchee over shield, date above shield 1561. Legend; POSVI DEV ADIVTOREM MEV. Weight 2.5 grams, diameter 26.19mm.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete late Iron Age to Roman copper alloy probable initial T-shaped brooch dating to AD 100-150.Only the bow of the brooch survives, with no trace of the wings, catchplate or pin. The bow itself is broken at its upper end, so there is no clear suggestion as to its type, although it is likely to be a south western variant on a t-shaped brooch. The bow itself is rounded in section and narrows to a sharp point, with slightly faceted sides. Its upper end, adjacent to the break, is flattened and was clearly once attached to the wings. It is decorated with a saltire in this area,  and along the spine of the bow is a further incised decorative design composed of two vertical lines and multiple horizontal lines forming a series of rectangular cells, possibly hinting at other forms which use enamel work decoration.Measurements: 35mm length, 9.9mm width, 6mm thickness, weight 8.43g.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy coin weight issued under Charles I (AD 1625-1647).The coin weight is circular and unifaced, with a stamped mark of a crowned initial C on the obverse and a central circular flan, in addition to the stamped ewer mark of the City of London.Measurements: 14.8mm diameter, weight 2.94g.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy flat seal with the arms of Exeter, dating to AD The object is circular in shape and rectangular in section. There is no indication of a lug or handle on the plain and undecorated reverse. The obverse bears a heraldic design, which comprises the arms of the city of Exeter, namely Rougemont Tower on a heraldic shield. The inscription reads S'EXON[...]ON...WIThe seal was likely used to mark lead seals for bales, probably dating to the wool or later linen and flax trade, that passed through Exeter. Measurements: 26.9mm diameter, weight 13.1g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver half penny of Henry V (AD 1413-1422). As North (1991: 72) no. 1409, with unbroken annulets by crown. London mint.Measurements: 12.9mm diameter, weight 0.46g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver soldino issued by Doge Leonardo Loredan (1436-1521), dating to AD 1501-1521.Obverse description: Doge, as standard bearer of Venice, kneeling left, receiving the banner of St. Mark from the patron saint. Obverse inscription: LE·LAV·DVX·S·M·V·  Reverse description: Standing figure of Christ with halo, holding a cross right. Reverse inscription: LAVS TIBI SOLI (You alone be praised).Measurements: 12.4mm diameter, weight 0.19g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver Spanish one real coin of Joana and Charles I of Castile and Aragon, issued by Philip II in Mexico and dating to 1535-1570.Obverse: CAROLVS ET [IOHANA REGE]S, shield of Léon and Castille with an 'M' with an annulet above to the left side and letter G to the right for the assayer Juan Gutierrez.Reverse: HISPANIARVM ET INDIARVM, with a design representing the discovery and journey to the new world (two crowned pillars on waves representing the Pillars of Hercules on the Straits of Gibraltar, between which is written PLVS [VLTR] (more beyond))Measurements: 24.2mm diameter, weight 2.98g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver half groat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603) dating to AD 1575.Second issue, Tower mint. No visible initial mark. As North (1991: 134) no. 1997.Measurements: 23mm diameter, weight 1.73g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver penny of Charles I (AD 1625-1647).Group D. Mint of London. As North (1991: 162) no. 2269. Part of the coin is missing, c.40%. It may be a cutting error intending to produce a halfpenny.Measurements: 12.9mm diameter, weight 0.38g.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy seal matrix dating from the late medieval to early post medieval period, c. AD 1400-1550. The matrix is heraldic, bearing an image of a shield with a bend embossed with three circular impressions, or torteaux. The reverse consists of a plain domed body with inward curving edges that narrows in diameter towards the apex, which is crowned by an openwork design with two circular apertures topped by a third drop shaped aperture, the upper part of which is now missing.The device is akin to two Devon arms recorded by William de la Pole in his work published in 1791, and these are the Beaudyn family "Azure, on a bend or three torteaux"  and the Courtenays of Godlington, "Or, three torteaux a bend argent." The latter option is tempting to consider, as the device was particularly associated with Edward Courtenay of Godlington (b. 1385, d. 1418) who was killed in naval service in the Channel, leaving no issue. However, there are further possible devices on the shield that may further specifiy its owner. Measurements: 20.0mm height, 17mm length,  14.2mm width, weight 5.35g.

properties.title: PIPE TAMPER
properties.description: A complete copper alloy pipe tamper incorporating a ring with seal matrix dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1600-1700.The tamper is has a moulded double collar at the junction with the hoop and a circular cross section, expanding to the triple-banded circular terminal. The ring is domed in section along the band and flattened at the bevel. The bevel itself is broad and oval in shape, and the band expands at the shoulders to accomodate the bezel. The matrix is formed of a figure, possibly an angel, wearing a robe and with arms outstretched to the right. She stands in front of a stylised tree.The two artefacts; finger ring and pipe tamper, were often combined in the 17th century, as apparently gentlemen would often loose their pipe tamper having had too much to drink. With such an artefact the user could wear his ring and conceal the tamper until needed! (SUSS-373EA5). It is tempting to speculate that the angel might act as a deterrent to this form of overindulgence.Measurements: 41.9mm length, 21.9mm width, 3.0mm thickness, weight 6.58g.

properties.title: KEY (LOCKING)
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy casket key dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1500-1700. The ward and stem survive, but the openwork design at the handle is damaged and missing. The ward is simple, rectangular with a very slight indent on the outward facing edge. The stem is cylindrical with a series of three collars adjoining the handle, which get slightly thicker as they move towards the handle. The openwork handle was once composed of at least three cells, with a suggestion of two circles and a larger central aperture. Measurements: 31.0mm length, 4.1mm width, 3.9mm thickness, weight 3.21g.

properties.title: RING
properties.description: A copper alloy ring, probably a harness ring, dating from the medieval to post medieval periods, c. AD 1400-1700. The ring is annular in shape, slightly flattened on its upper and lower surfaces giving it a section of a flattened hexagon. It is plain and undecorated. A large number of similar rings have been recorded on the PAS database, including OXON-C4AC21, NARC-0BB2C2, SWYOR-1382CB and many more. Geake has suggested that these rings are likely to be medieval, although a post medieval date is also a consideration. Measurements: 24.9mm diameter, 4.9mm thickness, weight 7.18g.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A very worn complete post medieval copper-alloy coin weight of James I (1603-1625), probably for the spur ryal. The weight is square in shape with slightly faceted edges, it is rectangular in cross section. There is a rectangular lion passant stamp below an unclear set of initials. The weight suggests its use for the spur ryal, worth 15 shillings.Withers & Withers (1993:82) note that the lion was used as a hallmark from the 1550s onwards and that there is no certain way of determining the age of a piece. The lion passant was the most common form of stamp used for grain weights, but the weight itself is suggestive of use for a spur ryal.Measurements: 16.1mm diameter, 3.7mm thickness, weight 6.31g.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A complete copper-alloy coin weight dating to the medieval period (c.AD1350 - 1550).The weight comprises a circular disc, with a worn fleur-de-lis on the upper surface. The reverse is undecorated. Similar examples are shown in Withers (1995, 33) and are described as being used in England and France for Florins from AD1350-1550. There is a suggestion of an inscription on the obverse but it is badly worn.Measurements: 13.8mm diameter, 2.9mm thickness, weight 1.67g.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A fragment of a copper alloy medieval French jetton of shield of France, France Modern type, dating to AD 1380-1422.Jettons of shield of France modern type are illustrated in Mitchiner (1988:227 no. 683-685).Measurements: 28.2mm diameter, 1.1mm thickness, weight 2.53g.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A copper alloy medieval French jetton of shield of France, France Modern type, dating to AD 1380-1422.Jettons of shield of France modern type are illustrated in Mitchiner (1988:227 no. 683-685).Measurements: 22.1mm diameter, 0.9mm thickness, weight 3.0g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An extremely worn Roman nummus (AE follis) emperor dating from AD 300-330.Unclear reverse type, unknown mint. Measurements: 27.8mm diameter, 2.7mm thickness, weight 8g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An extremely worn Roman as of Augustus (27BC-14AD) - Claudius (41-54AD), Reece Period 1. No bust visible on the obverse, reverse SC in centre of coin. As KENT-D065C0.Measurements: 19.4mm diameter, 2.0mm thickness, weight 3.40g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An incomplete copper-alloy Roman radiate of Gallienus (AD 269-268) dating to the period AD 260-268 (Reece period 13).FORTVNA REDVX reverse type depicting Fortuna standing left holding a rudder and cornucopiae. Mint of Rome. As Cunetio 1223Measurements: 15.1mm diameter, 1.2mm thickness, weight 1.37g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A worn and damaged  Roman radiate of Victorinus (AD 269-271) dating from AD 269-271, Reece Period 13.Slightly unclear reverse type depicting standing figure with open clearly defined legs, likely similar to Cunetio 2521, depicting Victory, running right holding wreath in right hand and palm against left shoulder in left hand. Measurements: 10.4mm diameter, 0.9mm thickness, weight 0.52g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An extremely worn and damaged contemporary copy of a Roman radiate (barbarous radiate) of Divus Claudius II  (AD c. 270), dating to the period AD 275-285 (Reece Period 14).CONSECRATIO reverse type depicting an altar. Unclear mint.Measurements: 17.1mm diameter, 2.3mm thickness, weight 2.16g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: A fragment of a copper alloy Roman brooch dating to c. AD 75-150. The fragment comprises the triangular foot plate of the brooch, which flares upwards from the flattened rectangular bow. The bow retains the cast decoration, in the form of two grooves which run vertically down its length. It has a dark green pitted surface overlain with a bright reddish brown tinge. It is very likely a South western regional variant on an initial T-shaped brooch, with its upper part possibly akin to DEV-A4A625. Measurements: 24.1mm length, 5.2mm width, 2.9mm thickness, weight 2.11g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval threepence of Edward V1. Coin is very worn, cracked and with part missing.  Obverse; rose visible and two letters NG. Reverse; worn. Weight 0.8 grams, diameter 19.57mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval groat of Mary. [ AD 1553-1554 ] Coin is very worn, cracked with part missing. Obverse; No bust and only some lettering visible. Reverse; square shield over long cross fourchee with some lettering visible. Weight 1.1 grams, diameter 22.21mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Edwardian Medieval penny [ AD 1279-1377 ] Obverse; crowned bust facing forward and worn. Reverse; long cross breaking legend with three pellets to each quarter. Legend, CIVI TAS CAN TOR. Weight 1.0 grams, diameter 17.59mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Edwardian Medieval penny. [ AD 1279-1377 ] Coin is worn and clipped one side. Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward, no neck. Legend, EDWARD.....Reverse; long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend, CIVI TAS CAN TOR. Weight 1.1 grams, diameter 17.42mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Edward 1 [ AD 1272-1307 ] Coin is worn to one side. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward. Legend,; EDWARDVS REX... Reverse; Long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter, double struck. Legend; CIVI TAS.... Weight 1.1 grams, diameter 18.54mm.

properties.title: HARNESS FITTING
properties.description: A post medieval harness mount, with leather still adhered, dating to c. AD 1500-1600. The mount is cruciform in shape, with a central openwork design composed of four oval apertures arranged around a square cross. The exterior is floreate with trefoil terminals on each side of the cross, and the small square frame lying between these more elaborate designs. The reverse is largely obscured by a fragment of leather which survives, blackened and damaged, attached to two pointed lugs.  Leather survivals adhered to metallic artefacts are not uncommon, and examples of earlier artefacts with leather survivals include NLM-75191C.Measurements: 38.5mm length, 34.1mm width, 4.2mm thickness, weight 7.70g.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A fragment of a post medieval copper alloy purse bar of Williams Class A1, dating to AD 1450-1500. The fragment comprises one of the arms, which is cylindrical in section with integrally cast flattened plate beneath, in which two sewing holes are visible, although these are damaged and now incomplete. The rounded cube shaped central block is also present, with a circular aperture through it. This is decorated with a saltire design, and thickened areas immediately adjacent to the central block are formed as the heads of large dogs, probably talbot hounds or more likely mastiff types. These zoomorphic designs are badly worn, but the line of the muzzle is clearly visible on both sides, with additional depressions for eye slits. The terminal of the arm is waisted, with a broader rounded knop which appears almost bead-like in its position on the arm.DEV-BF5F8F is a complete example of the form, and has a very similar decorative style, although that example is decorated with niello, which survives clearly. Measurements: 93.4mm length, 14.2mm thickness, weight 40.68g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete early medieval copper alloy disc brooch of Weetch's Type 5, dating to c. AD 900-1000. The disc of the brooch survives,as does the catch plate on the reverse, albeit in stub form. The pin is lost and missing. The brooch is circular in shape, and flattened in section, with rounded stubs forming the base for the catchplate and pin base. The design on the brooch is composed of a series of concentric circles, which begin with a central pellet, and then alternate between raised and depressed circles,with the perimeter acting as a final raised circle in the design. DEV-9FDCB6 is a similar example found in the county, although produced unusually in lead. Further similar examples include HESH-9145D1, and similar concentric circle designs are known on other examples including SF-19700B, SWYOR-D8439A and NMS-109141. This brooch form is primarily associated with the eastern part of the country.Measurements: 23.4mm diameter, 2.4mm thickness, weight 4.85g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Henry VI [ AD 1422-1427 ], first reign.The coin is broken in half and one quarter is missing. Annulet coinage, Calais mint. As North (1991: 74) no. 1429.Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward, two annulets either side of neck with a hole punched left of crown. Reverse; long cross breaking legend, Annulet to one quarter and another possible one in quarter with hole punch. Weight 0.4 grams.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval penny of Henry V1 [ AD 1422-1461 ] Coin has damage to one side. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward, Mascle to neck with Saltire left of crown. Not clear if another Saltire or pellets. right of crown. Reverse; Long cross breaking legend, three pellets in each quarter and quartrefoil to centre. York mint. Weight 0.8 grams, diameter 16.16mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval halfpenny of Henry V1 [ AD 1422-1461 ] Initial mark plain cross. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward. Reverse; Long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend CIVI TAS LONDON. Weight 0.5 grams, diameter 13.56mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Medieval halfpenny of Henry V [ AD 1413-1422 ] Obverse; Crowned bust facing forward with broken annulets either side of crown. Legend, HENRIC REX ANGL. Reverse; long cross dividing legend with three pellets in each quarter. Legend, CIVI TAS LONDON. Weight 0.4 grams, diameter 13.45mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval penny of James 1 [ AD 1603-1625 ] Second coinage [ AD 1611-1612 ] InItial mark Mullet. Obverse; uncrowned rose. Legend, I D G ROSA SINE SPINA. Reverse; uncrowned thistle. Legend, TUEATUR UNITA DEUS. Crack to coin, one side. Weight 0.5 grams, diameter 14.62mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval Irish threepence of Elizabeth 1. [ AD 1558-1603 ] Obverse; crowned bust facing left. Reverse; Irish harp. Weight 1.1 grams, diameter 20.14mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval threepence of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Obverse; no detail. Reverse; Long cross fourchee over shield. Legend, no clear detail. Weight 1.0 grams, diameter 18.60mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval half groat of Charles 1. [ AD 1625-1649 ] Obverse; Crowned bust facing left, 11 behind. Legend, CAROLVS D G M B R F ET H REX. Reverse; Royal coat of arms on and oval shield. Legend, IVSTITIA THRONVM FIRMAT. Weight 1.0 grams, diameter 15.93mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval half groat of Charles 1. [ AD 1625-1649 ] Obverse; Crowned bust facing left, 11 behind. Legend, CAROLVS D G M B R F ET H REX. Reverse; Royal coat of arms on and oval shield. Legend, IVSTITIA THRONVM FIRMAT. Weight 0.9 grams, diameter 15.14mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval half groat of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Obverse; crowned bust facing left with two pellets behind. Legend, E D G ROSA SINE SPINA. Reverse; Square shield over long cross fourchee. Legend, CIVITAS LONDON. Weight 1.0 grams, diameter 16.29 mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval half groat of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Sixth issue [ AD 1587-1589 ] Initial mark Crescent. Obverse; crowned bust facing left with two pellets behind. Legend, E D G ROSA SINE SPINA. Reverse; Square shield over long cross fourchee. Legend, CIVITAS LONDON. Weight 0.8 grams, diameter 17.05 mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver post Medieval half groat of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Seventh issue [ AD 1601-1602 ] Initial mark 1. Obverse; crowned bust facing left with two pellets behind. Legend, E D G ROSA SINE SPINA. Reverse; Square shield over long cross fourchee. Legend, CIVITAS LONDON. Weight 0.9 grams, diameter 17.32mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post Medieval Irish copper penny of Elizabeth 1. [ Ad 1558-1603 ] Mint of Dublin. Part of one side of coin missing. Obverse; Crowned harp dividing date 160-. Legend, POSVI DEV ADIVTOREM MEV. Reverse; square topped royal shield with E to left, R to right. Legend; ELIZABETH D G ANG FR ET HIBER RE. Weight 1.1 grams, Diameter 18.62mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post Medieval silver penny of Elizabeth 1 [ AD 1558-1603 ] Initial mark O [ AD 1600 ] Obverse; crowned bust facing left, legend E D G ROSA SINE SPINA. Reverse; square shield over long cross fourchee. legend CIVI TAS LONDON. Double struck bottom left quarter. Weight 0.3 grams, diameter 13.17mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver groat of Henry V1 [ AD 1422-1461 ] First reign. Obverse; crowned bust facing forward, initial mark Cross patonce, [ AD 1427-1434 ] Calais mint. Reverse; long cross breaking legend with three pellets in each quarter. Weight 3.3 grams, diameter 25.83mm.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A complete post Medieval copper alloy coin weight of James 1. [ AD 1603-1625 ] Third coinage [ AD 1619-1625 ] for the Rose Ryal. It is square in plan and rectangular in section. Its edges are slightly oblique. It is stamped on the obverse with a crown over XXX, an S underneath. Top left corner, is a symbol with 1 under. On the reverse is the shield of British Arms set within a circular beaded border. It is for thirty shillings. Weight 10.8 grams, thickness 4.29mm, width 19.47mm and length 20.28mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to AD 318-324, Reece Period 17.BEATA TRANQUILLITAS reverse type depicting altar inscribed VOTIS XX with globe on top. Minted at Trier.Measurements: 18.2mm diameter, 1.2mm thickness, weight 2.46g.

properties.title: SEAL
properties.description: An incomplete post medieval lead alloy bag seal dating from c. AD 1600-1800. The object is circular in form, with a slight rectangular tag where it would once have been attached to the other half of the seal. It is decorated with a stamped design, impressed twice, creating a symmetrical image placed slightly one above the other. The stamp consists of an outstretched palm with thumb above, inside a beaded border. The hand appears gloved, as a large flaring trapezium forms the wrist, rather than a more natural shape.Measurements: 22mm diameter, 1.3mm thickness, weight 5.28g.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A complete post medieval lead alloy trade weight dating to c. AD 1600-1800. The object is circular in plan and has a large raised flan around the outside, in addition to a central circular depression with a small circle around it. It bears the initials TM/ EXON, followed by a third line of text which is now illegible. The reference to Exon suggests the weight was confirmed as acceptable for use in the city of Exeter. This abbreviation is also known on trade tokens from the period. Two further  weights with EXON inscriptions have been recorded on the database, including: DEV-4A8884 and the slightly later DEV-3844C3. Measurements: 34mm diameter, 13mm thickness, weight 106.63g.

properties.description: A post Medieval silver groat of unknown ruler. Probably Tudor. Obverse; blank. Reverse; Long cross fourchee over shield. Weight 0.8 grams, Diameter 22.42mm.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy mount dating to c. AD 1500-1700.The fragment consists of the central part of the mount, it is broken on the vertical edges and both curving horizontal edges are slightly frayed. From the surviving profile of the curve, it may have originally been oval in shape. The reverse is plain and undecorated, but the obverse is marked with punched decoration consisting of a ring and dot design which tracks the perimeter. Tiny vertical lines within the outer ring elaborate the decorative design. DENO-687AC1 is similar, and may present a similar complete example. NLM-0045EF is different in shape but is another post medieval mount making use of an elaborated version of ring and dot decoration. Measurements: 26.9mm length, 22.0mm width, 1.9mm thickness, weight 4.79g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A pierced copper alloy modern personal token dating to the 19th century. The object is pointed oval in shape and flattened in cross section. It may have been adapted from a copper alloy coin to become a personal token. It has a pierced circular aperture at its centre. Both surfaces have been deliberately worn so that any original details of the coin beneath are lost. Atop this has been inscribed the figure of a male head, which appears Roman in its styling, sporting a helmet and cuirass, although as the helmet lacks cheek pieces and a plume it may be intended as a representation of a Conquistador or later Civil War soldier with their distinctly pointed and tilted helms, such as the Spanish morion (see https://collections.royalarmouries.org/object/rac-object-6546.html) or an English version (https://collections.royalarmouries.org/object/rac-object-19422.html). The rendering and styling of the design suggest a 19th century date,  possibly during a period of classical revival or interest in the Civil War. The helmet design referenced were rechristened "lobster pots" during 19th century reanalysis. Measurements: 26.9mm length, 20.5mm width, 2.4mm thickness, weight 2.89g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete early medieval lead alloy disc brooch of Weetch's Type 5, dating to c. AD 900-1000. The brooch is circular in shape and flattened in cross section, with raised moulded decoration in the form of three concentric circles with a pellet at their centre. There is also a sugestion of at least five outer pellets surviving from an outer ring around the perimeter. There are two circular apertures on the surface, possibly the result of damage when the catchplate was removed post deposition, and the reverse is plain and undecorated. A similar example is HESH-9145D1, and similar concentric circle designs are known on other examples including SF-19700B, SWYOR-D8439A and NMS-109141. This brooch form is primarily associated with the eastern part of the country.Measurements: 25.4mm diameter, 2.9mm thickness, weight 8.88g.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A complete silver finger ring of late medieval to possibly early post medieval date. The bezel is bi-faceted, divided by a central ridge to each side of which it is concave with smaller ridges at each edge. The shoulders revert to a flattened form, narrowing to the hoop which gives them a trapezoidal appearance. The hoop itself is D-shaped, but a very flattened D which is shallow. It is decorated on both the bezel and shoulders with carefully arranged geometrical designs. On the bezel these are composed of transverse lines, arranged to form two bands, with four individual lines in total. Between these bands, which are akin to heraldic designs, are smaller cross hatchings which make the bands themselves appear striped. The transverse bands do not align with one another. The design continues on the shoulders, but the engraving is shallower and more worn and is unclear. There is a suggestion that rather than individual bands, the design switches to saltires at this point. There is further decoration on the interior of the ring, arranged as a chequered band which shadows the interior. This fades out before recommencing, and is extremely worn. There is a possible star, part of an extremely worn inscription, but this is very speculative and could be simple scratching or damage. Dimensions: The hoop is 22.9mm in diameter. It is 7.2mm wide and 3.2mm thick at the bevel, 0.9mm thick at the hoop. It weighs 4.95g.Discussion: This type of ring is related to contemporary iconographic rings (such as Oman, 1974, plate 68f dated to the late 15th century) but lack the religious imagery, instead having simple geometric or floral decoration. A very similar example was recorded in Devon in 2019 (Shipley 2019). Other very similar examples reported through the Treasure act include WILT-709CC7 (Tanner 2013), WAW-843792 (2017 T119, Bolton 2017) and SUSS-73C8C4 (2013 T910, Smith 2013). All these examples are dated to the late 15th and early 16th centuries.Conclusion: On the balance of probabilities this object is likely to be over 300 years old. As it is also made from precious metal, it constitutes potential Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.

properties.title: DAGGER
properties.description: A copper alloy dagger pommel dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1500-1600. The object is discoidal in shape, with its circular upper plate supported by two rectangular bases that acted as points of attachment. These are placed directly opposite one another across the equator of the circle. The pommel is decorated with a low relief moulded floral design, with a large central "Tudor" style rose with an inner core of four petals and a small circular central point, and an outer series of eight petals. This is further backed by a possible many-pointed star or series of many small leaves extending outwards to the rear of the flower. Measurements: Diameter: 31.69mm, thickness: 11.52mm, weight: 14.06g

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post medieval to modern lead alloy trade weight, dating to c. AD 1700-1850. This weight is circular with a central stamp that has created a raised, rounded ridge around the edge. The stamp appears to have irregular edges, with a channel at the six o'clock position that cuts through the rim created by the stamp's application. The stamp has resulted in a raised inscription which reads:"E.XO/NL"In the centre of the inscription, between the O and N, lies a raised design of three towers, the arms of the city of Exeter. The arms of Exeter, with their distinctively formed representation of Rougemont Castle (described as being triangular and triple towered in the blazon) were awarded in 1564. They are seen on a variety of objects, ranging from trade tokens to finger rings, where they were used as the mark of the city's assay office, as on DEV-E119FD. They feature on other weights, notably a copper alloy weight dating to the 16th century, recorded as SOM-F89D00. Ricketts (1996: 237) depicts a number of stamps and marks used to confirm weights and measures in the city of Exeter in the 19th century, almost all of which feature the three tower design. The city was apparently so attached to this design that it continued to use its own stamps for thirty years after national designs were imposed in the mid 1850s. This example in lead appears to act as evidence for continuity between the 16th and 19th century stamped weights of the city, as the style of the lettering appears 18th century in date. During this period, Exeter flourished as a trading and developing industrial centre, with foundries and workshops producing high quality objects such as Brufords silversmiths, and the large Willey's and Garton and King iron workshops. The initial L is possibly the mark of the workshop or tradesperson using the weight, which weighs close to 4oz. Measurements: 29.3mm diameter, 15.9mm thickness, weight 113.03g

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy seal matrix dating to the medieval period, c. AD 1300-1450.The die survives, as does the stub of the lug, but the loop is missing. It has been damaged post deposition, and now appears hexagonal in form, with some irregular edges. It is personal and non heraldic, with the matrix composed of two legends, an outer and inner legend. The inner legend reads AVE MARI. The outer legend is damaged and difficult to read, but certainly begins "S'" suggesting that the remaining legend contained the owner's name, which may be "DAVI" or less likely "DIYAN" although the lettering is unclear. Measurements: 19.2mm length, 17.4mm width, 2.5mm thickness, weight 3.57g.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A copper alloy trade weight dating to the post medieval to modern period, c. AD 1650-1850.The weight is circular in shape, with a raised outer rim and incised inner circles and a distinct circular depression of the flan at the centre. There are a number of initials and symbols placed around the outer perimeter, although these are not always clear due to post depositional damage. There appears to be an I or an anchor below a large letter C at the 10 o'clock position, and a large letter A at the 2 o'clock position. There are also the letters ID, or possibly the number 10, placed on the outer rim at around the 1 o'clock position.Measurements: 48.2mm diameter, 7.8mm thickness, weight xXg.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy trade weight dating to the post medieval to modern period, c. AD 1650-1850.The weight is circular in shape, with a raised outer rim and incised inner circles and a distinct flan at the centre. It is plain and undecorated on the reverse, and no incription or marking survives on the obverse. The weight implies it was used as a measure for 4 oz.Measurements: 47mm diameter, 6.1mm thickness, weight 115g.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A complete copper alloy buckle dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1500-1700.The buckle frame, central bar and pin all survive in good condition. The frame is double looped, and each loop is bilobed in shape. The central bar is triangular in cross section, while the remainder of the frame is D-shaped in cross section.The reverse is hollowed out, with a shallow channel running inside the buckle frame. The vertical sides of the frame are thickened at their centre, with one side more rounded in appearance and the other more angular. The central bar is also marked by small pointed knops. The pin is formed of a single strip of copper alloy which has been wrapped around the central bar, leaving an open loop. It is flattned in cross section and tapers to a sharp point. DEV-96AC48 is a similar, if slightly more elaborate example. Whitehead (1996: 48) no. 371 is a very similar example, dating from the 16th to 17th centuriesMeasurements: 44.9mm length, 26.2mm width,  1.9mm thickness, weight 8.74g.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A copper alloy harness mount of post medieval date, c. AD 1500-1700.The mount is triangular in shape, with its main body composed of an isosceles triangle, with two long sides coming together to its sharply pointed terminal. This is topped by a more globular knop. The entire composition is reminiscent of a dagger within a sheath. The larger area is marked by incised decoration, which traces the perimeter of the object, creating an inner triangle. There are two integral pointed lugs on the reverse, which are placed close to its centre.Egan (2005; p. 39) comments that this group of mounts were used as dress accessories and continued on horse harness straps into the 18th century. Measurements: 24.1mm length, 7.4mm width,  2.3mm thickness, weight 2.0g.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A copper alloy harness mount of post medieval date, c. AD 1500-1700.The mount is flattened in cross section, and pointed oval in shape, with trefoil knops at each terminal. It has a large pointed oval shaped aperture int he centre, and a wavy outer perimeter giving an undulating effect. The two integrally cast lugs survive but are slightly bent. These taper to a sharp point and are slightly longer than expected at c. 5.3mm in length.Egan (2005; p. 39) comments that this group of mounts were used as dress accessories and continued on horse harness straps into the 18th century. This example was found very close to DEV-311A79 and may be contemporary.Measurements: 26.2mm length, 10.1mm width,  1.1mm thickness, weight 1.43g.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A copper alloy harness mount of post medieval date, c. AD 1500-1700.The mount is flattened in cross section, and sub-rectangular in shape, although there are two distinctly flared areas which then nip in to the original width for decorative effect. It terminates in a pointed knop. Both the sharply pointed lugs survive on the reverse, and both are placed slightly off centre on the vertical line, with accretions of sediment surrounding their bases.It is very similar to DEV-9F9DE8, and to DEV-FA1FC6. Egan (2005; p. 39) comments that this group of mounts were used as dress accessories and continued on horse harness straps into the 18th century. Measurements: 28.1mm length, 7.4mm width,  1.2mm thickness, weight 1.83g.

Reverse showing initials L TM in triad, reading IN S. HAMTON 1668. Not recorded in Williamson. Measurements: 13.2mm diameter,  0.9mm thickness, weight 0.61g.

properties.description: A post medieval silver halfpenny of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603) dating to AD 1587-1589.As North (1991: 137) no. 2018. Crescent initial mark, Tower mint.Measurements: 9.1mm diameter,  0.4mm thickness, weight 0.25g.

properties.description: An extremely worn and folded medieval to post-Medieval silver coin of unknown ruler and unknown denomination, probably a penny, dating to c. AD 1272-1600.Illegible mint, no initial mark. Measurements: 17.9mm diameter,  0.5mm thickness, weight 0.88g.

properties.description: A post medieval silver halfpenny of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1625-1649.As North (1991: 163) no. 2274. Tower mint. Measurements: 9.8mm diameter,  0.3mm thickness, weight 0.26g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman radiate of unknown emperior, dating to c. AD 260-310. Unclear reverse type, unknown mint. Measurements: 20.2mm diameter,  1.4mm thickness, weight 3.2g.

properties.title: TOY
properties.description: A copper alloy post medieval toy musket dating to AD 1600-1700.The musket is cast in one piece with a long barrel which is circular in cross section, the barrel is hollow. On one side is a circular resevoir where the gun powder would have been loaded. The trigger guard survives in full but there is no extant trigger. DEV-56F8EB is very similar, as is BUC-5813EB, and that record references Forsyth and Egan (2005: 92), most likely type 2.Measurements: 72.1mm length, 4.8mm width, 7.2mm thickness, weight 15.4g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper-alloy Roman sestertius of Faustina II (AD 147-175), dating to the period c.AD 161-175 (Reece period 8). FECVND AVGVSTAE, S C, reverse type depicting Fecunditas standing facing, head left, holding two children in arms, between two standing children raising right hands. Mint of Rome. RIC III, p. 345, no. 1635; BMC IV, p. 530, no. 902ff.Measurements: 32.1mm diameter, 4.2mm thickness, weight 17.8g.

properties.description: A fragment of a post medieval silver coin of uncertain issue of James I (AD 1603-1625) dating to AD 1603-1625).Unclear initial mark, probably Tower mint. The fragment consists of approximately 35% of the coin.Measurements: The surviving fragment measures 11.2mm length, 9.1mm width, 0.3mm thickness, weight 0.40g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An incomplete post medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) dating to AD 1602.One initial mark, Tower mint. As North (1991: 137) no. 2015. Approximately 30% of the coin is missing from post depositional damage.Measurements: 25.1mm diameter, 0.7mm thickness, weight 1.70g.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A largely complete medieval copper alloy and enamel heraldic harness mount dating to AD 1200-1400. The object is lozenge shaped, it appears square at first glimpse but the position of its heraldic design implies that it would have been positioned to appear lozengiform. There is a short cylindrical attachment stud on the reverse, which is integrally cast, although the tip of the stud is now broken off. The upper surface is dominated by a heraldic design in red enamel, depicting a porcupine passant left. The porcupine looks to have once been infilled with silver or gilding, giving the arms the heraldic description: gules, porcupine passant left argent/or. There is a question and debate over the difference between a heraldic porcupine and the similarly prickly hedgehog, sometimes called an urchin. However, the length of the spines, the shape of the head and the snout appear to confirm that this is a porcupine and not a hedgehog. In terms of possible heraldic connections, the prominent Grylls family of Cornwall use a porcupine passant left as a device, as demonstrated on the post medieval CORN-AD6552. They are described in Cadell and Davies (1814) as being a Devon family who moved to Cornwall in the later 16th century and then became more prosperous through advantageous marriages. Whether the device was used in the medieval period by the same family is unclear.Putting the porcupine like features aside, the hedgehog device is also often associated with families with the name Harris. A prominent family of Devon Harrises were based at Radford House, Plymstock, from the mid 15th century at the latest, although some sources cite a John Harris as "3rd of Radstock" in 1420.Measurements:  15.1mm length, 14.6mm width, 2.5mm thickness, weight 2.32g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An extremely worn and folded medieval long cross silver penny of unknown ruler, dating from AD 1272-1485.Unknown mint, no visible initial marks. Measurements: 16.1mm diameter, 0.6mm thickness, weight 0.68g.

properties.description: A medieval silver halfpenny of Henry V (AD 1413-1422), dating to AD 1413-1422.Mint of London. Type A. As North (1991: 71) no. 1408.Measurements: 11.9mm diameter, 0.7mm thickness, weight 0.52g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver half groat of Elizabeth (AD 1558-1603) dating to AD 1590-92.Hand initial mark, Tower mint. As North (1991: 137) no. 2016.Measurements: 16.1mm diameter, 0.5mm thickness, weight 0.93g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy silver washed barbarous radiate, imitating an issue of the Diva Mariniana, wife of Valerian I, dating to the period c.AD 253-260 (Reece period 12).Copying CONSECRATIO reverse type, depicting a peacock in splendour standing. Unknown mint.Measurements: 15.4mm diameter, 2.2mm thickness, weight 3.06g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete Roman copper alloy large, south-western developed T-shaped brooch, probably dating to cAD 75 - 200.The wings, upper bow and part of the headplate survive. The wings are cylindrical, and appear to have been potentially hollow although the apertures at the terminals are partly filled with debris- the opening is visible in the central rectangular notch which would have once housed the hinge, attached to a pin which presumably filled the hollow wings. Above the wings rears the head plate, which is comprised of a rectangular plate and the stub of the once circular head loop. Only a small part of the left hand side of this circle survives. The rectangular plate is decorated with four transverse grooves, which give a slatted effect. The second space between these grooves is further elaborated by incised cross hatching. The bow rises gently from below the wings, and is much plainer in decoration, having only two deeply incised grooves extending vertically downwards, tracking its outer perimeter. This brooch forms part of a group of south western variants on T-shaped brooches discussed by Bayley and Butcher (2004: 167-8, fig. 140) which they define as characteristic of the second century. DOR-71C271 and SOM-156BAF are additional similar examples recorded on the database. Other possible parallels are illustrated by Mackreth (2011: plate 64) nos. 2624 & 2615, the later example dated to before AD 120, although his group 15.b. as whole has a date range covering the entire Roman period.Measurements: 38.9mm length, 34.2mm width, 4.9mm thickness (wings), 15.4mm width, 2.1mm thickness (bow), weight 10.10g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy Roman developed T-shaped brooch of Hull T105/6, dating to c. AD 50-150.The brooch comprises the wings and part of the bow, the lower part of the bow, footplate and pin are all now missing. The wings are cylindrical in shape with a broad rectangular notch at the centre where a significant amount of iron decay suggests that the iron hinge would have been located. The bow rises gently from the centre of the wings, and is flattened in cross section. It curves very steadily downwards to the break. The wings are decorated with a number of incised vertical lines, and the notch for the hinge is highlighted with an incised saltire enclosed within an outer square. Beneath this is a band of diagonal incised decorative lines, the ends of which sweep downwards to form an incised triangle. This leads into the decorative scheme on the bow, which is composed of a series of two surviving lozenges, each of which has a red enamelled smaller lozenge at its centre, although the enamel in the lower lozenge is less well preserved. The incised outer lines of the lozenges give the appearance of crossing over one another. The reverse is plain and undecorated. The lozenge style decoration is known from other south western variants of developed T-shaped brooches, including DEV-8F48F4, DEV-476924, and SOM-5E626E. Like the latter object, this example is similar to Mackreth's (2011: plate 63) no. 2759, identified as a type 12a. Another example of a developed T-shaped brooch can be seen illustrated by Bayley and Butcher (2004: 166, Hull's type 105/6), a development of the Flavian "initial" T-shaped brooch, they are dated to the late first and second centuries (ibid: 167). Bayley and Butcher (2004, 167-168) suggest that such brooches form a group with a distinctly South-Western distribution (see also finds list in Wedlake 1982, 127), and can be dated to AD 50 to 160.Measurements: 25.1mm length, 35.4mm width, 4.8mm thickness (wings), 8.2mm width 3.1mm thickness (bow), weight 8.11g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Roman denarius of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) dating to AD 194.FELICITAS TEMPOR reverse type depicting ears of corn between two cornucopiae. Mint of Emisa. As RIC IV Septimius Severus 374 Measurements: 17.4mm diameter, 1.9mm thickness, weight 2.37g.

Measurements: 28.9mm diameter, 4.9mm thickness, weight 22.47g.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A complete copper alloy buckle dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1660-1720.The buckle is double looped, with a possibly iron central bar that has corroded more significantly than the copper alloy frame, pin and plate. The loops are oval in shape, while the bar appears rectangular, flattened in cross section. Attached to the bar is a flattened plate, which divides into two terminals where it adheres to the frame, creating a Y shape. The pin is triangular in shape and flattened in cross section, tapering to a very sharp point.SOM-DFAAF7 and DOR-41A663 are similar examples on the database. A further similar example is illustrated in Whitehead (2003; 103), number 663, which is dated 1690-1720 AD.Measurements: 35.2mm length, 28.1mm width, 3.7mm thickness, weight 8.39g.

properties.title: MICROLITH
properties.description: An assemblage of five small flint micro implements dating from the Mesolithic periods, c. 7000-4000 BC. All five are formed of the same dark grey black flint:1) A blade formed on a secondary flake, with a tiny area of cortex surviving. Triangular in cross section, rectangular in shape, very slender and almost transparent at the cutting edges, which have been created  using abrupt retouch. Slightly larger removals are present at the distal end, giving a slightly waisted appearance. 16mm length, 13.1mm width, 3.2mm thickness,  weight 0.79g.2) A microlith formed on a very dark grey almost black flint, which has become almost blue in colour due to a white patina affecting its shade. It is triangular in plan and cross section, with a crescentic appearance, curving slightly to the right, to a point which is now broken. 18.2mm length, 8.5mm width, 2.2mm thickness, weight 0.33g.3) An elongated slender microlith formed on a mid grey flint, with white mottling and some iron staining present. Triangular in cross section, elongated isosceles triangle in plan. Abrupt very fine retouch present. 23.1mm length, 7.9mm width, 3.2mm thickness, weight 0.55g.4) A slender microlith formed on a secondary flake of mid grey flint, with a tiny area of white cortex at the distal end. Triangular in cross section, elongated isosceles triangle in plan, with a sharp point that survives. Fine retouch present, one removal possibly erroneous towards the proximal end on the left side, which has left a marked notch. 20.2mm length, 8.9mm width, 4.9mm thickness, weight 0.67g.5) A more rectangular microlith formed on a tertiary flake of brownish grey flint. Rectangular in plan with a slightly tapered proximal end, triangular in cross section. Abrupt retouch present. 19.2mm length,  11.9mm width, 3.7mm thickness, weight 0.65g.Total weight: 2.97g. Butler (2005: 88) notes that microliths were used in a number of different tools and weapons, most frequently as the tip/point of a wooden shaft or as a number of barbs along the sides of an arrow shaft.

properties.title: SCRAPER (TOOL)
properties.description: An assemblage of five scrapers dating from the Neolithic to Early Bronze Age periods, c. 2500-1500 BC. All five are formed of the same dark grey black flint:1) Secondary flake, with the surface now patinised to a paler grey shade with some white mottling and iron staining on both faces, and cortex retained at the distal end. "Thumbnail" shape, with flattened distal end and broad arching proximal end. There is abrupt scalar retouch at the proximal end to create the cutting edge. 29.4mm length, 32.9mm width, 9.9mm  thickness, weight 8.48g.2) Tertiary flake of dark grey flint,, with mottling on the dorsal and ventral faces. D shaped in cross section, "thumbnail" shape but more sub-circular than arc shaped in appearance. Abrupt retouch present, markedly present striking platform. 23.9mm length, 29.1mm width, 7.9mm thickness, weight 5.9g.3) Tertiary flake of dark grey flint, with a large area of paler grey paina, mottling and iron staining present. D shaped in cross section, larger sub-circular shape with marked dorsal spine. Removals at distal end appear somewhat incongruous, but a clear striking platform is present, as is rather crude abrupt retouch at the proximal end. 28.9mm length, 34.2mm width, 9.9mm thickness, weight 11.15g.4) A larger secondary flake of dark grey flint, with a very small area of cortex at the distal end. There are large areas of mid to lighter grey patina on both faces and mottling and iron staining present. It is sub-circular in shape and D-shaped in cross section. Abrupt scalar retouch is present. 35.1mm length, 32.1mm width, 9.9mm thickness, weight 15.1g.5) A smaller and more slender secondary flake of dark grey flint,with a small  area of cortex surviving at the proximal end. Much of the distal end is covered with a paler grey patina, while white mottling is spread across both dorsal and ventral faces. The shape is irregular, possibly originally sub-circular, but now thanks to a large removal or possible break, there is a more pointed appearance to the proximal end. There is a distinct striking platform present at the distal end, and abrupt scalar retouch visible on the right side. 37.1mm length, 23mm width,  5.9mm thickness, weight 7.49g.Total weight: 48.07g.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: A fragment of a copper alloy seal top spoon dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1550-1650, repurposed as a possible tooth pick.The fragment comprises the terminal of the handle and part of the stem. The stem is slender and circular in cross section, and has been sharpened to a fine point, to which it tapers. The knop is formed of a flattened oval disc, which is inscribed with the initials R D, capitalised in a Latin script. This is adhered to a slender cylindrical attachment point, which is then swollen by two decorative collars, the upper markedly thicker than the lower.It seems to have been repurposed as a possible toothpick, possibly after being accidentally broken, or forming part of a deliberate set of dining equipment for its owner. The sharpened break, with its slight bend, would form an ideal implement for probing between the teeth, and would retain the object's connection with a food consumption scenario. The initials suggest personal ownership, and other examples of spoons with initials are recorded on the database, including DOR-E677DF and LIN-FF1016, and in silver, LEIC-FB4A8A.Measurements: 32.1mm length, 14.9mm diameter of knop, 3.2mm thickness of stem,  weight 3.79g.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy seal matrix of medieval date, c. AD 1400-1500.It is a conical seal matrix, with a hexagonal die. The terminal is missing, the break is just above the rectangular collar of three ridges. The break along the line of the apertures suggests a possible trefoil terminal, but this is speculative. There is a possible orientation mark, and the ridges of the conical design align with the design on the die. The design features a male and female bust facing one another. Both are dressed in 15th century fashions in terms of hair and head dress styling. Between them is a flowering plant, or possibly an oak tree with an acorn,  which appears to grow from a long trunk. At the base of the trunk is curled a sleeping lion, lion dormant. The inscription reads " SV ET IO DVLCE EST," which may be translated as "He and I are sweet," suggesting that the seal may have belonged to a woman. The combination of the sentimental legend with the facing couple may suggest that the seal marked a betrothal or marriage. CAM-83011F has a similar design, and cites a number of earlier examples, but this design is significantly more sophisticated in its execution and use of Latin, so a later date is appropriate. Measurements: 19.1mm length, 13.2mm width,  11mm thickness, weight 4.42g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: An extremely worn post medieval copper alloy trade token dating to c. AD 1600- 1700.The token is badly worn, and the designs and legends on both obverse and reverse are illegible.  Measurements: 15.1mm diameter, 0.7mm thickness, weight 0.49g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy trade token farthing dating to c. AD 1600- 1700.The token is badly worn but the central inscription EXON is visible on both faces. It is therefore an Exeter token farthing, although the issuer remains unknown due to the wear. Measurements: 16.9mm diameter, 0.6mm thickness, weight 0.40g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy "rose" farthing of Charles I (1625- 1649) dating to 1634-36.An example of North (1991: 165) Type 2 no. 2291.Measurements: 13.2mm diameter, 1.1mm thickness, weight 0.73g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy "rose" farthing of Charles I (1625- 1649) dating to 1634-36.An example of North (1991: 165) Type 2 no. 2291.Measurements: 12.9mm diameter, 1.1mm thickness, weight 0.82g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy "rose" farthing of Charles I (1625- 1649) dating to 1634-36.An example of North (1991: 165) Type 1 Class B, no. 2288.Measurements: 14.0mm diameter, 1.3mm thickness, weight 0.72g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver sixpence of James I (1603- 1625) dating to 1607.Second coinage, minted at London.Escallop initial mark. As North (1991: 146) no. 2103.Measurements: 26.1mm diameter, 1.2mm thickness, weight 2.57g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper alloy pot leg dating to the post medieval period, c. 1500-1750.The leg is D-shaped in cross section with a flat back and a convex front. It has three conjoined convex ribs on the outer face, evenly spaced apart and relatively shallow. Above the ribs is a raised fetlock which runs horizontally across the outer face. The break is directly above this fetlock, but the ribs continue above it up to the break, and survive in better condition here. The foot has a markedy pointed central rib, and as a result is triangular in cross section.Cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from AD1200 to 1700 for serving and cooking. Legs and feet are the most commonly recorded finds and Butler et alii (2009: 4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is an example of Type C which they suggest was already in use by the 16th century and was almost universal in the 17th century. Measurements: 32.1mm length, 22.3mm width, 11.8mm thickness, weight 28.52g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper alloy pot leg dating to the post medieval period, c. 1500-1750.This example is relatively slender and delicate for this class of vessel, and appears to have been short. The leg is D-shaped in cross section with a flat back and a convex front. It has three conjoined convex ribs on the outer face, evenly spaced apart. Above the ribs is a raised fetlock which runs horizontally across the outer face. The break is directly above this fetlock.Cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from AD1200 to 1700 for serving and cooking. Legs and feet are the most commonly recorded finds and Butler et alii (2009: 4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is an example of Type C which they suggest was already in use by the 16th century and was almost universal in the 17th century. The small size suggests a vessel for a single serving only. Measurements: 27.5mm length, 17.5mm width, 10.9mm thickness, weight 20.8g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper alloy pot leg dating to the post medieval period, c. 1500-1750.The leg is D-shaped in cross section with a flat back and a convex front. It has four conjoined convex ribs on the outer face, evenly spaced apart. Above the ribs is a raised fetlock which runs horizontally across the outer face. It remains D-shaped in cross section even to the foot. Cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from AD1200 to 1700 for serving and cooking. Legs and feet are the most commonly recorded finds and Butler et alii (2009: 4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is an example of Type C which they suggest was already in use by the 16th century and was almost universal in the 17th century.Measurements: 44.3mm length, 31.2mm width, 18.6mm thickness, weight 119g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper alloy pot leg dating to the post medieval period, c. 1500-1750.The object is D-shaped in cross section and broadly rectilinear in form, tapering to a blunt rectangular edge. There is an old break at the point where the leg would have once joined the body of the vessel. No part of the body of the vessel survives adhered to this. There are a series of five ribs, which while subtle are nonetheless clearly present, which run down the length of the leg. There is also an extended rounded foot, as the middle three ribs swell and curve downwards to create the terminal. This example is representative of Butler et al (2009, 4)'s Type C, which they consider as in use by the 16th century and "almost universal" by the 17th century. The exaggerated foot suggests a date towards the later end of this time frame.Measurements: 52.9mm length, 40.6mm width, 25.1mm thickness, weight 215g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper alloy pot leg dating to the post medieval period, c. 1500-1750.The object is D-shaped in cross section and broadly rectilinear in form, tapering to a blunt rectangular edge. There is an old break at the point where the leg would have once joined the body of the vessel. There are a series of five ribs, which while subtle are nonetheless clearly present, which run down the length of the leg. This example is representative of Butler et al (2009, 4)'s Type C, which they consider as in use by the 16th century and "almost universal" by the 17th century.Measurements: 61.3mm length, 37.4mm width, 17.5mm thickness, weight 134g.

properties.title: KEY (LOCKING)
properties.description: A fragment of a copper alloy rotary key dating to the post medieval period, c. AD 1500-1700.Only the terminal of the handle of the key survives. The key itself would have been rectangular in cross section, as is the handle itself. In plan it is a rounded lozenge, with three distinct pointed knops at each cardinal point. The edges are undulating, with a single completed wave between each knop. It is decorated with four circular apertures, which create a double spandrel in their centre. The initials MO are placed below the apertures on one side, possibly a maker's or owner's mark.SUR-2A0636 is similar, albeit with a more elaborate openwork pattern. The openwork style is reminiscent of earlier medieval openwork keys such as keys of London Type VI, including WMID-643E11, but the initials suggest a later post medieval date. Measurements: 33.9mm length, 36.5mm width, 5.9mm thickness, weight 19.25g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A  worn and incomplete post-medieval silver probable half groat of James I (1603-1625) dating to AD 1604-1609.Second coinage. Tower mint. As North (1991: 146) no. 2104. Approximately 30% of the coin is now missing.Measurements: 18.2mm diameter, 1.3mm thickness, weight 0.78g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A  post-medieval Scottish silver twenty pence of Charles I (1625-1649) dating to AD 1625-1636.Second coinage, XX behind head. Mint of Edinburgh. Measurements: 16.1mm diameter, 0.7mm thickness, weight 0.75g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A pierced post-medieval silver penny of James I (1603-1625) dating to AD 1604-1619.Second coinage, no initial mark, Tower mint. As North (1991:  146) no. 2106/1.It is pierced at the 7 o'clock position on the obverse. The piercing is rough and irregular, so does not suggest the coin being used as jewellery.Measurements: 13.9mm diameter, 0.8mm thickness, weight 0.57g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post-medieval silver penny of Elizabeth (1558-1603) dating to AD 1561-65.Second coinage, Pheon initial mark, Tower mint. As North (1991:  135) no. 2001.Measurements: 13.2mm diameter, 0.6mm thickness, weight 0.40g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post-medieval silver Portuguese vintem (20 reis) of Pedro II (AD 1683- 1706), dating to AD 1683-1706.Minted at Porto. As Krause and Mishler (1993:823) no. 133.Measurements: 13.9mm  diameter, 1.1mm thickness, weight 0.51g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver cut penny of Philip and Mary (1554-1558) dating to AD 1554-1558.Cut from a groat, as North (1991:129) no. 1973. Tower mint, Lis initial mark. Measurements: 11.1mm radius, 0.9mm thickness, weight 0.31g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth (1558-1603), dating to 1562.Second coinage, Pheon initial mark, Tower mint. As North (1991: 134) no. 1997.Measurements: 23.9mm diameter, 1.2mm thickness, weight 2.55g.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A fragment of a pressed copper alloy purse bar of post medieval date, c. AD 1600-1700.The object is formed from a folded sheet of copper alloy which is now infilled with soil, rendering it V-shaped in cross section. It is loosely rectilinear in shape and curves steadily along its length. There is a circular suspension loop which extends from its underside. The terminal adjacent to the suspension loop appears rectangular on one side, but on the other can be seen to be more ointed, with a raised ridge demarcating its end. A rivet hole is present on the same side, located at the opposite end close to the break. Folded purse frames are recorded on the database, examples include SOM-45F3A6 and BH-BAA898.Measurements: 59.8mm length, 11.1mm width, 6.1mm thickness, weight 19.41g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman radiate, possibly barbarous, of unknown emperor, dating to AD 260-310.Unclear mint, unclear reverse type. Measurements: 22mm diameter, 1.88mm thickness, weight 3.66g

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A copper-alloy open type sheet thimble or 'sewing ring' of late medieval to early post medieval date, c. AD 1450-1600.This thimble is circular in plan with sides which taper inwards from the bottom to the top. The outside is decorated with punched circular indents, arranged fairly regularly in four rows in a spiral. The metal has corroded to a blackened patina. The splayed base was to allow an easier fit on the finger and is also chronologically diagnostic to the late Medieval or early Post Medieval periods (Holmes 1988, 3).Measurements: 18.4.mm diameter, 1.58mm thickness, weight 3.67g

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: An incomplete post medieval copper alloy belt or harness mount dating to c. AD 1500-1650.The object is cruciform in plan, with a lozenge shaped centre. It is flattened in cross section, save for a raised central circle. The circle forms the heart of a flower with eight petals, probably a rose, on the petals of which traces of red enamel survive. The ends of the cross are divided as lis, creating an impression of a cross fleury. The reverse is plain and undecorated but has two attachment rivets, cylindrical in shape and integrally cast. Only one rivet survives in full, the other is bent and damaged at its terminal.Measurements: 20.4MM LENGTH, 20.7MM WIDTH, 1.6MM THICKNESS WEIGHT 2.20G

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver penny of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), dating to 1591-94.Tun initial mark. Mint of London. As North (1991: 137) no. 2017. Approximately 25% of the coin is missing due to post depositional damage.Measurements: 16.9mm diameter 0.97mm thickness weight 0.89g

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: A fragment of a post medieval lead alloy spoon, dating to c. 1750-1800.The fragment consists of the spoon terminal, which is rounded with a central ridge. The edges are damaged and worn, although the tapering form of the handle can be seen. It is plain and undecorated on the reverseA spoon in the collections of the University of Birmingham is very similar, no. 59/56/260. That complete example is described as "Pewter spoon with oval (?) section stem and rounded, upturned end with central ridge. Ownership triad to back of stem top. Maker's mark of rose with petals, crowned X and illegible label to reverse of stem. Double-drop reinforcement where stem meets bowl."Measurements: 44.26mm length, 15.2mm width, 5.2mm thickness, weight 12.5g

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: An incomplete late medieval to post medieval copper alloy harness pendant, dating to c. 1450-1600.The pendant is formed of a sexfoliate flower, with a large circular centre which has decayed to a different coloured patina to its surrounding petals (it is a darker rich brown, while the petals have a paler yellow brown tinge). The flower is suspended by a hinge from the upper part of a circular ring with a scalloped inner edge, which accomodates the suspended flower's petals, ensuring it would have been free moving in use. This ring is in turn attached to a suspension loop which is largely missing.LON-DC06DC is a similar example, albeit with a different patina and with a more simplistic and angular central suspended flower. Griffiths (1995) describes harness pendants as being out of fashion by the late 15th century, but this variation may represent a slightly later form allied to newly fashionable and politically relevant floral iconography of the 16th century.Measurements: 34.9mm length, 23.7mm width, 1.6mm thickness weight 6.7g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Henry III (1216-1272), dating to 1253-1256.Minted at Canterbury by Nicole. As North (1980; 182) no. 992, class 5b.Measurements: Diameter: 18.42mm, thickness: 0.14mm, weight: 1.28 g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver penny of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), dating to 1583-1603.Mint of London. Third coinage. Initial mark missing. (North 1991: 137, no. 2017).Measurements: Diameter: 13.32mm, thickness: 0.68mm, weight: 0.46 g.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A copper alloy Post Medieval floral mount dating from c.1500-1700.The object is broadly sub-circular in shape, with a convex front and concave reverse. The front has a somewhat unclear floral design, with raised central boss surrounded by semi-circular incised lines forming small circular petals around the edge of the mount. The reverse is plain apart from a central fixing pin, possibly rectangular in cross-section, which has been bent over to touch the edge of the mount.Measurements: Diameter: 22.79mm, thickness: 7.87mm, weight: 7.57 grams.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver cut penny of Charles I (1625-1649) dating to AD 1640.Star initial mark. Mint of London. As North (1991: 162) Group D no. 2258. The coin has been deliberately cut in half to make a penny from a half groat. Measurements: 16.1mm diameter, 0.9mm thick, weight 0.34g

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A lead alloy uniface token of Post Medieval date, c. 1600-1750. The object is very worn, and approximately circular. The object is flattened in cross section. The reverse is flat and plain. The front is somewhat corroded, but shows markings that could be initials, possibly a T and other letters to the side, arranged in the manner of a personal seal but very obscure.An example of Powell type 2, lead token with initials.Measurements: diameter 22.43mm, thickness 4.74mm, weight 12.08 g.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete Roman copper alloy brooch dating to the first century AD, c. AD 43-100.The brooch consists of the wings and part of the bow, the hinge, pin and catch plate are all missing. The arms are short and tapering, but broadly cylindrical in cross section. There is a wide triangular notched void at the centre where the hinge would have been, and the head appears rolled under, with the flattened plate of the bow emerging from it at a gentle angle. The bow is decorated with small incised decoration which appears to create a series of widening segments in a triangular shape. The bow then narrows markedly to a central slender point, at which it is broken. The broad spread of the wings with the large slot for the hinge is similar to Hattatt (1982: 93) no. 58, which he describes as a British made Hod Hill derivative of the "Fiddle" type. This example also shows an abrupt narrowing of the bow, as is suggested in the Devon case. Hattatt dates this example to AD 44-51. Bayley and Butcher (2004: 154) also discuss and present loosely similar examples, including their T53, which they describe as having a wide variety of forms characterised as the products of indigenous craftspeople copying the form but not the detail of the hinge on newly introduced brooch types.Measurements: 32.9mm width, 24.9mm length, 2.9mm thickness, weight 8.35g

properties.title: VESSEL
