properties.description: A post-Medieval cast copper alloy pot leg dating to c.AD 1500-1700. The leg and foot are triangular in section with a flat back and convex front; the leg is broken off above a transverse collar with an old break. The prominent collar is triangular in section, with the remaining section of leg running below it, which has a prominent central rib flanked by a smaller rib either side. The base of the leg flares downwards into a hoofed foot with a flat base, somewhat rounded due to being worn.The leg is a dark grey/brown colour and abraded.Cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from AD 1200 to 1700 for serving and cooking. Legs and feet are the most commonly recorded finds and Butler et al (2009, 4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is an example of Type C which they suggest was already in use by the 16th century and was almost universal in the 17th century.Measurements: Length 40.45mm, width 27.33mm, thickness 16.33mm, weight 60.65g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver half groat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603), dating to AD 1582-1583. Third coinage, bell initial mark. London mint. As North (1991: 137) no. 2016.Measurements: diameter 16.15mm, thickness 0.64mm, weight 0.75g.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A copper alloy Post Medieval strap fitting, probably strap slide, dating to c. 1550-1650.The object has a rectilinear frame which is D-shaped in cross section on the vertical sides, and flattened in cross section on the horizontal sides. In the centre of the upper horizontal bar is a large decorative knop, which flares outwards before tapering and flaring to a rounded point once again. There is an additional, more pointed, terminal. At the base of the knop is a horizontal line. The reverse is plain and undecorated. Post-deposition, the lower horizontal bar has been bent inwards slightly. SUR-14F8BC is a similar example which was once gilded. No trace of gilding survives on this example. Measurements: length 22.99mm, width 23.98mm, thickness (of knop) 2.97mm, thickness (of frame) 12.50, weight 3.65g.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A copper alloy Post Medieval to Modern stacking weight, dating to c. 1800-1850.The weight is circular with flaring sides and a raised rim. It is somewhat worn, but was originally flat and plain on the upper surface. There is a central lathe-turned incised circle, overlapped with three stamped marks. One may be a sword (at 9 o' clock), an urn or teapot (at 6 o'clock) and an unclear shape, possibly a backwards S (at 3 o' clock). The edges are plain. The underside is flat and has multiple file adjustment marks.It is very similar to objects IOW-B26E82 and BUC-EB3A53, although the stamped marks differ.Measurements: diameter 17.80mm, thickness 4.57mm, weight 6.16g.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A copper alloy button of Post Medieval date, c. 1650.The object is very worn, approximately circular, and hollow, with a convex front and concave back. The front shows a possible four-petalled flower with several lines radiating from the centre between each petal. The reverse is plain, with a central rectangular-section shank with rounded end, which is slightly curved at the end furthest from the button. The pierced shank hole appears to be filled with iron oxide.Similar buttons can be found in Read (2005, p. 36-45), where they are interpreted as cloak fasteners. Iron wire, clips and iron oxide found in the shank holes of other examples may relate to this use.Measurements: length 24.24mm, width 23.65mm, thickness 7.58mm, weight 4.13g.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A copper alloy button of Post Medieval date, c. 1600-1800 (Read 2005, p. 30, 34-35). The object is worn, approximately circular, and flattened in cross section. The front shows possible floral decoration with six points around the edge, and faint traces of rounded petals towards the centre. The reverse is flat, with rectangular raised area in the centre, with a protrusion at either end where a shank with pierced hole has been broken off, leaving a worn break.Similar buttons can be found in Read (2005, p. 34 and 35), nos. 120, 121 and 122.Measurements: length 13.32mm, width 11.67mm, thickness 4.27mm, weight 1.55g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A lead alloy uniface token of Post Medieval date, c. 1600-1750.The object is worn, and approximately circular. The object is flattened in cross section. The reverse is flat. The front shows initials, possibly BC, although the second letter is somewhat obscured.An example of Powell type 2, lead token with initials.Measurements: diameter 19.24mm, thickness 2.26mm, weight 4.45g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A lead alloy uniface token of post medieval date, c. AD 1600-1750.The object is worn, circular in shape and flattened in cross section. The reverse is flat. The obverse shows a central cross, with four quarters containing multiple chevrons pointing towards the centre and extending to the edge.An example of Powell type 12, lead token with quartered geometric design.Measurements: diameter 18.24mm, thickness 2.07mm, weight 4.13g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A lead alloy uniface token of post medieval date, c. 1600-1750.The object is worn, circular and shape and flattened in cross section. The reverse is plain and undecorated. The front is somewhat corroded, but with markings that appear to be five flower petals emanating from a central circle.An example of Powell type 1, lead token with petalled flower.Measurements: diameter 15.94mm, thickness 3.05mm, weight 4.14g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A lead alloy uniface token of Post Medieval date, c. 1600-1750.The object is very worn, and while possibly originally circular, has become more drop-shaped. The object is flattened in cross section. The reverse may originally have been flat, but is now somewhat corroded. Markings on the front appear to be initials, possibly R A. An example of Powell type 2, lead token with initials. Measurements: diameter - 16.89mm, thickness 4.28mm, weight 6.77g.

properties.title: PIPE TAMPER
properties.description: An incomplete post-medieval lead alloy anthropomorphic pipe tamper dating to c. 1680-1750.Only the upper plaque of the pipe tamper survives. It depicts a nude male and female figure engaging in standing sexual intercourse, posed beneath a tree branch. The female figure's leg is lifted to expose penetration to the viewer. B It is flat on the reverse. Both figures appear to have long hair which is tied back in distinct styles.It is very similar to WILT-FE9706 and to NCL-739535, both of which survive in much better condition and show the entirety of the scene, with the tree featured more prominently than the branch which survives in this example. Erotic scenes such as this were popular with 18th century pipe tampers, used to press down tobacco, presumably accompanied by ribald comments.Measurements: 49.18mm length, 28.64mm width, 7.04mm thickness 48.3g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A worn copper-alloy coin, possibly a Roman radiate of unclear ruler, perhaps Claudius II (AD 268-270), dating to the period c.AD 260-275 (Reece period 13). Unclear reverse type or mint. Measurements: 16.9mm diameter, 3.1mm thick, weight 2.99g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A worn copper-alloy Roman coin, probably a radiate of unclear type, dating to the period c.AD 260-296. Illegible reverse type. Unclear mint. Measurements: 15.2mm diameter, 4.0mm thick, weight 2.80g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward II (1307-1327) dating from 1310-1314.Class 11d, as North (1991: 36), no. 1062/2. Minted at Canterbury.There is a slender crack extending from the ten o'clock position to the centre of the coin, and it has been bent post depositionally.Measurements: 17.8mm diameter, 1.2 mm thick, weight 0.89g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A clipped medieval silver penny of Henry VI (first reign, 1422-1461), annulet coinage, dating from 1422-1427.Minted at York. As North (1991: 75) no. 1433, with lis by the bust and quatrefoil at centre of the reverse. Part of the coin is missing due to two distinct clips from the 9 o'clock to the 1 o'clock position, leaving no initial mark. There is a suggestion that the reverse was mis-struck, with a shadow pellet appearing in one quarter.Measurements: 15.1mm diameter, 0.9 mm thick, weight 0.69g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A very worn post medieval silver threepence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), second issue, dating from 1561-1582.No visible initial mark or date, mint of London. As North (1991: 135) no. 2000.Measurements: 19.2mm diameter, 0.8 mm thick, weight 1.02g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A worn and damaged post medieval silver coin, probably a three half pence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) dating to 1561-1582.No visible initial mark or date, mint of London. As North (1991: 135) no. 2000.Measurements: 21mm diameter, 0.6 mm thick, weight 0.92g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval pierced silver penny of the Commonwealth of England (1649-1660) dating from 1649-1660.No initial mark or date. Mint of London. As North (1991: 206), no. 2729. The pierced aperture is placed at the foot of the shield of St George, piercing through from the obverse to the reverse, possibly as an act of devaluation.Measurements: 14.5mm diameter, 0.9 mm thick, weight 0.53g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy Irish half penny of Charles II (1645-1685), dating from AD 1680-1684.An example of Armstrong and Legge's regal coinage, as Spink (2015: 184) no. 6574. The coin is badly wornand damaged, so cannot be identified further. Legends illegible.Measurements: 18.9mm diameter, 1.9mm thickness, weight 0.96g

properties.title: SCRAPER (TOOL)
properties.description: A flint thumbnail scraper of late Neolithic to Early Bronze Age date, c. 2400 to 2200 BCE.The scraper is formed of a dark grey flint with small areas of pale grey patina, which are present on both the dorsal and ventral faces. It is discoidal in form and bi-convex in cross section. The striking platform and bulb of percussion are retained and clearly visible. The dorsal face shows invasive semi-abrupt retouch around the proximal end and along the lateral edges, with a particularly large removal on the right side of the dorsal face. There are two, possibly accidental, removals at the proximal end of the ventral face.Measurements: 32.5mm length, 29.4mm width, 9.3mm thick weight 8.64g.

properties.title: PENCIL
properties.description: An incomplete Modern silver pencil cover or porte crayon dating to c. 1800- 1920.The object is cylindrical in form and hollow on the inside. It is formed from a single sheet of silver that has been folded to create a tube. The join of the fold is now clearly visible due to damage post deposition. The majority of the surface is covered with a floral design, which surrounds a deliberately blank trapezoidal central area, giving a framing effect. This blank central space is directly opposite the join and clearly designed to be viewed. A deliberately punched circular aperture is present just above the open end. The aperture is placed in a band of plain silver, which is differentiated from the main floral design that occupies the majority of the surface. At both the open and closed ends the object is encircled by a a raised line. At the open end this is slender, and at the closed end it is thick. On the closed end of the object, the circular cover is embossed with the letter B, possibly an initial or possibly a maker's mark. There is no visible hallmark.Measurements:  39.4mm length, 7mm diameter, 1.2mm thickness, weight 2.81g

properties.title: DENTAL IMPLEMENT
properties.description: An incomplete and misshapen Modern silver dental plate, dating to c. 1800-1920.The plate consists of part of the palate, the gum area and a series of five teeth, probably intended to represent the lower incisors and possibly a canine. Only three survive in good order, but the stubs of the other two are clearly visible. The odd number of teeth appears unusual, so it is likely that an additional tooth was once present but is now missing, possibly in the gap between what now appear to be the front incisors. The teeth are crudely rendered and largely rectangular in form, but each tooth is different and appears to have been moulded onto the palate individually. Gilding survives on the front of the teeth, which would presumably have once appeared entirely golden. Any attachment point no longer survives.Most of the dentures/dental implements recorded on this database are made from gold and a silver one is relatively rare, as the record for LANCUM-F66F0B states. That example appears more exclusive with its more realistic porcelain teeth. Most of the gold dentures or dental plates still hold their shape and still have some of the teeth in place, and in terms of form. This may be an earlier example due to the crudeness of the design and the metal teeth themselves, or may simply belong to an individual without access to more elaborate dental assistance.Measurements: 47.8mm length, 13.5mm width, 1.2mm thick, weight 6.5g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An incomplete post medieval silver shilling of Charles I (1625-1649) dating from 1631-32.The coin has been systematically clipped, reducing it in size and removing the inscriptions. However, the coin does appear to be an example of Nicholas Briot's milled coinage, as North (1991: 166) no. 2300. No initial mark survives.Measurements: 28.8mm diameter, 1.3mm thickness, weight 2.53g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward II (1307-1327) dating to 1317-1323.North (1993: 37) no. 1065, Class 14. Minted at London.Measurements: 19.8mm diameter, 1.1mm thickness, weight 1.44g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy dupondius or as of unknown emperor, dating to c. AD 43- 260. Unclear reverse type with standing figure. Mint unknown.Measurements: 28mm diameter, 4.7mm thick weight 11.47g

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A complete post medieval copper alloy discoidal button dating to the 16-18th century.The button has a convex outer face and concave reverse. The front is decorated with a geometrical pattern resembling a five armed "cross" over two concentric lines. There is a raised circular decoration in its central part, possibly the remains of a central knop. The reverse is undecorated and has a complete integral attachment loop in the middle.OXON-C02D9A shows a similar decoration.Measurements: Diameter: 23.1 mm Thickness: 2.8 mm Weight: 6.41 g

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy pot leg probably from a cooking pot or cauldron, dating AD 1500-1700.Very similarly to DEV-23438E, the fragment is D-shaped in cross section, and takes the form of a slightly flared hoof-like foot and prominent ridged fetlock-like band, with the break 7.5 mm above the ridge. The protruding fetlock band is almost as wide as the flared end of the foot. The front of the foot is decorated with a prominent central rib and two smaller ones that run parallel at each side. The back of the foot fragment is plain and sits almost flat when set on a flat surface.As DEV-3014BB reminds us, crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg that developed over this period. This is an example of their Type C, which was in use by the late 16th century and remained popular throughout the 17th century.Measurements:Length: 47.2 mmWidth: 22.2 mmThickness: 14.1 mmWeight: 60.08 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver half groat of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603) dating to 1582-83.Third coniage. Bell initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 137) no. 2016.Obverse: [E D G] ROSA SINE SP[INA]. Crowned bust left with two pellets behind.Reverse: CIV[ITAS] LONDON. Square shield on cross fourchee. Bell initial mark.Measurements: Diameter: 16.8 mm Thickness: 0.8 mm Weight: 1.07 g

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: A complete Medieval cast copper-alloy seal matrix of pointed oval shape (vesica) dating to the 14th century.The die has a central incised design probably meant to represents the pelican in her piety with the pelican over her nest. There is a plain line around the design with a worn inscription which reads retrograde as to appear the correct way round when used. The back is flat completely flat apart from the central vertical ridge which extends to a worn integral suspension loop at the top.As KENT-DEA97A reminds us, this type of matrix is not a personal seal. It would have been purchased already inscribed (or 'off the shelf') and were originally used by people unable to commission their own personal seal. Anonymous non-heraldic seals bearing pious motifs and sayings become particularly more common and smaller after 1300 (Harvey & McGuiness 1996, 88). It is therefore probable that this example comes from the 14th century.Measurements: Length: 29.9 mm Width: 19.7 mm Thickness: 3.5 mm Weight: 9.08 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver half groat of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603) dating to 1601-2.Third coinage. One initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 137) no. 2016.Obverse: E D G ROSA SINE [SP]INA. Crowned bust left with two pellets behind.Reverse: CIVITAS LONDON. Square shield on cross fourchee. One initial mark.The obverse is very worn in its central part but most of the inscription is clearly legible.Measurements: Diameter: 16.9 mm Thickness: 0.8 mm Weight: 0.89 g

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete cast copper alloy Colchester derivative "developed" T-shaped brooch dating to the Roman period (50-150 AD).Only the wings and a small fragment of the bow survive.The wings are cylindrical in shape, sub-circular in cross section, perpendicular to the bow and are decorated with two parallel circular grooves at each end. The wings contain the axis bar for the hinged pin, a small fragment of which is still visible on the reverse side. There is a central slot on the reverse of the wings, to allow the hinges to move. The humped head of the bow is convex and decorated with a central ridge which probably ran the length of the bow.It is similar in essentials to a more elaborate example depicted in Bayley and Butcher (2004: 166), no. T120. That example is dated to the late first and early second centuries, and this fragment is probably contemporaneous, an example of another variant of the South Western phenomenon of developed T shaped brooches.Measurements: Length: 13.8 mm Width: 44.2 mm Thickness: 6.2 mm Weight: 8.52 g

properties.title: SPINDLE WHORL
properties.description: A lead alloy spindle whorl dating to the medieval to post medieval period (c.1100-1500).The spindle whorl is sub-oval in plan, D-shaped in cross section and rests flat when rested on a flat surface. There is a central uneven perforation on both sides; both openings, which were probably sub-circular in shape originally, now taper into an elongated tear shape. One almost three times the size of the other. The outer surface is decorated with an uneven series of circular punctured incisions that vary in size and depth. The outer and inner walls of the spindle appear worn and uneven, which is compatible with the tear and wear that comes with the usage of the spindle whorl.As LVPL-4C0671 reminds us, lead weights of this form were commonly used throughout the Medieval and Post-Medieval period and are therefore difficult to date accurately. Examples of spindle whorls have reportedly been found in contexts dated from the Roman through to the Post-Medieval period although the majority are typically dated broadly to the medieval period c.1100-1500.Measurements: Length: 23.8 mm Width: 21.4 mm Thickness: 6.7 mm Weight: 29.44 g

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A copper alloy post medieval floral mount dating from 1500-1700.The object is broadly sub circular in shape, in the design of a convex flower with six petals. Each petal is separated by an incised radial line. The end of each petal is slighly raised and separated by the rest of its body by a semi circular line, creating a boss like shape at the end of each petal.The back of the mount is concave and undecorated apart from the the stub of an integrally cast fixing pin which projects from the centre of the mount.It is similar to SUR-A2AEC7 and NLM-7AA3B6, both of which are also post medieval in date, dating from the 16th to 17th centuries.Measurements:Diameter: 37.8 mmThickness: 2.8 mmWeight: 11.24 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A worn post medieval fragment of a silver coin, probably a sixpence, of Elizabeth I (1558-1603).Mint and initial mark unclear.Obverse type: crowned bust of Elizabeth facing left with rose behind.Reverse type: Square shield with long cross fourch�e.Measurements:Thickness: 0.9 mmWeight: 0.51 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A very worn post medieval silver Sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603).Obverse: Crowned bust of Elizabeth facing left with rose behind. [ELIZABETH D G ANG FR ET HIB] REGIN[A]Reverse: Square shield with long cross fourch�e, 1570 above. [POSVI] DEV [AD]IVTO[REM MEV].Mint and initial mark unclear.The coin is bent and in very poor condition. There is a portion of coin missing at 9 o'clock, possibly deliberately clipped.Measurements: Diameter: 24.8 mm Thickness: 0.8 mm Weight: 2.13 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) dating to 1578.7th issue, mint of London, plain cross initial mark, as North (1991:1997).Obverse: Crowned bust of Elizabeth facing left with rose behind. ELIZABETH D G ANG FR ET HIB REGIReverse: Square shield with long cross fourch�e,?????? 1578 above POSVI DEV ADIVTOREM ME[V].Although now bent to an "S" shape the coin is in good conditions.Measurements: Diameter: 26.1 mm Thickness: 1.1 mm Weight: 2.70 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver threepence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) dating to AD 1570.Mint of London, castle initial mark. North (1991: 135) no. 1998.Obverse: Crowned bust of Elizabeth facing left with rose behind. ELIZABETH D G ANG [FRA ET HIBER REGINA]Reverse: Square shield with long cross fourch�e, 1570 above.POSUI [DEUM AD I]UTOREM MEUM.Measurements: Diameter: 24.8 mm Thickness: 0.8 mm Weight: 1.13 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy nummus of the House of Constantine dating to AD 348 to 350 (Reece period 18). FEL TEMP REPARATIO depicting a soldier going right and looking back left dragging a smaller figure from a wooden hut. Mint unclear.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A complete copper alloy Trade Weight dating to the Post Medieval to Modern date c. AD 1700-1850.This trade weight comprises a disc which has been ground down on one side leaving a rim around the edge. In the centre is a ring-and-dot used to hold the weight while it was being ground. There are two identifying marks overlapping the rings in the depressed section. The first mark is the sword of St Paul for the City of London, the second is unclear.The reverse is flat and, apart from the numerous file marks, plain.Measurements: Diameter: 31.9 mm Thickness: 5.6 mm Weight: 26.33 g

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A complete post medieval cast lead Russian cloth seal, for hemp or flax, dating to the 18th to 19th century.The seal consists of two joined discs, one showing the arms of Russia, a double headed eagle, with an inscription in Cyrillic above; the other is plain.The original inscription would have read ?????-????????? (Saint Peterburg) to indicate the port of origin but unfortunately only the letters ???? are now visible. As SUR-D58F17 reminds us, seals bearing the state arms of Russia, a double-headed eagle usually holding an orb and scepter which is straddled or surmounted by the date, were used in an official capacity, mainly by the Customs Service.This find links Exeter rope making industry with flex and hemp grown and imported from Russia in the 18th -19th century. Hemp and flax were widely grown in post medieval Russia and exported to both the US and Britain. Another example is NMS-23782C.Measurements: Diameter: 25.8 mm Thickness: 4.9 mm Weight: 14.98 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper-alloy Roman nummus of Valentinian I (AD 364-375), dating to the period c.AD 367-375 (Reece period 19). SECVRITAS REI PVBLICAE reverse rtype depicting Victory advancing left holding wreath and palm. Mint of Siscia. cf. LRBC no. 1414ff17.9mm in diameter, 1.3mm thick, weight 2.04g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A copper alloy trade token of the post medieval period, dating to c. 1650-1700.The token is circular in plan and flattened in cross section. Very little survives of the original design, although in the centre of the obverse face is a possible shield with a central lis. The reverse may show clasped hands (possibly crowned) although this is highly speculative. There is a single record in Williamson (1967 no. 93) for a token with two crowned hands, from Hemel Hempstead in Hertfordshire, although there is no mention of any shield or lis device.18.1mm diameter, 0.9mm thick, weight 1.95g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver halfpenny of Henry IV (1399-1413), dating to 1412-1413.North (1991: 67) no. 1367, with annulets beside crown. Minted at London.12mm diameter, 0.3mm thick, weight 0.45g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver groat of Henry VIII (1509-1547), dating to 1544-1547.North (1991: 114) no. 1846. Minted at Bristol. No visible initial mark.24.1mm diameter, 0.6mm thickness, weight 1.81g.

properties.title: PLANO CONVEX KNIFE
properties.description: A complete plano convex flint knife of late Neolithic to Early Bronze Age date, c. 2700-1600 BC.Formed from a secondary flake, the object is sub-rectangular in shape, and plano-convex in cross section. It is formed of a dark grey flint, with no patinisation on the surface. The proximal end has been carefully texturised in order to create a consistent squared finish.There is invasive retouch pressure flaking covering almost the entirety of the dorsal face, with the bulb of percussion clearly visible on the ventral face. An additional removal is visible adjacent to the bulb of percussion. It is possible that the object was discarded due to an accidentally over large retouch removal which is plainly visible.Similar examples have been recorded on the PAS database including: WAW-3FD07D, WAW-C0CAE9, WAW-C0CAE9, WMID-F23B97; HESH-BD97A2; SWYOR-B645D2 and SUR-E41676. such knives are found in late Neolithic to early Bronze Age (c.2700 BC to c.1600 BC) contexts, often associated with food vessels and beakers in the early Bronze Age (Butler 2005,172). Plano-convex knives could measure up to 150mm long, but this is not common (ibid).Measurements: 45.62mm long, 16.6mm wide, 4.7mm thick and weight 5.18g

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy pot leg probably from a cooking pot or cauldron, dating to AD 1500-1700.The fragment is D-shaped in cross section, and takes the form of a flared hoof-like foot and ridged fetlock-like band, with the break 4.66 mm above the ridge.The inner surface of the fragment is flat while the outer surface is decorated with three convex ribs, a more prominent one in the middle and a thinner one at each side of the foot.Butler et al (2009: 4) defines this type of pot leg as a type C, which was in use by the late 16th century and commonly found thoruough the 17th century.Measurements:Length: 34.35 mmWidth: 20.70 mmThickness: 10.67 mmWeight: 23.27 g

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A complete post medieval lead alloy cloth alnage seal dating AD 1550-1750.The two discs and the rivet survive. The rivet, which is integral to and projected from one of the discs, was pushed through the central hole in adjacent one, before the two discs were pressed together.Most discs of this period were stamped with an inscription and a design, often a portcullis as Egan (1994: 9) notes that it was "the main design for alnage seals in the late Tudor period... and continued in use into the early seventeenth century", but this particular example appears to have been stamped with neither.Both the discs and the rivet were impressed with the weave of the threads of fabric they sealed.The discs, originally flat, are now bent in proximity of the edge of the discs where the terminal part of the rivet rests.Measurements:Diameter: 21.98 mmThickness: 2.98 mmWeight: 8.71 g

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy pot leg probably from a cooking pot or cauldron, dating AD 1500-1700.The fragment is D-shaped in cross section, and takes the form of a flared hoof-like foot and prominent ridged fetlock-like band, with the break just above this ridge. The fetlock band (26.81 mm) is wider than the flared end of the foot (23.21 mm).The front of the foot is decorated with a prominent central rib which flares towards the end of the foot and two smaller ones that run parallel at each side. The back of the foot fragment is plain and sits flat when set on a flat surface.As DEV-3014BB reminds us, crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg that developed over this period. This is an example of their Type C, which was in use by the late 16th century and remained popular throughout the 17th century.Measurements: Length: 45.98 mmWidth: 26.81 mmThickness: 14.18 mmWeight: 64.28 g

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy double looped trapezoidal buckle of the post medieval period, dating to c. 1550-1700.The object comprises approximately 55% of the frame, and the central bar. The pin and the remainder of the bar are missing. The frame is sub-rectangular in cross section, with a slight bevel to the outer vertical edge. The central bar is cylindrical in cross section and bears a darker mark, possibly of iron corrosion, where the original pin would have been placed. There are two pointed knops on the outer frame at each end of the central bar but the outer vertical edges are plain, albeit with slightly thickened corners.Cuddeford (1996: 26, example L) describes this form of buckle as dating to the 16th and 17th centuries.Measurements: 16.5mm long, 15.3mm wide, 2.5mm thick, weight 1.32g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A fragment of the rim of a post medieval copper alloy cooking vessel dating to c. AD 1500-1700.The original vessel was likely to be a cauldron or a bowl with shallow andd relatively straight sides. The body of the vessel is slightly curved, indicating an open profile.The bevelled rim is on the internal surface and it tapers slightly towards what would have been the top of the vessel. Both the interior and exterior are sooted from organic material that has been burnt onto the surface when the vessel was near an open flame.Similar examples such as SUR-3E97C2, SUR-D4E773 and CORN-52C395 can be found on the database.Measurements:Length: 41.61 mmWidth: 48.70 mmThickness: 4.75 mmWeigth: 37.14 g

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy pot leg, dating to the period c. AD 1500-1700.The leg is broadly D-shaped in cross section, with a flat back and a convex front. A raised fetlock runs horizontally across the outer face. Originally the leg probably flared downwards and terminated in a hoof-like foot like other similar examples on the database, SOM-18541D and DEV-DC54FE.Cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from AD1200 to 1700 for serving and cooking. Legs and feet are the most commonly recorded finds. This is an example of Butler, Payne and Green (2009: 4) Type C. Measurements: Length: 31.96 mmWidth: 25.68 mmThickness: 13.84 mmWeight: 39.70 g

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete post medieval copper-alloy single loop buckle dating to c. AD 1550-1650.Only the frame survives, the pin is missing.The buckle is broadly D-shaped, with a fluted outer vertical frame and a rectangular central bar. There is a drop shaped knop projecting from the centre of this vertical outer partof the frame. The inside of the frame is recessed and appears oval in cross section. The strap bar is narrower and rectangular in cross section. There are two transverse groves on the strap bar, indicating the original position of the pin.Numerous similar buckles have been recorded on the database, including the slightly more elaborate DEV-0869FC and the plainer DEV-27F45F.Measurements:Length: 28.23 mmWidth: 24.73 mmThickness: 4.29 mmWeight: 6.36 g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to AD 330 - 335 (Reece Period 17). GLORIA EXERCITVS reverse type depicting two soldiers with two standards. Second mint of Treveri (Trier).

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: An incomplete cast copper alloy bar of uncertain dating, but possibly Medieval in origin (12th to 15th Centuries AD).The bar is sub rectangular in plan, and lozenge shaped in cross section. It exhibits five double ridges (bands) equally spaced down the length of the bar the outer double ridges of which are slightly larger than the three other pairs. Each single ridge is approximately 3.9mm wide.The base of the bar consists of a pyramid head with convex edges such that it has a slightly rounded end, whereas the top is more irregular ending in a square irregular protrusion that may be broken.It is a mid dark green/brown colour, with an even surface patina, suggestive of a Medieval date.It measures 36.0mm in length, 6.8mm wide and 5.7mm thick. It weighs 4.5 grams.At present, it is uncertain what type of object this bar originated from. It could be part of a handle, or a votive scabbard. It has tentatively been dated to the Medieval period, due to style and patina, but these are not definite methods of dating, so it could be of any date from Roman through to Post Medieval (1 AD to 1800 AD). Similar objects have recorded on the database include WAW-447E50, HAMP-2769E8, HESH-4BA0F7 and IOW-5C549E.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy pot leg, dating to the period c. AD 1500-1700. The leg is broadly triangular in cross section, the inner surface being flat and the outer surface formed of three conjoined convex ribs. The leg terminates downward in a flared, claw footed base, separated from the leg by a raised collar. The object has a grey-orange patina.The leg is 45.7 mm tall, and has a width of 35.2 mm. The foot protrudes 27 mm. The leg weighs 134.3 g.Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1800 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is an example of type B which they suggest was widespread in the Medieval period with some examples continuing into the early 17th century (ibid).

properties.title: WHISTLE
properties.description: A complete post-medieval lead-tin alloy whistle of the modern period, dating to c.AD 1700-1900.It is cylindrical in cross section with some corrosion, mostly complete. The whistle is no longer hollow and has been filled in by corrosive action, with the inclusion of a small stone. The knop shaped terminal has a hole, diameter approximately 2mm. There is a rectangular shaped sound hole to the top of the whistle. The top and side are also decorated with a scallop shell, although largely corroded the detail. The mouth piece is semicircular.This form of whistle was probably used by a bosun or boatswain, in order to deliver clearly audible commands aboard ship. It is similar to KENT-46DA73, although this artefact is incomplete. While such whistles were in use for a significant period, suggests an early modern date in the 19th century.Measurements: length 54mm, width 16mm, thickness 15mm, weight 35.2g.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Medieval copper alloy buckle complete with frame, pin and plate dating to AD xx. The frame is D shaped with a narrowed and offset strap bar and the outer edge expanded in the centre into a rounded point which is also slightly swollen and thicker than the rest of the frame. There are three transverse incised lines across the outer edge creating a pin rest flanked by lines. The frame is oval in cross section. The frame is 38.0mm wide, 20.5mm wide and 4.4mm thick.The pin is formed of a strip of copper alloy sheet wrapped around the strap bar and narrowing from the end of this wrapped section to the slightly rounded point. The pin is 21.5mm , 3.6mm wide and 1.6mm thick.The plate is formed of a piece of copper alloy sheet bent in half over the strap bar. The front is rectangular with cut out inner corners flanking two tabs which go over the strap bar with a pin slot between them. The back is trapezoid and widens slightly from these tabs to the straight outer edge and is slightly shorter than the front plate. The front plate is chipped around the edges and decorated with incised lines forming a single line rectangular outer border around a eight petalled flower. the petals are pointed oval with rounded outer edges coming to points in the centre. The four petals reaching to the corners are larger than those between then going towards the sides of the plate. On each petal there are short lines of wriggle work, running transversely across the petals, three evenly spaced along the longer petals and one in the centre of each shorter petal. In the gaps between the petals and outer border is background shading formed of wriggle work.There are three seperate copper alloy rivets, one through the centre of the plate and flower and one near each outer corner. Two are complete with irregular projecting heads at the front and roved over at the back. One of the corner rivets is missing its head. The plate is 29.4mm wide 24.8mm long, 3.8mm thick excluding the rivets and 6.2mm including them.There is mud between the plates held in by a preservative coating that covers the frame, pin and plate. There entire piece weighs 13.62g and is 41.1mm long.The frame is of Meols type 4 dating to the late 14th century (Egan 2007, 88).

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper cast-alloy mount (AD 1550-1700).The mount is an open work quatrefoil with scallop shell shaped expansions between petals. In the centre is a cross, the ends of the arms of which are joined by projecting V-shaped points with rounded ends. Each scallop shell has raised lines radiating from the base to the outer edge. The mount's back is flat has two projecting attachment spikes placed behind the centre of two opposite clam shells. These spikes are rectangular in cross section and curled towards the centre of the mount.The artefact is 36.6mm, 38.35mm wide, has a thickness of 2.45mm and weighs 8.51 grams.Similar finds include SOM-D2CCB6 and SOM-9F27F2 although these have three attachment spikes and the latter is dated from circa AD 1600-1700. Near identical examples from East Lincolnshire and South Somerset have been illustrated by Read (2001, 27 and 34, fig 19 no 276-277) and dated to the 17th century (ibid).

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: A fragment of a Medieval or Post-medieval lead-alloy (pewter) spoon now comprising the knop and part of the stem. The style most closely approximates a proto-acorn type but it is unusual in its details.The knop and the remaining stem now form an angle of c60 degrees while the final c4mm of the stem is angled at c30 degrees further, bringing it at right angles to the line of the knop, this orientation is due to later damage and cracking. The remaining stem is c20mm in length and hexagonal in cross-section, the sides of the hexagon at the front and rear being longer to create an approximate oval.The knop is c14mm in length and consists of a section representing the elongated top of the acorn (which appears to be a continuation of the stem with a rounded end) together with a wider section representing the acorn cup, which appears to have been welded on as a separate piece. The top section is c6.5mm long and tapers slightly in width from 4.9mm to 4.5mm; it is a pointed oval in cross-section and c3.3mm thick along its length until the rounded end, which does not have a terminating pip. The cup section is c7.5mm high, 10.2mm wide and 7.3mm thick with seams at the width extremities. The front of the cup (i.e. on the inside of the curve of the spoon) has decoration in the form of raised intersecting lines with a pip or pellet within each section; each section is sub-square rather than diamond-shaped. The back of the cup has traces of the same pattern but has mostly been worn smooth. The stem immediately below the knop has a single raised line collar with a second line slightly further down only visible on the less worn side.Overall the object measures 31.3mm in length, 10.2mm in width and 7.3mm in thickness; it weighs 6.15g.Broadly similar designs are shown in Homer (1975:25) where he notes that knops that are classed as acorn or proto-acorn vary widely in style and time-span, from the 13th century to the 17th, the longest time span of any spoon knop. The closest match terms of shape (though not identical in decoration) is Homer's type 'g', which he describes as having a fig-shaped bowl and dates to the 15th to 16th century (ibid). These dates are therefore proposed for this example.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A uniface, post-medieval lead-alloy token, Powell type 12. The decorated side has a cross extending to the edges of the token with chevron consisting of three radiating lines in three of the quarters. The fourth quarter has initials, .IR. likely referring to a person with the initials J.R. The reverse is smooth and was probably plain.The token has a diameter of 24 mm, a thickness of 2mm and weighs 7.19 grams.Lead tokens had a wide variety of potential uses such as use as tallies, gaming pieces, tickets, weights, etc. and are believed to have been locally produced; they are therefore difficult to date precisely but were popular between c AD 1500-1700. The decoration on this token appears to fit in Powell type 12, quartered geometrically. See Powell Classification for Lead Tokens online at http://www.mernick.org.uk/leadtokens/Classification_System.pdf

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy strap fitting, probably from a sword belt, dating to the 17th century.The hanger's main body is an ovoid plate with a flat reverse and slighlty convex front surface. At the top of this plate there is a trefoil knop. On the opposite end to this is a collared hook, which curves backwards to a rounded point. The plate has a hole in the centre of the upper part and the remains of a rivet project from the reverse in the centre of the hanger just above the hook. A futher rivot project from the reverse of the trefoil knop.The front of the plate is decorated with an engraved vine and foliate pattern but the back is plain.The piece has a green patina. The mount measures 65.05mm in length, 28.68mm in width, 3.75mm in thickness and weighs 19.56g.Read (2008:222) no. 800 shows a similar example which he dates to the 17th century. LVPL-3F4348 on the database is also very similar.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: Post-Medieval copper alloy hooked strap fitting, probably dating to c. AD 1500-1700. The strap fitting consists of a sub-rectangular plate narrowing towards one end where there is a backward-turning hook projecting from the bottom. The top of the plate has an indent in the centre and rounded corners, creating the effect of two lobes. It tapers in width from top to bottom, before expanding again into rouned lobes to each side joined by a transverse incised line. The hook projects below the lobes and is D-shaped in cross section with a flat back. The hook curves back 90 degrees before terminating in an old break.The plate is very shallowly convex at the front and concave at the rear. The hook is convex at the front and flat at the rear. There are two rivet holes with traces of the rivets still in place, arranged on the longitudinal axis, one near the top and the other just above the incised line.The fitting has a brown and green patina. It is 37.2mm long (23.4mm without the hook), 12.1mm wide and 7.4mm thick, 3.2mm excluding the hook. It weighs 23.12gMargeson (1993: 39, nos. 257-258) publishes a pair of extremely similar strap fittings both found in contexts dating to c. 1600-1650, and suggests that they were mounted to sword belts although their small size makes a use on spur straps possible.Similar examples can be seen on this database, for example SOM-20FDE5 and SOM-1373DD.

properties.title: RIVET
properties.description: Late Medieval or post-medieval copper alloy pot mend, consisting of a staple rivet, probably dating to c. AD 1475-1600. The mend is of a lozenge shaped sheet of copper alloy folded in on itself, to create a sub-rectangular plate with the two pointed ends then bent out again on themselves to project to the sides. It is curved in profile.Dimensions: length 38.8mm; width 15.0mm; thickness 3.0mm, of sheet 0.9mm; weight 4.70g.Egan (2005: 101, nos. 460-463) notes that such pot repairs were in use from early in the Medieval period, but were at their most prevalent in the late 15th and 16th centuries. Examples published by Margeson (1991: 92, nos. 574-576) were found in contexts dating to the 16th and early 17th centuries.

properties.title: STIRRUP
properties.description: A complete Early Medieval copper alloy stirrup-strap mount of Williams Class A, type 8, probably dating to c. AD 1000-1100. The stirrup-strap mount consists of a sub-triangular plate from the base of which projects backwards a rectangular angled flange, at c. 90 degrees to the plane. There is a central circular hole through the plate about one third of the way form the apex and two others near the base, above the flange. The plate is moulded with a large head at the apex facing upwards with stepped in snout and nose and small heads as at the base corners, flanking the flange. Between the heads running parallel to and creating the multiple curves of the outer edges, are a series of looped, curved and lobed lines with a large triangular lobe near the base. These are interpreted by Williams (1997) as the body, legs and wings of the creatures at the corners, although in a perhaps deliberately ambiguous effect on this example they could also be interpreted as open jawed beasts facing towards the apex with forelegs raised to the upper hole. There is a small, plain, triangular area adjacent to the base between the large lobes. On this example this has no trace of inlay although there are patinated scratches, some deep and parallel.Dimensions: length 46.4mm; width 28.9mm; thickness 7.2mm, 4.6mm excluding the flange; weight 22.11g.This is an example of a Williams Class A, type 8 stirrup-strap mount (1997: 47-50), typically dated to the 11th century. This is a large group with no obvious distribution pattern, although like most stirrup-strap mounts they are rare in Devon (ibid: 19).

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A worn copper alloy coin weight of the post medieval period which is sub-square in plan and has designs on both faces. Both faces show an arrangement of five annulets, positioned with one in each corner and one in the centre. At the top in the centre is a larger impression, which may possibly be a lis, although this is unclear. The obverse face also has the numbers "51" positioned on the left hand side, between the upper and lower annulets. The weight of just under 7g is suggestive that it may have been used for the production of half (spur) ryals, which Withers and Withers (2011:79) describe as dating to 1604-1619. The lis is described (ibid: 78) as being associated with the coin weights of James I, which is consistent with this date. The 51 may be a form of maker's mark.Measurements: weight 6.87g, 16mm length, 17mm width, 4mm thickness.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A fragment of cast copper alloy vessel leg, dating to 1550-1700 probably from a cooking pot or cauldron.The object is D-shaped in cross section, and takes the form of a flared hoof-like foot and ridged fetlock-like band, before narrowing to a straighter leg. The foot is marked by three raised ribs, all of equal width. Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg that developed over this period. This is an example of their Type C, which was in use by the late 16th century and remained popular throughout the 17th century.28mm length, 26mm width, 14mm thickness. Weight 38.26g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy "rose" farthing of Charles I (1625-1649) dating from 1636-1644.An example of (North 1991:165) Type 1 no. 2287No visible initial mark, but probably a crescent.Diameter 12.37mmThickness 1.03mmWeight 0.63g

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A cast copper alloy buckle from the post-medieval period (c.1500-1650).The rectangular frame survives, but the central bar and pin are missing. In cross section, the frame is D-shaped with a flat bottom. The frame is decorated by a series of vertical grooves, which extend all the way along the horizontal parts of the frame, ending with one further groove on each of the two vertical parts. The points at which the central bar would have been placed are markedly thickened, forming two square decorations.Whitehead (1996:75) describes similar examples from the post-medieval period, and see DEV-6F8EF4 and SOM-7A489D for two similar shaped examples.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy "rose" farthing of Charles I (1625-1649) dating from 1636-1644. An example of North (1991:165) Type 1 no. 2287 A fragment, probably of baser metal, is missing at the eleven o'clock position. No visible initial mark, but probably a crescent.Diameter 12.10mmThickness 1.0mmWeight 0.54g

properties.title: TOBACCO HOLDER
properties.description: A complete lead/tin alloy tobacco holder, dating from the post medieval period (c. 1650-1750).The object is formed in the shape of a flower, with a central circular raised boss surrounded by 8 rounded petals. Between each petal is a deep groove. One petal is folded over backwards on itself, damage that is probably post depositional. It was originally domed, but is now somewhat flattened on the reverse.Bailey (2000) illustrates a similar tobacco box handle on page 62, in figs.1-2, which he dates to the middle of the 17th century and states that the lead boxes were used to keep tobacco moist. It is likely that this form of tobacco jar is popular into the late 18th century. CORN-345A0A is a similar example.

properties.title: MEDALLION
properties.description: A milled copper alloy memorial medallion dating to the modern period, celebrating a visit to the Great Exhibition of 1851.The obverse shows a bust of Queen Victoria, while the reverse shows the Crystal Palace of the Great Exhibition, with the legend "GREAT EXHIBITION BUILDING". There is a further inscription beneath the image but this is badly worn.Measurements: 21.44mm in diameter, 1.65mm thick, weight 3.82g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver shilling of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) dating to 1560-61.Minted at London. Martlet initial mark. North (1991: 133) no. 1985.Diameter: 29.36, Thickness 1.12 Weight 5.64g

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A copper alloy jetton from the post medieval period (c. AD 1586-1635).An example of a Nuremberg token, probably minted by Hans Krauwinkel II in Nuremberg, Germany, with the obverse showing the Imperial orb contained within a tressure of three arches and three points and the reverse showing three crowns and three lis surrounding a broken rose.YORYM-867252 is a very similar example. See Mitchiner (1988) Jetons, Medalets and Tokens, vol. I, p. 445, nos. 1574 - 1578.19.6mm diameter, 0.53mm thick, 0.71g weight.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A cast lead alloy cloth or alnage seal dating from the post-medieval period, probably the reign of Queen Anne (1702-1714), dating to 1707-14.The obverse shows the post 1707 arms of Great Britain, surmounted by a lion passant above the crown and with the arms supported by the lion and the unicorn with rose and thistle beneath them. The arms are encircled with the garder motto: HONI SOIT QUI MAL Y PENSE.The reverse shows a crowned Tudor rose with a cross pattee mark above.KENT-075FE8 is a very similar example.Measurements: 36.9mm diameter, 4.7mm thickness and weight 27.2g.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: An incomplete lead cloth seal dating to the post-medieval period, c. 1600-1750.Only the open annular half of the cloth seal survives. It is circular in shape, forming a ring with a central void that measures 8.6mm in diameter.On the outer surface are a series of moulded decorations. These take the forms of two trefoils either side of what appears to be an elongated axe. They are placed at even intervals around the seal, at the 2 o'clock, 4 o'clock and 6 o'clock positions.It is 18.4mm in diameter, 1.4mm thick and weighs 2.21g.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A complete lead cloth seal dating to the post-medieval period, c. 1600-1750.Discoidal in shape and formed of two circular discs, joined together by a folded rectangular connecting sheet at the lowest point of their circumference. Two smaller circular discs clamp the upper parts together, although the outermost of these has been damaged and coroded and is now drop shaped. These two clamping discs are to be found on the reverse, while an annular attachment loop has been folded over so it is now flush with the obverse.The obverse shows an eagle or other bird of prey with wings outstretched.The eagle's left talons grip a branch, while the right leg is raised. Above the eagle's head is the inscription "Wm" followed by two pellets. The reverse bears the number 23.This example is very similar to DEV-70FC98, found nearby. The two may form part of a set and almost certainly were issued together. The record for the latter states that:"Although not identical, the design on the seal can be compared to BH-128517. Egan (1994: 49) suggests that seals depicting eagles with wings adorsed rather than outstreched may be linked to the Norwich weaver's guild."It is 26.8mm in diameter and 3.6mm thick. It weighs 22.02g.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy mount dating to the post-medieval period, c. 1600-1750.The object is formed in a floral design, composed of a central flower on a stem with two elongated leaves flanking it. It is flat in cross section.The reverse is undecorated, and a regular integral rivet is placed at the point where the flower and stem meet.The flower is formed of 12 shallow lobes around a central circle, and could be a representation of a rose. The stem and leaves join together at a waist before tapering to form a flared triangular knop. The leaves are pointed ovals in shape, but are particularly elongated. They do not resemble rose leaves, but are closer to a tulip leaf in shape. The spaces between the leaves are openwork, but other possible spaces have become filled by debris and decay post-deposition.There are similar examples on the database, including DENO-010D4C and KENT-7896F6. The latter record describes the design as characteristically 17th or 18th century.It is 21.9mm in length and 17.2mm wide. It is 2.1mm thick, and the rivet is 7.3mm in length. It weighs 2.70g.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete cast copper alloy buckle dating to the post medieval period, c.1500-1600.The frame is all that survives of this buckle, the pin is missing.A double oval framed buckle, composed of two D-shaped loops with a central bar. The frame itself is convex in cross section, with a flat reverse.It is similar in shape and form to Egan and Pritchards' number 332 (Egan and Pritchard 1991: 82). It is similar to NARC-432CF8 and NLM-949D57, and like them probably dates from between 1500 and 1650.It is 23.2 mm in length and 16.1 mm wide. It is 2.5 mm thick and weighs 2.65g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy trade token, dating to c.1650-1750.Both faces are worn and damaged. The obverse face shows a floral central design with a legend that includes the name "GEORGE." The reverse face is obscured by patinisation, and the legible part of the surviving inscription reads "...TUR...".Dickinson (1986:48) lists a George Hingston from Holsworthy in his records of tokens, which he suggests was made in 1669. This is the only George he lists from Devon. Alternatively, Williamson (1889) lists a number of references to George and the Dragon pub tokens from within Devon, although the absence of a St George and Dragon design and presence of the floral design makes this less likely.It is 27.2mm in diameter, 1.6mm thick and weight to be taken at a later date due to broken scales.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A medieval to post medieval copper alloy domed thimble dating to c. AD 1450-1600 (Read, 2018, 26).The thimble is slightly bent out of shape, with the lower (foot) perimeter particularly affected.It is decorated with drilled circular pits arranged in a leftward spiral, with the spiral ending just before the crown. This area is damaged, but preserves the remnants of a possible maker's mark, perhaps a reversed RR or two eagle's heads. The lowest band of pits around the foot of the thimble are particularly deep, noticeably deeper than those close to the crown . There is no further decoration.It is 29.8mm in diameter and 30.3mm in length. Its walls are 12.45mm thick and the thimble weighs 7.89g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A complete late medieval to early post medieval lead token dating from 1450-1600.The obverse face is decorated with a pattern of a central cross with chevrons following the lines of each individual quarter. The chevrons in each quarter are bisected by a further vertical line, giving the appearance of a web design. The design is consistent with Powell Type 14.It is 32.2mm in diameter and 12.2mm thick. It weighs 5.13g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A complete late medieval to early post medieval lead token dating from 1450-1600.A raised floral design on the obverse face is composed of five angular petals around a central raised circle. At the centre of the token is a raised pellet marking the heart of the flower. There is a markedly raised rim. The reverse face is flat with the remnants of a slightly raised rim. In its centre are two annulets The floral design is consistent with Powell Type 1.Some damage has occurred to the obverse face, resulting in a depression in the middle of one of the petals.It is 33.9mm in diameter and 13.2mm thick. It weighs 8.96g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward II (1307-1327), Class 10cf, issued 1300-1310 but attributed to Edward II.Cross pattee initial mark. Minted at Canterbury.It is 17.7mm in diameter and weighs 1.22g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver groat of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), First Coinage, dating to 1560-1.An example of North (2006:133) number 1986.Cross crosslet initial mark, Tower Mint.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy buckle of post medieval date (c. 1550-1600).Half of an elaborate square shaped double loop buckle, composed of a thin central bar with trefoil knops at each terminal. These are flanked by a further linear knop on each side of the frame, 1.8mm distant from the terminal knops. Although the object shows signs of corrosion and damage, there is a suggestion of an incised additional loop designed to make the trefoil terminal knops appear as quatrefoil floral decorations. This is supported by the presence of a further knop in the centre of the outer frame in the form of a flower with 8 petals, with 3 petals extending out from the frame on both the exterior and interior sides. There is also a suggestion of a circle marking the centre of the flower. Adjacent to this elaborate knop are two series of dots, following the outer line of the frame. The pin is missing, as is the other half of the frame.From knop to knop, the width at the bar is 30.1mm. It is 24.3mm wide at the end of the frame. The frame itself is 9.56mm wide at the point of the large floral knop with 8 petals, its widest point, and 3.9mm wide at its narrowest point, between the trefoil knops and the linear knops, near to the bar. It is 24.2mm long and 1.9mm thick, weighing 4.23g.Elaborate double looped buckles with floral decoration on the database include DEV-7EA590 and GLO-E8B8D1. Parallels for this type of buckle can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p66.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A complete copper alloy buckle of medieval date (c. 1350-1400).A double oval framed buckle, composed of two D-shaped loops with a central bar. The frame itself is convex in cross section, with a flat reverse. The frame is angled, and it is very similar to Egan and Pritchard (1991: 82) number 333. There is a small raised linear decoration marking the points where the central bar meets the frame at both top and bottom edges. The bar is much more sharply angled and is triangular in cross section.The pin survives on the central bar, and is trapezoid in cross section, with a flat top and bottom and angled sides, tapering to a point at its terminal.It is 23.3mm wide at the point where the bar meets the frame, and the widest point of the loops measures 25.1mm. It is 36.3mm in length, while the pin is 21.4mm in length from the bar to its terminal. The frame is 2.5mm thick, the bar is 2.4mm thick and the pin is 1.5mm thick. It weighs 6.47g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward III, Third (Florin) coinage, dating to 1344-51 AD.North (2006:47) Type 1119.Slightly damaged around the perimeter. Minted at London.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy post medieval double loop buckle dating to c. 1550-1650. Two rectangular loops with a central bar, all of which are very narrow and fine in appearance and are ornately decorated with rounded knops at each corner and a trefoil knops at the centre of each bar. Those on the horizontal sides of the frame are more rounded in appearance, with two more angular lobes extending from a rounded central lobe. Those on the vertical sides are more angular in appearance, with all three lobes triangular in shape and reminiscent of a flower and central stamen. The pin and its loop are missing. The frame is flattened in cross section.A similar example is DEV-7EA590. Similar to Marshall type 3A which he dates to 1550-1650.It is 51.4mm long and 29.9mm wide.The frame is 2.66mm thick. It weighs 8.11g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A largely complete late medieval to early post medieval lead alloy unifaced token, dating to approximately 1450-1600 AD. The design is composed of a central raised circle, from which extend 8 linear spokes. Between these there is a suggestion of a web of four concentric circles. The spoked design is consistent with Powell Type 3.The surface is much affected by an orange patina and has been badly worn, so the original design is not entirely clear.It is 23.3mm in diameter, 2.7mm thick and weighs 7.98g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A group of three largely complete late medieval to early post medieval lead alloy unifaced tokens, dating to approximately 1450-1600 AD. Two share the same design of a stylised raised cross, with the resulting quarters divided further by two points of a triangle, following the line of the cross. The third is a gridded cross composed of four raised lines crossing over one another. All 3 are examples of Powell Type 14. All three show signs of damage and having portions missing, the largest and most severely affected being missing just under 1/3 of its surface.The largest is 17.7mm in diameter and 1.9mm thick. It weighs 3.4g.The second is 16.6mm in diameter and 2.5mm thick. It weighs 4.45g.The smallest is 15.4mm in diameter and 2.6mm thick. It weighs 3.3g.The total weight of all 3 is 11.11g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A largely complete late medieval to early post medieval lead alloy unifaced token, dating to approximately 1450-1600 AD. A raised design on the obverse face is composed of 14 spokes emanating from a central raised boss, suggestive of a cartwheel. The reverse face is concave and appears undecorated. The spoked design is consistent with Powell Type 3.Some damage has occurred to the outer edge, but it appears that the spoked design was contained within a raised rim.It is 17.3mm in diameter, 1.7mm thick and weighs 3.06g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A largely complete late medieval to early post medieval lead alloy unifaced token, dating to approximately 1450-1600 AD. A raised floral design on the obverse face is composed of six angular petals around a central raised circle. At the centre of the token is a raised pellet marking the heart of the flower. The reverse face is flat with the remnants of a slightly raised rim. The floral design is consistent with Powell Type 1.Some damage has occurred to the outer edge, resulting in the loss of approximately 10% of the surface area. It is 26.3mm in diameter, 3mm thick and weighs 8.3g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver groat of Henry VIII (1509-1547), dating to 1538-41.North (2006: 111) Type 1797. Minted at London, Lis initial mark.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), dating to 1574.North (2006: 134) Type 1997. Minted at London, Eglantine initial mark.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward III (1327-1335) dating to 1344-1351.Third (Florin) coinage. North (2006: 46) Standard Type G no. 1123. Minted at Durham, no. 4 or possibly 5.The coin is damaged around the upper perimeter of the obverse face, with approximately 10% of the total surface area missing. The surviving coin is worn with the king's face rather obscured.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver half groat of Charles I (1625-1649), dating to 1628-29 or 1638-39.Group A, anchor initial mark. London mint. North (2006: 161) no. 2249.The coin is bent at almost 90 degrees 4.1mm from the right hand edge of the obverse face.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy trade token, (1600-1750), much eroded and affected by a green patina that obscures the original design.There is a suggestion of an anchor within a curved shape, itself within inner circle on the obverse face, and in the legend the letter "E" is visible at the 2 o'clock position, with the letters "RATE" visible from the 10-12 o'clock positions. On the reverse face there is a possible second anchor or plume in the centre, within an annulet circle, and with annulet stops between the largely illegible legend. It is possible to make out "9.7" but the remainder of the legend cannot be read.There are numerous examples in Williamson (1967) of trade tokens which feature an anchor, and there is a possible parallel with the tokens of Benjamin Massey, mercer of Colyton, which feature an anchor within a heart (Williamson's number 56) although this is highly speculative due to the condition of the token.It weighs 1.16g, is 18.3mm in diameter and 0.83mm in thickness.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver shilling of William III (1694-1702), minted at London and dated 1700 on the coin.Obverse: GVLIELMVS III DEI GRA; Laureate and draped bust facing right.Reverse: 00 MAG BR FRA ET HIB REX 16; Four shields within which are a harp, one lion rampant, three lions passant and three fleurs-de-lis, all around a central circle with the lion of Nassau within, creating a cruciform shape.It is 24.9mm in diameter, 1.3mm thick and weighs 5.68g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Post medieval silver penny of Charles I (1625-1649).The coin is much damaged and eroded, so that the obverse face is almost entirely illegible. There is a faint suggestion of a surviving bust, facing left, but only the crown and possibly the profile is visible. The coin is folded in upon the reverse face, but this has to some extent protected the legend, which can just be read on the portion of the perimeter above the fold. The legible part of the inscription reads "THRON[UM]." An inner circle and part of an uncrowned rose can be made out in the centre of this face. Probably a Group C (2265) example (North 2006:162).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy dupondius or as of unknown emperor dating to AD 1- 250. Unclear reverse type. Unclear mint.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: The token celebrates the centenary of the "Glorious Revolution" of November 4th 1688, when James II was replaced by William and Mary as joint monarchs. Scalloped edge flan. Obverse; GULIELMUS III DEI GRATIA, right facing bust, //1688. Reverse; REVOLUTION JUBILEE/ (within wreath) NOVR/4TH/ 1788.The best similar example on the database is NMS- F65FF4.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman dupondius or as of unknown ruler. Unknown mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver penny of Edward I (1272-1307).Long cross reverse with three pellets in each quadrant. Mint of London. Obverse has the bust of the king facing. The crown has side fleurs and the king's hair is short. The coin has been damaged, with a particularly large dent at the 7 o'clock position.Class 3g 2-3 or 4a 1-2, dating to 1280-3.It is 18.1mm in diameter and weighs 1.26g.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: A fragment of a copper alloy rowel from a spur of medieval to post medieval date, c. 1300-1700.This fragment preserves three elongated triangular points from the original multi-pointed star. These are arranged around a central circular hole for the now missing axis bar. This form of spur rowel is problematic to date due to its long period of usage. For further examples of similar star rowels, cf. Read 2001, Fig 42, nos. 505-51.The individual spikes are 23.9mm in length, and are 5.5mm wide at  the base and 1.75mm wide at the tip. The diameter of the central circular hole is 7.8mm. The fragment as a whole is 42.5mm across and weighs 5.66g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy dupondius or as of uncertain Emperor, dating to AD 43-250. Unclear reverse type depicting standing figure. Unclear mint.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete asymmetrical double looped copper alloy buckle from the early post-medieval period (1500-1650). Both loops are triangular in cross section with a flat back and ridge around the front. One loop is trapezoidal in shape, where the outer bar is longer than the inner, central bar. The other loop is D-shaped, and has a pointed knop in the centre of the outer edge. The knop is composed of 3 sections- the lowest is relatively narrow and rounded, the middle level is cylindrical and provides much of the length of the knop (this layer is 3.39mm in length) and the third a pointed terminal. The central bar is affected by a mass of iron corrosion, which may still contain the original iron pin, although in a much deformed state. Both terminals of the central bar are marked by a rectangular knop, although one of these has been broken off.The trapezoidal loop is 16.5mm wide and 2.87mm thick and the D-shaped loop is 16.3mm wide and 2.75mm thick. The buckle is 30.91mm long, with the knop 8.94mm long. It weighs 3.1g.A similar example, albeit with a more elaborate outer knop, is  BERK-96B5FE on this database.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy post medieval double loop buckle, incomplete and missing its pin. Two rectangular loops with a central bar, all of which are very narrow and fine in appearance and are ornately decorated with pointed trefoil knops at each corner and two double lobed knops at the centre of each bar. The upper and left of these knops are quite damaged and their form is difficult to ascertain, however it is very similar to the surviving examples and it seems likely they were the same shape. There is a slight suggestion of raised cast decoration on the bars themselves, but this is very faint and is affected both by wear and the yellowish green patina which is developing on the object's upper surface. A similar, albeit slightly thicker example, is CORN-17B50C.Similar to Marshall type 3A which he dates to 1550-1650.It is 30.26mm wide, and 22.62mm in length. The outer bars are 3.15mm wide and 1.76mm thick, while the inner bar is 1.94mm wide and 1.92mm thick. It weighs 3.46g.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy post medieval double loop buckle. The two loops come together to create a double oval frame, bisected by the central bar. The bar and to some extent the underside of the upper loops is marked by iron decay, suggesting the presence of an iron pin which is now missing. Of the two loops, one has been damaged, slightly flattened and bent inwards, giving the impression of a narrower void and thicker loop. The frame is flat in profile. It is similar in shape and form to Egan and Pritchards' number 332 (Egan and Pritchard 1991: 82). It is similar to NARC-432CF8 and NLM-949D57, and like them probably dates from between 1500 and 1650.It is 16.8mm wide at the point where the two loops join the bar, 19.93mm wide across the width of the flattened loop and 19.28mm wide across the undamaged loop. It is 23.8mm in length. The flattened loop is 2.32mm in thickness and the undamaged loop is 1.93mm. It weighs 2.8g.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A largely complete late medieval lead alloy unifaced token. A raised floral design on the obverse face is composed of six angular petals around a central raised circle. The edges are worn and damaged, with a possible circular decoration below the flower at the 6 o'clock position. The token has also been slightly bent, so that it is slightly concave when viewed in profile. The reverse face is flat with the remnants of a slightly raised rim. The floral design is consistent with Powell Type 1.The token is 19.95mm in diameter and 1.8mm in thickness. It weighs 4.5g.Lead tokens had a wide variety of potential uses such as tallies, gaming pieces, tickets, weights, etc. and are believed to have been locally produced; they are therefore difficult to date precisely. Those carrying initials are generally deemed to be post-Medieval in date (1500-1850), those which seem to mimic Medieval penny designs are deemed to be Medieval, the remainder which carry stylised designs remain difficult to date but the majority are probably post-Medieval in date c. 1500-1850.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post medieval copper alloy button with surviving integrally cast and latterly drilled loop. The button is discoidal in shape, with a convex face and concave underside. The face is decorated with an incised pattern of lozenges, arranged in a grid with a further stamped floral decoration in each alternating row. The floral decoration is composed of six petals arranged around a central circular stamp. The lozenges in the central and clearest row measure 5.5mm in width and 5.6mm in length and are fairly uniform. There is an outer border of closely spaced annulets, each measuring approximately 0.6mm in diameter.The button itself is 26.2mm in diameter and 2.15mm thick. The loop is 4.42mm in height and 6.1mm wide. The button weighs 7.29gThis example is very similar to Read (2005: 45) Type 157, also from East Devon.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Incomplete medieval silver penny of Henry III (1216-1272), dating to 1251-72. Voided long cross Class 5a, minted by Davi at London. North (1980:182).This example has not been clipped, but has nonetheless been damaged, with the portion from the 12 o'clock to around the 4 o'clock position missing. The face of the king is preserved, but much of the inscription is missing as a result.It is 17.66mm in diameter and 0.82mm thick. It weighs 1.19g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval silver groat of Edward III (1327-1377), dating to 1352-1353. Fourth coinage, pre-Treaty period, Series D. Minted in London. North (2006:48) number 1152.When the coin was hammered, the stamp has landed slightly awry, with the result that on the lower right quadrant a patch of blank silver exists, while the full inscription is missing and only the lower half of the letters can be read in the upper left quadrant. The amount of slippage seems to be about 2.35mm as this is the width of the blank band.It is 25.65mm in diameter and 0.94mm thick. It weighs 4.53g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver groat of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), dating to 1560-61. First issue (1558-1561), initial mark of a cross crosslet. North number 1986 (2006: 133). It is 22.75mm in diameter and 0.57mm thick. It weighs 1.89g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post-medieval silver half groat of Charles I (AD 1625-49) dating to 1634-1640. Group D, North 2257 (2006:162).The obverse face is extremely damaged and appears almost blank. It has also been bent into a slight S-shape in profile. Rounder oval shield with new garniture. Uncertain mint. It is 12.9mm in diameter and 0.44mm thick. It weighs 0.78g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver penny of Charles I (AD 1625-49). North (2006:163) Type 2270 with initial mark unclear. The obverse face is extremely damaged, particularly around the bust, while the inscription remains clear and in good condition. Oval garnished shield on reverse. Uncertain mint. It is 12.9mm in diameter and 0.47mm thick. It weighs 0.47g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval silver penny of Charles I (1625-1649). The coin is damaged with approximately 25% of the outer perimeter either missing or folded over onto the obverse face.This is an example of a Group A penny (North 2006: 162) without bust, with uncrowned roses on both the obverse and reverse faces. The inscription is visible where the perimeter has not been damaged, and the initial mark is of two pellets.The penny is 12.25 mm in diameter where undamaged. It is 0.58mm thick. It weighs 0.44g.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Two early post-medieval (1550-1700) German salt-glazed stoneware body sherds of a Cologne or Frechen ware 'Bartmann' or 'Bellarmine' bottle or jug.
