The fabric is buff coloured and has been hard fired. It does not show the black spotting that would suggest it was produced in London as opposed to Germany.  The exterior surface has with a mottled brown salt glaze.The larger fragment comes from the part of the body displaying an applied, moulded medallion, with the larger fragment preserving approximately one quarter of the medallion, depicting two ears of wheat with surrounding stalks. The medallion border is marked in a moulded pattern of vertical lines, while its outer perimeter is traced in the stoneware glaze creating a double border effect. A large wear mark or glazing error is present directly beneath the medallion on this sherd. The smaller sherd is from the point at which the hande would have connected to the vessel, preserving a stippled glazed deoration surrounding the broken surface where the handle would once have been attached. The larger sherd measures 67.6 mm in length, 49.6mm at maximum width and is 9.7mm thick,weighing 27.6g. The smaller measures 40.8mm in length, 30.6mm at maximum width and is 12mm thick at the handle join, and 6.4mm at its thinnest point. It weighs 15.2g.There are 5 other examples on the database from Devon, including DEV-BC45D8, which shows a very similar wheat ear decorative medallion.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy dupondius or as of uncertain Emperor, dating to AD 43-250. Unclear reverse type depicting standing figure. Unclear mint.

properties.title: KNIFE
properties.description: A domed, gilded, cast copper alloy object, possibly a dagger or knife pommel of probable medieval or early post-medieval date, about AD1300 - 1700.  The piece is circular in outline and highly domed with angled sides and rounded top. The sides have extensive remains of gilding. The concave back is entirely filled with iron corrosion apart from a small rectangular slot that runs through the corrosion and appears to hold remains of a  grained iron substance, either wrought iron or organic material filled with iron corrosion. The copper alloy dome is 19.1mm in diameter, 11.0mm tall and 2.0mm to 2.6 thick at the base. The slot through the iron corrosion is 3.6mm by 2.1mm and 3.0mm deep. The entire piece weighs 6.60g.Due to the incomplete nature it is hard to parallel this object exactly. While large gilded domed copper alloy heads on rivets are known from early-medieval buckle plates the size and iron corrosion makes this identification less likely. The slot containing the iron appears similar to those seen on ends for whittle tang knives and swords, such as SWYOR-E6C685, a knife form ubiquitous until the 14th century and still produced after that date. However other uses such as a stud cannot be fully ruled out.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy coin from India, probably the denomination called a paisa, probably dating to AD 1790-1830. A close parallel seems to be SWYOR-B55B81, "a Paisa of Gwalior State, Gwalior Fort mint, struck in the name of the Mughal Emperor Muhammad Akbar II, during the reign of Maharaja Daulat Rao Scindia (1796-1825)".It is common to find Indian coins in Britain, probably because they were brought here by people serving in the colonial Empire in India.

properties.title: PENANNULAR RING
properties.description: A gold-plated copper alloy penannular 'lock ring' of Late Bronze Age date. The ring consists of a central core in copper alloy covered by sheets of gold: one on the front and the back of the ring and one on the inner side. This inner sheet is now detached from the core and irregularly folded, whilst the edges of the first sheet on one side are lifted. The gold sheet is decorated on both surface with seven concentric incised lines following the shape of the ring.The ring is C-shaped in plan with a gap of 2.7 mm. It is and triangular in cross-section, with a flat inner side, flat surfaces and a prominent external rim. It is worn with several blackened spots along the sheets of gold.The ring measures 24.9 mm in diameter and weighs 5.01 g.Gold or gold-on-base-metal rings and penannular rings are characteristic finds of the Middle to Late Bronze Age (1300-800 BC) and they could have been used as hair-rings or earrings and are often found in pairs. They are usually decorated with repousse' decoration or with fine concentric incised lines imitating fine wire works. More rarely, lock-rings are made from plates obtained from individual gold wires soldered together.A close parallel is BERK-4A433E (2016 T106) dating to 1150-800 BC. Another similar parallel but without copper alloy core is no. W.20 in British Museum Collection, dating to BC 1150-750.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A highly abraded Post-medieval ceramic rim sherd, of a local Coarse sandy ware, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1850. A micaeous, sandy oxidised fabric containing frequent coarse quartz and iron stone inclusions, as well as ferrous clay pellets and larger stones. Weight: 20.99g. Sherds of similar fabric were recovered from excavations in Exeter (Allan 1984: 149), probably from a shallow bowl or pan similar to Allan's (1984: 153) form 8.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy double looped buckle, probably dating to c. AD 1350-1650. The frame comprises of two symmetrical oval loops, separated by a central bar. The bar is sub-rectangular in cross section and both loops are sub-oval. Traces of iron corrosion, probably from a lost iron pin, are present on the bar. The frame appears undecorated.Dimensions: length 23.4mm; width 16.3mm; thickness 2.7mm; weight 2.67g.The lack of any decoration makes it difficult to suggest anything more than a very general date range, a number of double looped buckles are published by Whitehead (2003), which he dates to AD 1350-1650.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy button, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1700. The button is circular in plan with a convex front and concave back. The front of the button is decorated with an incised floral design, consisting of a flower of 5 eliptical petals, around a central boss and overlaying a series of concentric bands. A central integral rectangular shank projects from the reverse, with a circular drilled perforation. Traces of an iron link remain within the shank.Dimensions: diameter 26.7mm; thickness 10.2mm; weight 8.30g.Read (2005: 39-45) illustrates a large number of extremely similar buttons, all with convex fronts, concave back and integral drilled shanks. They have a range of incised and punched decoration, mostly floral or geometric; although none are identical. Read (ibid:36) suggests they were fashionable in the mid to late 17th century and may have been used in pairs as cloak fasteners as well as buttons.

properties.title: STIRRUP
properties.description: A late Early Medieval to early Medieval copper alloy stirrup terminal, probably dating to c. AD 1000-1100. The object is now highly abraded, but is sub-rectangular in plan and sub-triangular in cross section, tapering into a sub-circular sectioned debased urnes-style crested animal head which curls around to meet the main body of the terminal and form a circular aperture. The interior (sub-triangular) face of the terminal is concave, and retains a significant amount of iron corrosion, although the outer edges (and possible face) have been lost.Dimensions: height 22.4mm; width 21.5mm; thickness 12.1mm; weight 11.98g.The object can be compared to more complete examples on this database (e.g. SF-D8BEE1) and published by Williams (1997: 2, fig. 3). This type of terminal is noted as having a distribution concentrated in East Anglia and Lincolnshire, making this find notable. It is also the first stirrup terminal recorded on the PAS from Devon.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy strap fitting or mount, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1700. The mount is flat, and cast into the form of a moustached bust, facing looking out from within scrolled decoration, with a fleur-de-lis at the apex, and tapering towards the base, which terminates in a lobe between two scrolled volutes. Two incomplete, integral rivets project from the reverse, both on the longitudinal median line. Extensive remains of a white metal coating survive on both faces.Dimensions: length 31.6mm; width 19.8mm; thickness 5.8mm; weight 4.98g.The general style and decoration would suggest a 17th century date, compare similar mounts such as: SOM-9BB054.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy coin weight probably dating to c. AD 1400-1600. The weight is uniface, sub-circular in plan and rectangular in cross-section. The front depicts a ship with single mast, with further detail lost to abrasion, the reverse is plain.Dimensions: diameter 17.2mm; thickness 4.0mm; weight 5.75g.Withers & Withers (1995: 19) publish a similar example, with mast flanked by a lis and lion, which they suggest was a weight for the gold noble.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A Late medieval Copper alloy french Jetton, Tournai (late), dating to c.AD 1373-1437. AVE MARIA GRASIA PLENA obverse type, depicting a stylised Chatel Tournai, reverse depicting a triple stranded straiht cross fleuretty within a four-arched tressure. Mint of Tournai. cf. Mitchiner 1988: 187 no. 505-507.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval gold half-guinea of George II (AD 1727-1760), dating to AD 1759. Spink (2011) no. 3685. The coin has been folded, obscuring the reverse.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver coin, possibly a threepence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603), possibly dating to AD 1561-1582. Probably second coinage, unertain initial mark, london mint. North (1991: 135) no. 1998.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver halgroat of James I (AD 1603-1625) dating to AD 1620-1621. Third coinage, rose intial mark, London mint. North (1991: 148) no. 2127.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver halgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603) dating to AD 1583-1585. Third coinage, A intial mark, London mint. North (1991:137) no. 2016.

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: A Medieval enamelled copper alloy horse harness pendant and associated mount, probably dating to c. AD 1200-1400. The pendant is lozengiform, with a transverse attachment loop projecting from the apex, and decorated with an enamelled depiction of the pelican in her piety, with the birds depicted using white enamel seated within a nest of sub-square red enamel cells. The associated mount is unelaborated, consisting of a simple D-shaped perforated lug with a separate rivet projecting from the reverse. Two transverse perforated lugs project from the base of the mount, forming a box for the attachment loop and retaining an iron axis bar in situ. Dimensions: length 44.6mm; width 29.1mm; thickness 6.4mm; weight 12.77g.Griffiths (1986) suggests that enamelled heraldic harness pendants were at their most popular ding the 13th and 14th centuries, depictions of the pelican in her piety, which symbolises the sacrifice of christ, are relatively common on harness pendants of the period, cf. SOM-DF7DBE, NMS-646F75, HAMP-88B9D4.

properties.title: PIPE (SMOKING)
properties.description: An incomplete Post-Medieval to Modern clay tobacco-pipe, probably dating to AD 1787- c. 1807. The surviving portion consists of roughly 50% of the bowl, it's juncture with the pipe as well as the pointed spur. The bowl was originally moulded in two parts and later joined, with the longitudinal seems running along the inside and outside joins of the bowl decorated with moulded foliate decoration. The spur features no maker's marks. The surviving face of the bowl is decorated with a depiction of a male figure kneeling left, bound in chains and with with hands raised in prayer.Dimensions: Height 39.1mm; length 34.4mm; diameter of stem 8.7mm; width of bowl 21.2mm; weight 5.80g.The depiction on the bowl is most likely that of an African slave, imitating the design of the prominent ceramic 'Am I not a man and Brother?' medallion produced by Josiah Wedgwood for the Society of the Abolition of Slavery in 1787. The object therefore likely dates to between 1787 and 1807, although the device continued in use, for example by the Women's abolition movement in the 1830s (Guyard 2000). Similar pipes commemorating the battle of Trafalgar were excavated in Poole (Horsey 1992: 170, nos. 145-146), dated to 1805.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy strap fitting, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1700. The strap fitting consists of an oval plate, with a perforated knop expanding from the apex and retaining iron corrosion from a separate rivet. At the base of the plate is a moulded transverse collar, surmounting an old break. The plate is decorated, although now worn, with the decoration cinsisting of a combination of incised lines and punched annulets, in a probable foliate design. Further iron corrosion is affixed to the reverse of the plate at the base.Dimensions: length 37.8mm; width 21.9mm; thickness 4.4mm; weight 9.09g.Read (2008: 221-222) publishes a number of comparable examples which he dates to the 17th century.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A fragment of a Medieval to Post-Medieval Spanish silver two real of Ferdinand and Isabella (AD 1479-1504). Probably minted in Seville.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval Scottish silver Twenty pence of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1637-1642. Third coinage. Spink (2015: 93) nos. 5589-5591.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver sixpence of James I (AD 1603-1625), dating to AD 1605. Second coinage, rose initial mark. North (1991: 146) no. 2103.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver penny of Edward I (AD 1272-1307), dating to c. AD 1303-1305. Class 10ab5, Canterbury mint. North (1991: 31) no. 1039/3.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy dupondius or as, probably dating to c. AD 1-250. Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval open thimble or sewing ring, probably dating to c. AD 1400-1600. The thimble consists of a hoop of copper alloy, now flattened and with a large dent to the upper edge. The hoop comprises of a flat band with a series of shallowly hand-drilled sub-circular indentations aranged into a series of concentric circles.Dimensions: Length 26.4mm; width 8.3mm; thickness 13.8mm; weight 4.29g.cf. Holmes (1988: fig. 4), dated to c. AD 1500.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy rowel, probably dating to c. AD 1500-1700. The spur takes the form of a seven-pointed mullet in plan, with a central perforation and with an incised groove radiating from this to the insterstice of each point.Dimensions: Diameter 42.1mm; thickness 2.4mm; weight 11.41g.Similar rowels are illustrated by Read (1995: 127, nos. 805-806), which he suggests date to the eaely Post-Medieval period. cf. similar examples on this database, e.g. HAMP-A89734

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy nummus of Constantius II (AD 337-361), dating to AD 341-346 (Reece period 17). VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN reverse type, depicting two victories standing facing each other holding wreaths. Mint of Trier. LRBC I, p. 6, nos. 145-147.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy posy ring, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1800. The ring comprises of a plain hoop, shallowly plano-convex in cross-section and with a brazed join at one point on its circumference. The interior of the ring is inscribed 'RE GOD ONLY' in capitals; the beginning of the inscription appears to have been truncated by the join, suggesting that the ring was originally larger, and that it was resized. By comparison to other examples (see below) the inscription would likely have read: FEARE GOD ONLY. Dimensions: Diameter 18.8mm; width 5.0mm; thickness 1.7mm; weight 2.30g.On precious metal examples of similar posy rings short inscriptions in block capitals are normally taken to indicate and earlier date, normally in the 17th or early 18th century; a less well executed base meta example such as this however may have been more conservative and a broader date range is suggested. Other posy rings with the same insciption are recorded on this database, cf. NMGW-C6437A, DYFED-7E5761, PAS-3AAF34, SF-4DEE72.

properties.title: DAGGER
properties.description: A Late Medieval to Early Post-Medieval copper alloy dagger guard (quillon), probably dating to c. AD 1400-1550. The guard consists of a lozengiform bar which broadens to expanded hexagonal section terminals at either end, and has a rectangular hole for the dagger tang at the center. To one side projects a double-arched protective frame. The surface is worn and retains traces of green patina, and black laquer. Iron staining is present around the tang hole, suggesting the blade has corroded in-situ.Dimensions: length 45.7mm; width 26.3mm; thickness 5.6mm; weight 18.3g.Read (2001, 76, 86) publishes a similar example which he dates to the 15th century. Ward-Perkins (1940: 40, 42) suggests the quillon-dagger was the most common form of military dagger during the 14th century, it's use continuing on through the 15th century whilst the rondel dagger became the more common type, he also notes however, that they continued to be depicted in all periods. Quillon guards of this form are reaively common and appear highly standardised (cf. LANCUM-DC7805, SOM-53C4B4, LEIC-6B072B, amongst others on this database) and thus a broader date range is suggested, allowing for a slightly later date.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A fragment of a Medieval copper alloy purse bar, probably dating to c. AD 1450-1500. The fragment comprises of one fragmentary arm only, with the circular sectioned arm projecting from the jaws of an incomplete zoomorphic moulding. Double-stranded niello-inlaid cross-hatched decoration survives at the terminal end of the arm, with an incomplete sub-rectangular attachment plate projecting from the arm, parallel to the length of the arm; one perforation survives. The arm terminates in worn breaks at both ends.Dimensions: length 39.9mm; width 8.0mm; thickness 12.2mm; weight 14.35g.Purse bars with niello inlaid decoration and zoomorphic mouldings at the bases of arms are classified by Ward-Perkins (1940: 164) as his type A1, they are believed to be at the earlier end of the range, and pre-date c. 1500 (ibid).

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy zoomorphic spout, probably dating to c. AD 1400-1550 and likely from an ewer. The spout terminates in a simplistic moulded dog's head with the spout projecting outwards from its open mouth. The upper snout is sub-triangular to trapezoidal in cross section and is sub-rectangular when viewed above, with a rounded, slightly lipped nose. Behind the snout the spout expands into a sub-rectangular head, with no idication of eyes or further additional detail. On either side of the head are a pair of intregal sub-rectangular ears with slightly depressed outer surfaces and which project upwards slightly. Behind the head the spout then narrows into the neck, with the lower edge then flaring pronoucedly, expanding to the edge where the spout was affixed to the vessel. The spout has a tubular cross section.Dimensions: Length 68.3mm; width 16.8mm; thickness 52.1mm; weight 78.53g.A comparible example is illustrated by Lewis (1987: 5, no. 8A) from Cardiff Castle's moat, given a 15th century date range. There are also numerous comparible examples on this database: e.g. SOM-FDFCBB, SOM-4A45C4, YORYM-178D04.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Sestertius of an uncertain issuer, possibly a second century empress, but probably dating to AD 138-222. Uncertain reverse type, depicting a figure standing left. Probably Rome mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Sestertius of an uncertain Antonine or Severan Emperor, probably dating to AD 161-222 (Reece period 7-10). Uncertain reverse type, [...] S-C, depicting a figure standing left with a probable rudder or baton in left hand. Mint of Rome.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An incomplete Roman copper alloy nummus of Constantinus II as Caesar, dating to AD 330-335 (Reece period 17). Gloria Exercitvs reverse type, depicting two soldiers with two standards, with a star above. Mint of Arles. LRBC I, no. 353.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1636-1645. Rose (type 2), crescent initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 165) no. 2291.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver threepence of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603), probably dating to c. AD 1567-1569. Second coinage, probably coronet initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 135) no. 1998.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver halfgroat of James I (1603-1625), dating to AD 1606-7. Second coinage, escallop initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 146) no. 2104.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver groat of Mary (1553-4), dating to AD 1553-4. Pomegranate privy mark. London mint. North (1991: 126) no. 1960.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver halfgroat of Henry VII (AD 1485-1509), dating to c. AD 1490-1500. Facing bust issue, class IIIa, lis initial mark. Canterbury mint. North (1991: 102) no. 1712.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver groat of Mary (1553-4), dating to AD 1553-4. Pomegranate privy mark. London mint. North (1991: 126) no. 1960.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver groat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603), dating to 1558-60. First coinage, lis initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 133) no. 1986.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval Scottish silver twenty pence of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to c. 1636. Second coinage, Briot's hammered issue, Spink no. 5550.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy pot leg, of Butler, Green and Payne's type C, probably dating to c. AD 1500-1700. The leg is sub-rectangular in plan and plano-convex in cross-section, with a prominent transverse collar dividing the foot and leg, with the latter lost to an old break. The inside edge is flat and plain.Dimensions: length 49.5mm; width 31.1mm; thickness 19.9mm; weight 107.74g.Butler, Green & Payne (2009) classify such legs as their type C, in use by the 16th century and ubiquitous by the 17th.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy six Deniers of Louis XIV of France (AD 1643-1715), dating to AD 1711. Ampersand mint mark, minted at Aix-en-Provence. cf. DENO-2F2045 on this database.The coin has been struck off-centre, and has a green-black patina.

properties.title: PALSTAVE
properties.description: A fragment of a Middle Bronze Age copper alloy palstave, probably dating to c. 1500-1100 BC. The surviving fragment comprises of the upper portion of the blade, truncated below the stop ridge at the butt end and with the cutting edge also lost. Both breaks are worn and patinated. The fragment is sub-trapezoidal in plan, slightly flaring towards the cutting edge, and sub-triangular in cross section, measuring 21.5mm wide by 15.5mm thick at the butt end, and 37.3mm wide by 7.4mm thick at the cutting edge-end. The fragment is 47.3mm in length. There is the suggestion of a mid-rib on one face of the blade, but this is tentative due to abrasion.Overall dimensions: length 47.3mm; width 37.3mm; thickness 15.5mm; weight 105.4g.The fragment is too incomplete to be assigned to a typological group, and a broad middle Bronze Age date is suggested.

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: An incomplete Late medieval or Post-Medieval copper alloy plaque or fitting, probably dating to c. AD 1400-1550. The object comprises of a sub-rectangular sheet of copper alloy, intact along three of its edges and with a patinated break on its fourth (left) edge. The object is perforated twice, with a rivet hole in either right corner. An incised rectangular border, partially followed by the break on the left, defines a field containing a crowned IS, the two being entwined. A wavy incised line follows the median line of the S, terminating in an oval at either end. The I appears to have originally had a transverse bar at the top, but this appears to have been subsequently filled. The crown is bifoliate with a central fleur and vestigial jewels, with triangular voids beneath each. The background of the field is filled with incised cross-hatching. There are traces of a laquer coating.Dimensions: length 43.5mm; width 30.6mm; thickness 1.0mm; weight 7.13g.The incised IS is likely a contraction of (or mistake, possibly suggested by the erased cross-bar on the I) of Ihs. Although it is not clear what the fitting was a component of, the style of crown and decoration would probably all suggest a late medieval or early Post-Medieval date. A similar inscription, although lacking the crown, can be seen on a composite strap end, of a form dated to c. 1350-1530, BH-379383.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver penny of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603), dating to AD 1560-1561. First coinage, Cross-crosslet initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 133) no. 1988.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver penny of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to 1636-1645. Group D, Two-pellets inital mark. London mint. North (1991: 163) no. 2270.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing probably of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1636-1645. Probable rose farthing, uncertain type. London mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1636-1645. Rose (type 2), uncertain initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 165) no. 2291.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1636-1645. Rose (type 2), Crescent initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 165) no. 2291.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1636-1645. Rose (type 2), Crescent initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 165) no. 2291.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver penny of Edward I (AD 1272-1307), dating to AD 1283. Class 4a, Canterbury mint. North (1991: 29) no. 1023.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver halfgroat of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1640-1649. Group D, uncertain intial mark, probably triangle-in-circle or (R), (P). London mint. North (1991: 162) no. 2258.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A Post-medieval lead 2-part cloth seal, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1800. The sela comprises of two discs of lead connecting by a rectangular connecting strip, with one disc having an integral rivet pressed through an aperture on the other. Disc-1 is stamped with 3 / COADE / 84 (the latter being upside down. Disc-2 is plain.Dimensions: length 34.0mm; width 25.6mm; thickness 3.7mm; weight 12.81g.The Coades were a family of wool merchants, local to Devon and West Dorset.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval Silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603), dating to AD 1572. Second coinage, ermine initial mark, London mint. North (1991: 134) no. 1997.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An extremely abraded probable Roman coin. From its size and by comparison to other finds made in its vicinity, probably a dupondius or as dating to c. AD 1-200. Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: METAL WORKING DEBRIS
properties.description: Copper alloy metal working debris of unknown date, c. 2400 BC - AD 1900, but probably post AD 1500. Weight: 77.18g.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: An incomplete Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy purse bar frame, probably dating to c. AD 1450-1550. The frame consists of a slightly curved, oval-sectioned bar of copper alloy, terminating in a worn break at one end and bifurcating into an incomplete loop at the other. The outside edge of the bar is slightly facetted, with both featuring incised zig-zag decoration.Dimensions: length 77.6mm; width 5.2mm; thickness 5.3mm; weight 12.65g.cf. Ward-Perkins (1940) plates XXXIV-XXXV, who notes that frames of solid construction are most likely associated with less elaborate types.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy radiate of uncertain issue, probably dating to c. AD 260-275 (Reece Period 13). Uncertain reverse type, depicting a central standing figure holding a patera. Uncertain mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy As of uncertain issue, probably dating to c. 43-200. Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Sestertius of Trajan (AD 98-117, Reece period 5). Uncertain reverse type. Probably Rome mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver penny of Edward II (AD 1307-1327), dating to c. AD 1312-1314. Class 11b1, London mint. North (1991: 36) no. 1061/1.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver groat of Mary (AD 1553-1558), dating to AD 1553-1554. Pomegranate initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 126) no. 1960.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver Three halfpence, halfgroat or penny of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603). Uncertain intial mark, london mint.The coin has been pierced, drilled from the obverse, behind the bust, with a mark left by initial drilling to the left of this. If a halfgroat, these would be in line with the two pellets behind the bust.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete Roman copper alloy colchester derivative hinged initial T-shaped brooch, probably dating to AD 60-100. The surviving section comprises of the majority of the bow and vestigial remains of the wings, the foot, catchplate and most of the wings are missing. The brooch is encrusted in a well compacted, red sand.The head of the brooch survives to a width of 13.3mm, with only the vestigial remains of the right wing surviving. The back of what were probably originally cylindrical wings have worn away to leave a C-shaped cross section with an open back. The axis bar and pin do not survive. The bow falls out of the head at a relatively straight angle, D-shaped in cross section with a slightly concave reverse, initially c. 11.8mm wide by 7.3mm thick and tapering towards the worn break. Encrusted material obscures the decoration, however sightly obliquely angled ridges define what is probably a tapering central zone, with this raised slightly below the head.Overall dimensions: length 29.5mm; width 13.3mm; thickness 7.3mm; weight 7.34g.A very comparable brooch has been excavated in Exeter from a context dating to c. AD 160-200 (Holbrook & Bidwell 2001: 235-236, no. 11). Another example, although with a more angular profile, and a differently formed crest, was found at Henley Woods, Somerset (Watts & Leach 1996: Fig. 87, no. 8). Typologically the general form and simple decoration would suggest that it is an example of an initial T-shaped brooch, generally dated to the Flavian period (Bayley & Butcher 2004). cf. IOW-9D7150.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy as probably dating to c. AD 100-250. Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A very worn Roman copper-alloy coin, probably a contemporary copy of a Claudian as, dating to the period c.AD 41-54 (Reece period 2). Unclear reverse type possibly depicting a standing figure with elbow projecting to right. Cf. Boon, 1988: pl. III, especially nos. 41-44 (nos. 41-43 for Antonia under Claudius), for similar contemporary copies that may provide parallels. The coin is struck on an irregularly shaped and unusually thin flan. Robert Kenyon, following on from the work by the French scholars P-A. Besombes and M. Bompaire (in Tr�sors Mon�taires XXI, 2005), is working through the British examples of Claudian coinage recorded through the PAS assigning many so-called Claudian contemporary copies to Roman auxiliary mints which operated at Lyons (Gaul) and in Spain. This example is a native copy.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Sesterius of probable Flavian date (AD 69-96, Reece Period 4). Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy tournai (late) jetton, dating to c. AD 1447-1521. Three circles type, with the obverse depicting three annulets each with a quatrefoil within and fleur-de-lis at the interstices, in the centre a pellet, The reverse a cross pattee with flowers sprigging into each quarter from the inner circle. cf. Mitchiner (1988: 243) no.750.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A Medieval gilded copper alloy horse harness pendant suspension mount, probably dating to c. AD 1200-1400. The mount is cast into the form of a quatrefoil, with incised V-shaped grooves further defining the intersice between each lobe. The transverse lobes each have a central, circular perforation holding a copper alloy rivet in situ. One is loose, 8.3mm long with a circular shaft and flatened, sub-circular head, c. 3.7mm in diameter. The perforation was probably drilled from the reverse, resulting in a slight lip on the front. The mount is flat in profile, thickening towards the edge of the lower lobe from which projects a pair of transverse perforated lugs from which a harness pendant would be suspended. Significant traces of gilding survive on the front of the mount.Dimensions: length 38.0mm; width 30.1mm; thickness 6.1mm; weight 8.83g.Griffiths (1986: 4) and Clark (1995: 69) illustrate suspension mounts in various forms. It can be compared to enamelled heraldic pendants of the same basic form (cf. Clark 1995: 66, nos. 65-66) as well as mounts such as DUR-498573. Enamelled heraldic pendants are generally dated to the 13th and 14th centuries, although they more have originated slightly earlier and most will be from the latter end of this range (Griffiths 1986).

properties.title: AXEHEAD
properties.description: A small Neolithic flint axehead roughout, probably dating to c. 4000-2400 BC. The axehead is crudely knapped, and shows indications of being reworked from a larger, polished axhead. The axehead is of a heavily patinated grey/white flint, containing frequent buff inclusions and with several areas of iron staining on its surface. The axehead is bifacially worked, with verry large, irregular and often hinged struck from the edges of the tool to create a broadly sub-rectangular plan, expanding from a squarred butt, 29.1mm wide, to its widest point at roughly the mid-point, 50.2mm, and from there narrowing into a battered, trapezoidal blade, 30.1mm wide. The axehead has a broadly pointed-oval cross section, 29.1mm thick at the mid-point, and tapering in either direction into blunted ends. The axehead is 93.7mm long and weighs 131.89g.Positioned roughly centrally at the butt end of one face is a single smooth, polished facet cut on all sides by subsequent removal scars, suggesting that is has been reworked from a completed axehead.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval copper alloy Tournai (late) Jetton, dating to AD 1497-1521. IHS Christus Dominus Laudetus' type. The obverse depicts an Ihs monogram with a pellet below the s, the reverse a cross pattee with fleur-de-lis in each quarter. cf. Mernick & Algar (2001: 239) no. 191.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: An incomplete Post-Medieval silver threepence of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603) dating to AD 1565. Second Coinage, rose initial mark, mint of London. North (1991: 135) no. 1998.There is an irregualr break between c. 3 and 6 o'clock.

properties.title: DAGGER
properties.description: A probable Post-Medieval copper alloy pommel from a dagger, probably dating to c. AD 1500-1700. The pommel is sub-rectangular in plan and profile, and is was cast in two halves and subsequently affixed together. The interior of the pommel is hollow, with a large circular aperture at one end c. 9.2mm in diameter, and a much smaller, sub-oval aperture at the other, allowing for a tang to pass logitudinally through the object, although there is no evidence of iron corrosion. Both faces of the pommel are cast into a series of parellel, diagonal recessed lines which are continuous across the two halves. The remaining reserved ribs are scored by a series of perpendicular lines.Dimensions: length 36.0mm; width 27.7mm; thickness 16.5mm; weight 42.01g.No parallels for this object have been identfied, however LON-636D08, on this database, is of broadly similar construction. The green/red powdery patina of the object is highly suggestive of an early post-Medieval date, with the vast majority of material in the area also being post-1500.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Greek coin - silver obol of the city of Massalia (Marseilles) in southern France, dating to c. 400-300 BC.Obverse: Youthful male head leftReverse: Wheel with four spokes; M A in two quarters.SNG Copenhagen Spain and Gaul, pl. XXXVI, nos. 722-8

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy cloth seal, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1800. Two lead alloy discs pressed together with one connecting strip surviving, the vestigial remains of a second set of connecting strips as well as the lack of a rivet on either disc suggesting that it was originally a 4-disc seal. One face is stamped in low relief with a depiction of an eagle or other bird of prey standing left with wings outstretched, stood on a trasverse line of pellets. This is within a low largely illegible inscription: [...(IN?)...]WA[...]ON (pellet). On the reverse, again in low relief is the number 23, with the number three incuse above.Dimensions: length 30.9mm; width 27.2mm; thickness 3.2mm; weight 14.82g.Although not identical, the design on the seal can be compared to BH-128517. Egan (1994: 49) suggests that seals depicting eagles with wings adorsed rather than outstreched may be linked to the Norwich weaver's guild.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Medieval to Post-Medieval cast copper alloy pot foot, probably dating to AD 1200-1700. The fragment is highly abraded, triagular in plan and sub-triangular in cross section, tapering from the break into a pointed foot. The front of the foot expands outwards into a pronounced central crest or rib, with the reverse being convex. It terminates at the top in a worn break.Dimensions: length 40.6mm; width 28.4mm; thickness 17.5mm; weight 38.66g.Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used throughout the Medieval and Post-Medieval periods for serving and cooking (Butler et al 2009).

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval cast copper alloy pot foot, probably dating to AD 1500-1700. The fragment is highly abraded, sub rectangular in plan and broadly triangular in cross section, with a short, trapezoidal foot below the collar. The foot has a flat back and convex front, and is broken above a transverse collar at an old break.Dimensions: length 38.1mm; width 23.6mm; thickness 15.4mm; weight 44.55g.Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is a Type C which they suggest was already in use by the late 16th century and almost universal in the 17th.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing token of Charles I (AD 1625-1649), dating to AD 1634-1636. Type 3b (Maltravers "rounds"), bell/bell initial mark. Minted in London. North (1991: 164) no. 2281.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post-Medieval cast copper alloy mount, probably dating to c. AD 1500-1700. The mount is sub-circular in plan, with a slightly convex front and concave back, with an incomplete square-sectioned integral rivet expanding from the centre of the reverse, tapering to a worn break. The front of the mount is decorated, moulded in relief, with a central pellet flanked by the arms of a pelleted cross with a sub-rectangular/oval foil in each quarter.Dimensions: diameter 22.0mm; thickness 2.7mm, including rivet 8.3mm; weight 4.32g.The mount can be compared to near identical examples recorded on this database, cf. SF-EA9B09, NMS-55E378, as well as to Post-Medieval mounts more generally, cf. SOM-2AC422, SOM-DA1446, SOM-89F891.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver halfgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1548-1603), dating to AD 1595-1598. Third coinage, key initial mark, minted in London. North (1991: 137) no. 2016.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy contemporary copy nummus of the of the House of Constantine, dating to c. AD 355-361 (Reece period 18). Imitating the FEL TEMP REPARATIO reverse type, depicting a soldier advancing left spearing a fallen horseman.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Dupondius or As, probably dating to c. AD 1-200. Uncertain reverse type and mint.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy Sestertius, probably of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) or Lucius Verus (AD 161-169), probably dating to AD 161-170 (Reece Period 8). PROFECTIO AVG TR P II COS II or PROFECTIO AVG COS III reverse type, depicting the emperor with spear on horse prancing right, with an armed soldier in front and further soldiers behind. Mint of Rome. RIC III, pg. 290, no. 963, pg. 291, no. 977 or pg. 319, nos. 1321-1323.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete Roman copper alloy Colchester derivative developed T-shaped hinged brooch, dating to c. AD 70-150. The surviving fragment comprises of the head and upper bow, with part of the wings, lower bow and pin all missing.At the head of the bow the wings survive to a width of 33.2mm, the left wing being incomplete. The wings are cylindrical, c.5.1mm in diameter, and hold the partial remains of a copper alloy axis bar in situ. Into the reverse of the head a rectangualr slot has been cut centrally to accomodate a pin, now lost.The bow expands out from the head with a width of 9.1mm, sub-rectangular in cross section and with a very slightly convex outer face, 3.8mm thick. Initially expanding out relatively level, there is subsequently a break in angle of around 90 degrees, from which point the brooch continues largely straight before terminating in a wron break. The bow does not survive to its original width at the break, however the width appears to remain largely consistant.The bow is decorated with a border of punched pellets, running along both edges and along the head, parallel with the wings. At the top of the bow, as it expands from the head, their is the suggestion of a downwards pointing triangle within this border, again of punched pellets, although this is obscured by abrasion. Lower down the bow, prior to the break, is a circular depression, most likely a cell for inlaid enamel decoration, with this followed by a second sub-rectangular or triangular cell, truncated by the break. Neither contains surviving enamel. A circumferencial incised line (or series of abraded punched pellets) deliniates the surviving wing tip.Overall dimensions: length 24.5mm; width 33.2; thickness, as measured from front of bow to rear of head, 11.9mm; weight 6.55g.Although lackign an integral headloop, in its general proportions and enamelled decoration the brooch closely resembles developed T-shaped brooches, see for example those illustrated by Bayley & Butcher (2005: 166, fig. 138). They describe this as a type with a largely South Western distribution, and they are generally dated to the later first or early second centuries (ibid: 167).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver sixpence of William III (AD 1694-1702), dating to AD 1694-1695. Minted in London. Spink no. 3520.The coin has been pierced centrally by a large circular, drilled perforation, 2.9mm in diameter, from the reverse, which is very heavily worn.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval cast copper alloy pot foot, probably dating to AD 1500-1700. The fragment is highly abraded, sub rectangular in plan and D-shaped in cross section, with a short, trapezoidal foot below the collar. The foot has a flat back and convex front, and is broken immediately above a transverse collar at an old break.Dimensions: length 31.7mm; width 24.8mm; thickness 13.7mm; weight 39.67g.Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is a Type C which they suggest was already in use by the late 16th century and almost universal in the 17th.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post-Medieval cast copper alloy pot foot, probably dating to AD 1500-1700. The fragment is highly abraded, sub rectangular in plan and D-shaped in cross section, with a flat back and convex front. Broken immediately above a transverse collar at a worn break and with traces of cast vertical ribs just visible.Dimensions: length 41.9mm; width 23.3mm; thickness 16.5mm; weight 68.84g.  Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is a Type C which they suggest was already in use by the late 16th century and almost universal in the 17th.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: An impacted piece of lead shot, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1700.  Dimensions: diameter 23.4mm; thickness 9.7mm; weight 24.27g.Whilst difficult to date in isolation, a large concentration of shot in the area, many of which displaying evidence of being cast, may suggest a civil war site, hence a 17th century date range is suggested.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: An unimpacted piece of lead shot, probably dating to c. AD 1600-1700. Evidence for both casting seam and sprue present.Dimensions: diameter 12.8mm; weight 10.82g.Although difficult to date in isolation, the evidence that the shot was cast would suggest it was produced in the 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy Medieval to Post-Medieval double looped buckle, probably dating to c. AD 1350-1650. The surviving frame comprises of a single oval loop, with the second lost to worn breaks. The frame is D-shaped in cross section with a narrowed central bar, flanked by knops. The bar is similarly D-shaped in cross secion. A copper alloy sheet pin survives wrapped around the bar. Areas of black may suggest traces of a linseed oil coating.Dimensions: length 19.9mm; width 21.4mm; thickness 2.7mm; weight 2.69g.The lack of any decoration makes it difficult to suggest anything more than a very general date range, a number of double looped buckles are published by Whitehead (2003), which he dates to AD 1350-1650.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver threepence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603), dating to AD 1575. Second coinage, elegantine initial mark. Minted in London. North (1991: 135) no. 1998.

properties.title: CHISEL
properties.description: A copper-alloy fragment of a possible middle or late Bronze Age tanged chisel, dating to c. 1500-800 BC. The fragment is sub-rectangular in plan, and rectangular in cross-section, measuring 19.7mm wide by 6.5mm thick. At one end it terminates in a worn break from which point it tapers in profile to a point, where the blade terminates in a convex edge. The fragment has a mottled dark and pale green patina and is pitted across the surface.Dimensions: length 30.5mm; width 19.8mm; thickness 6.6mm; weight 17.33g.Although with such a small fragment any identification must remain tentative, the patina of the metal would suggest a Bronze Age date. Mr Matthew Knight commented that the fragment may possibly be a piece of a late Bronze Age tanged chisel (pers. comm. 13/07/2016), and possible parallels can be seen recorded on this database: see for example, YORYM-71EBF0 or HESH-51B7E2.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval silver groat of Henry VIII (AD 1509-1547), dating to AD 1529-1544. Second Coinage, Lis initial mark. London mint. North (1991: 111) no. 1797.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy farthing token of Charles I (AD 1625-1648), dating to c. 1636-1644. Rose type 2, Crescent initial mark. Mint of London. North (1991: 165) no. 2291.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post-Medieval copper alloy coin weight, produced in Antwerp and probably dating to c. AD 1500-1600. The weight is square and stamped bifacially. The detail of both faces is largely unclear, but with the hand of Antwerp visible in low relief on the obverse, with a possible letter R, also in relief, to the right. The design on the reverse was within a circular border, but no other detail remains.Dimensions: length 14.7mm; width 14.7mm; thickness 2.3mm; weight 3.45g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver Roman denarius of Vespasian (AD 69-79), dating to the period AD 75-76 (Reece period 4). [P]ON M[AX TR P COS VI/VII] reverse type depicting Pax seated left holding branch. Mint of Rome. As RIC II (2nd ed.), pp. 114, 120, nos. 772-773, 852.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver groat of Edward III (AD 1327-1377), dating to AD 1351-1352. Fourth Coinage, pre-treaty series C, Cross 1 initial mark. Minted in London. North (1991: 50) no. 1147.

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: A Medieval copper alloy heraldic horse harness pendant, probably dating to c. AD 1200-1400. A shield shaped pendant with a square top and with the sides curving round to meet in a point at the base, which has been bent and now curves backwards slightly. From the top of the shield expands a square cross-sectioned tang which terminates in a now incomplete transverse attachment loop. The shield is decorated with a recessed design of a double-headed eagle with outstreched wings and a trefoilate tail. Traces of a red enamel inlay survive in the beak and wings, and with blue enamel at the wing tips and the side feathers of the tail. One of the heads also has a surviving enamel inlay, dark blue but now discoloured dark green in some areas. Dimensions: length 40.7mm; width 26.2mm; thickness 4.3mm; weight 10.79g.Griffiths (1986) illustrates similarly shaped pendants and notes that heraldic horse harness pendants were at their most popular in the 14th century, but had originated earlier potentially in the twelfth. Although with differently coloured enamel, a very similar pendant, also found in Devon, can be seen recorded on this database: DEV-C01A37. The record SF2605 notes that:"A double-headed eagle displayed was a armorial device used by Richard Earl of Cornwall following his election as King of the Romans in 1257. He died in 1272 and the arms was also used by his son Edmund, Earl of Cornwall 1272-1300. Richard was given the extensive Honour of Eye in Suffolk in 1230 and the Honour of Haughley by 1241. Both Honours were also held by Edmund until his death in 1300."

properties.title: HOARD
properties.description: 2017 T362 - Undergoing consideration as treasureDescription:  A complete Late Bronze socketed axe head. The axe head is 58.7mm long with a sub-rectangular mouth and with a small triangular protrusion at the centre of each lateral edge, in line with well-defined casting seams running the length of the axe head. The external edge of the mouth is 41.8mm wide and 29.5mm thick, the internal edge of the mouth is 27.0mm wide and 18.9mm thick, the socket is 46.3mm deep.Below the mouth the axe narrows to 38.6mm wide and 23.6mm thick. The blade has a sub-rectangular to hexagonal cross section, with both lateral faces expanding into a pronounced longitudinal, central ridge with the casting seam at the centre. The blade is sub-rectangular when viewed in plan, flaring into a slightly convex cutting edge which is 39.2mm wide, when viewed in profile the blade is triangular, tapering from the mouth to the cutting edge, 3.9mm thick.From one lateral face expands a sub-rectangular attachment loop, 23.4mm long, connecting to the axe head at the juncture between the mouth and blade and just prior to the mid-point of the blade. This loop has a sub-oval cross section, c. 3.7mm thick and with the width of the axe including the loop being 38.6mm. On each broad face of the axe are a set of three slightly converging longitudinal ribs, cast in low relief.The axe head weighs 110.35g.Discussion:  Although unusually squat, the axe head otherwise fits in well with the Ewart Park phase of Late Bronze Age metal working, giving it a likely date of c. 1000-800 BC. Very similar socketed axe heads of comparable sizes (c. 60mm in length) from late Bronze Age hoards can be seen illustrated both by Savory (1980: 190, no. 281:7), found as part of a hoard recovered in Llantwit Major, Glam, and recorded onto the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, from a founder's hoard in Herefordshire (2015 T663; Adams 2015).A Bronze Age fragment of a probable chisel or awl, not under consideration as Treasure, had been found previously on the site by a separate finder, probably in the first half of 2016. This was handed into the Royal Albert Memorial Museum for identification on the 8th of July, 2016 and has now been recorded onto the Portable Antiquities Scheme database as DEV-BA9812. This is highly fragmentary and largely undiagnostic, but is probably a fragment of a middle or late Bronze Age chisel.Given their greatly varying states of preservation, and considering a reported wet area in the centre of the field, multiple depositions cannot be ruled out with certainty. However, with incomplete tools and other "scrap" being a noted feature of hoards of the Ewart Park phase of metal working (Needham 1996), on the balance of probability these objects seem likely to represent two components of a Late Bronze Age hoard probably disturbed by cultivation.Conclusion: Given the condition of the axe head the previous find of Bronze Age chisel in the vicinity, it is reasonable to suggest that both finds were deposited as part of a hoard. Given their prehistoric date the axe head therefore qualifies as potential Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Wil PartridgeFinds Liaison Officer for Devon & SomersetJuly 2017Seen by Neil Wilkin, Curator, The British Museum,January 2018

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: Medieval cast copper alloy heraldic harness pendant. The pendant is lozenge shaped. From the top point of the lozenge projects a transverse suspension loop. The loop has a rectangular sectioned shank widening to a ring shaped terminal which projects slightly forward of the main pendant.The front of the pendant appears to be decorated with the arms: Or, three torteaux a label azure; ie gold with three red circles and a blue line across the top which has three short lines descending from it. However two regular areas on each point of the label lack enamel and it is possible the arms were further differenced by designs on the points. The enamel mostly survives well but the gilded background is very worn. The back and loop are plain. It is 38.7mm long including the loop, 24.1mm wide and 6.3mm thick including the loop, 2.3mm excluding it.Harness pendants are generally dated from the twelfth to the fourteenth century, with enamelled and heraldic types predominating in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries (Griffiths, 1995:62). 'Or, three torteaux a label azure' were the arms of the Courtneys from about 1200, including those who were Earls of Devon, between AD 1276 and 1458. Junior branches of the family differenced these arms by adding designs to the points, for example three bezants in the case of the Courtneys of Powderham and three mitres for Archbishop William Courtney. A member differencing the arms with two designs has not yet been identified in preliminary researches. The pendant may have been used by a supporter of the Courtneys or a retainer or by a family member. See PUBLIC-E82839 and IOW-DB7A13 on this database for similar examples with the same arms.

properties.title: CROTAL
properties.description: Cast copper alloy Post Medieval spherical crotal bell dating from the 18th century. The upper and lower hemispheres are divided by a horizontal circumferential joining rib. The upper sphere has two circular sound holes either side of the suspension loop, a '4' is stamped below the suspension loop which presumably indicates the particular size of bell. The lower hemisphere is decorated with a 'sunburst' pattern, a sound slit with circular holes at either end runs across the lower hemisphere. Either side of the sound slit, and at the centre of the 'sunburst' pattern, are two semi circles with ethe initials R and W, both flanked by two pellets. This suggests that the bell was manufactured by the founder Robert Wells or his son, Robert Wells Junior, of Aldbourne, Wiltshire, who were producing them from 1760-1799. The bell contains its spherical iron pea and is still capable of ringing.Bailey (1992) illustrates a similar example from the Robert Wells Foundry on page 42, no.30.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy disc weight of unknown date. The item is flat on both faces; there are no markings or stamps visible on either surface.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy setertius of Lucilla, dating to AD 164-169 (Reece period 8). Uncertain reverse type, probably minted in Rome.The edges of the coin have potentially been filed.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A possible Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is flattened and mis-shapen. The surface patina uneven and pitted and is mid gray in colour.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A medieval hammered silver coin. The coin is worn and cannot be identified further. A circular border of pellets is visible on both the obverse and reverse of the coin.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: A medieval to post-Medieval copper-alloy sword or dagger chape. The item appears to be made from sheet copper alloy. The chape is broadly triangular in plan; the sides gently taper from the open end to a rounded closed end. At the open end, there are two decorative,broadly triangular, indentations on either side. The body of the chape does not appear to be decorated. A broadly similar item, which is probably of 14th century date, is recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database at: DEV-DC3FD0. An incomplete 'roughly engrailed' chape with similar triangular indentations at the open end is illustrated in Egan (2005) p192, number 1074, which is dated from c. 1530 to 1550.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy decorative horse harness mount. The item is circular in plan with scalloped edges and a convex, domed boss in the centre. The item is likely to date from c. 1700 to 1800. A similar example is recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database: DEV-0AB6D5.

properties.title: CUTLERY
properties.description: An incomplete post-Medieval copper-alloy pastry jigger, dating from around the 18th century. The item consists of a cutting wheel at one end, and a shank which appears to have broken at its mid point. Both faces of the cutting wheel are flat with radiating grooves and ridges. The cuting edge forms a zig-zag shape in profile and is pierced centrally for an axis bar which secures it to the shank. The cutting wheel measures c.32 mm in diameter. At the wheel end, the shank divides into two arms, creating a slot for the cutting wheel to be housed. There is a circular hole at each arm to take the axle. The axle is still present and attaches the cutting wheel to the shank.Pastry jiggers were also known as rowles, jagging irons and pastry jaggers and were used for cutting and/or indenting pastry with a crimped pattern. Similar examples can be seen in 'Old Cooking Utensils' by David J. Eveleigh (Shire Library Classics) p 29.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button, dating to the 18th century. The button is octagonal in shape. The front face is flat and is decorated with two conccentric circles at the centre; in the space within the two circles are a series of short linear decorative grooves. Diameter 15 mm. See Bailey (2004) p55, fig 9.119 for a similar example.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button of 18th century date. The button is circular in shape. The front face is flat and has a sunburst decoration pattern at the centre; an unclear running decoration runs around the outer edge. Diameter 18 mm. See Bailey (2004) p66, fig.9.192 for a similar example.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button of 18th century date. The button is circular in shape and there are traces of decoration on the front face. Diameter 35 mm. See Bailey (2004) p60 for similar examples.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy shoe buckle chape from a two-piece buckle. The chape is a type VI 'cooking-pot' chape with a single spike (Whitehead 2003, p 96), which Whitehead dates from c. AD 1690 to 1720.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy shoe buckle with a drilled frame for a seperate spindle. The frame is rectangular with rounded corners. The spindle and loop chape with two internal spikes remain intact. A similar buckle is illustrated in Whitehead (2003) p105, number 669, which is dated from c. AD 1720 to 1790.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy asymmetrical buckle frame with one rounded end and one rectangular end, and an integral central strap bar. The pin is missing. A similar buckle is illustrated in Whitehead (2003) p90, number 561, which is dated from c. AD 1575 to 1700.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy double loop buckle frame with a lobed knop on the outer edge of each loop. The pin is missing. A similar buckle is illustrated in Whitehead (2003) p55, number 319, which is dated from c. AD 1500 to 1650.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval cast copper alloy double loop buckle frame. The buckle frame has a trilobed moulding on the outer edge of each loop, and one at either end of the strap bar. The pin is missing. A similar buckle is illustrated in Whitehead (2003) p65, number 397, which is dated from c. AD 1550 to 1650.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy Post Medieval button, dating to the 18th century. The button is circular in shape; the front is domed and the reverse is hollow and concave with an iron attachment loop at the centre. The front is decorated at the centre with a series of concentric circles, Diameter 29 mm. A button of broadly similar form with a domed front and convex reverse is illustrated in Bailey (2004; p 50, 9.75).

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy Post Medieval button, dating to the 18th century. The button is circular in shape; it is flat on both the front and reverse faces. The item is very worn so it is not possible to ascertain whether it was once decorated. The attachment loop has broken away and is missing, but it is possible to see where is was attached at the centre of the reverse face. Diameter 27 mm. A button of broadly similar form is illustrated in Bailey (2004; p 66, 9.193).

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: An incomplete copper alloy Post Medieval button, dating to the 18th century. The button is circular in shape and has flat and undecorated faces on both the front and reverse. The attachment loop remains intact at the cmtre of the reverse face. Diameter 27 mm. A broadly similar button is illustrated in Bailey (2004; p 66, 9.193) whilst the illustrated example is decorated, the overall form is similar to this undecorated button.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A lead alloy two-part cloth seal, probably dating to c. 1650-1724. Both discs and the connecting strip survive. The discs are flat and circular in form, and both surfaces are very worn. The front face of the disc depicts a laureate bust right; traces of an inscription, now illegible. The reverse of the seal depicts a double rose, above which is the inscription: 838(star). The circumference is marked with a border of inwards pointing, narrow triangles. The entire object measures 25 mm in length, 17 mm in width, 2 mm in thickness. No weight was recorded for this object.Although no exact parallel has been found, similar designs are commonly seen on late alnage seals, such as WAW-5F8532, BH-88CF06 and SOM-30BA48. Although local seals continued in use, the alnage taxation system ended in 1724 (Egan 1988) and a date range of c.1650-1724 seems likely.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy dandy button dating to the 18th century. The button is circular in plan and both front and reverse faces are flat. The front face is decorated with a curvilinear design around the circumference. The reverse has a circular attachment loop at the centre. Diameter 32 mm. See Bailey (2004, chapter 9) for similar examples.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button. The button is probably a tombac button (copper alloy and zinc), dating to the 18th century. The button is circular in plan. The front face is flat and is decorated with two concentric circles at the centre. The back is domed slightly at the centre where the attachment loop (now missing) would have been positioned. Diameter 26mm. See Bailey (2004, chapter 9) for similar examples.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button. The button is probably a tombac button (copper alloy and zinc), dating to the 18th century. The button is broadly circular in plan. The front is flat and the surface is worn; it is decorated with a series of small circlets around the circumference. The back is domed slightly at the centre where the attachment loop is positioned. Diameter 24mm. See Bailey (2004, chapter 9) for similar examples.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: An incomplete Post Medieval copper alloy button. The button is probably a tombac button (copper alloy and zinc), dating to the 18th century. The button is broadly circular in plan; part of it has broken away ad is missing. The front is flat and undecorated, the back is domed slightly at the centre where the attachment loop (now missing) would have been positioned. Diameter 22mm. See Bailey (2004, chapter 9) for similar examples.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy token of Powell type 7. The token is circular in plan and is undecorated on the reverse. The front is domed or convex; the surface is very worn and there are traces of vertical and horizontal lines forming a criss-cross pattern. Some crude lead tokens of late 17th century date are illustrated in Egan (2005: p170; fig 165). However, as the Devon item did not come from a dateable archaeological context, it can only be given a broad Medieval to Post Medieval date.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy token of Powell type 3. The token is circular in plan and is undecorated on the reverse. The front is domed or convex and has a motif of radiating lines or sunburst pattern; approximately half of this has worn away. A lead token with similar radiating lines, which is dated from AD 1675 to 1700, is illustrated in Egan (2005: p170; number 932). However, as the Devon item did not come from a dateable archaeological context, it can only be given a broad date.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy token of Powell type 3. The token is circular in plan and is flat and undecorated on the reverse. The front is domed or convex and has a motif of radiating lines or sunburst pattern. A lead token with similar radiating lines, which is dated from AD 1675 to 1700, is illustrated in Egan (2005: p170; number 932). However, as the Devon item did not come from a dateable archaeological context, it can only be given a broad date.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy token probably of Powell type 14. The token is circular in plan and is flat and undecorated on the reverse. The front is domed or convex and has a grooved cross motif. A lead token with a cross, which is dated from AD 1675 to 1700, is illustrated in Egan (2005: p170; number 936). However, as the Devon item did not come from a dateable archaeological context, it can only be given a broad date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. One side of the musket ball is flattened, probably as a result of impact, and there are deep irregular grooves on the surface. The item has a mid grey patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 20 mm

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item, which is probably a flattened Post Medieval musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is circular in shape; one of the hemispheres is domed or convex with a circular indentation or crater at the centre. The opposite side has a shallower dome and the surface is pitted. The patina is whitish - grey in colour. The diameter is 22 mm. See DEV-EE0228 for a very similar item.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item, which is probably a flattened Post Medieval musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is circular in shape; one of the hemispheres is domed or convex with a circular indentation or crater at the centre. The opposite side has a shallower dome and the surface is pitted. The patina is whitish - grey in colour. The diameter is 22 mm. See DEV-EE074E for a very similar item.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item, which is probably a flattened Post Medieval musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is circular in shape; one of the hemispheres is domed or convex; the opposite side is flattened and uneven. The domed surface is smooth with deep lacerations which may have been made intentionally to cause further damage; the flattened surface is pitted. The patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter is 23 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item, which is probably a flattened Post Medieval musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is circular in shape; one of the hemispheres is domed or convex; the opposite side is flattened and uneven. The surface is pitted and the patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter is 24 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item, which is possibly a flattened Post Medieval musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800, or possibly a lead alloy weight. The item is circular in shape and both hemispheres are domed or convex. The surface is uneven with some pitting and the patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter is 27 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface is smooth and the patina is whitish- grey in colour. The diameter is c.15 mm

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened and has a concave indentation, probably caused as a result of impacting against a sold surface. The surface is smooth, with some areas of pitting, and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened. The surface is smooth and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 19 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened. The surface is smooth and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is slightly flattened. The surface is very abraided and pitted and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The surface is smooth and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 13 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The surface is smooth and the patina is whitish grey in colour. The diameter is 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball has two semi-circular impressions on one side. The surface is smooth and the patina is mid grey in colour. The diameter is 16 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is very smooth, except for a raised and uneven rough area at one side which may have occured during casting. The surface is smooth and the patina is mid grey in colour. The diameter is 16 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball has two semi-circular deep impressions which have caused the surface to splay outwards. This may have been done deliberately to cause more damage on impact, or may be the result of being pushed down the gun barrel. The patina is mid grey in colour. The diameter is 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is flattened on both sides. The patina is mid grey in colour. The surface is is covered with small linear indentations which have probably been caused by a rodent knawing at the surface after deposition. The diameter is 16 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. One end of the musket ball has a deep indentation, probably caused as a result of impact; the other end has deep linear lacerations radiating from the centre to the outside edges. The surface is pitted and uneven and the the patina is mid grey in colour. The diameter is 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is slightly flattened, probably as a result of impact. There is a sub-circular surface indentation which may be caused by the musket ball being pushed down the gun barrel. The surface is pitted and uneven and the the patina is dark grey in colour. The diameter is 20 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened, probably as a result of impact. The surface is pitted and uneven and the the patina is dark grey in colour. The diameter is 19 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. There is  prominent casting sprue visible on one side of  the musket ball. The surface is smooth and the the patina is white in colour. The diameter is 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened, probably as a result of impact. The surface of the flattened side is pitted and the domed surface on the opposite side is smooth; the patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter is 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is generally spherical in shape; one side is slightly flattened. The surface is smooth with some slight surface indentations. There is a small deep circular identaion on one side which may be a casting fault. The  patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter is 19 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is flattened on one side, probably as a result of impact. The flattened surface is pitted, whilst the domed surface is smoother; the overall patina is mid - grey in colour. The diameter (as flattened) is 22 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is flattened on one side, probably as a result of impact. The surface is generally smooth and the patina is whitish- grey in colour. The diameter (as flattened) is 23 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is squashed and mis-shapen and there is a deep indentation on one side. The surface is pitted and the patina is mid- grey in colour. The diameter is c.18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
