properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is flattened on one side, probably as a result of impacting against a solid surface. The surface is pitted and the patina is mid- grey in colour. The diameter (as flattened) is c.23 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is completely flattened on one side, probably as a result of impacting against a solid surface. The surface is pitted and the patina is mid- grey in colour. The diameter (as flattened) is c.21 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. There are other deep grooves in irregular places around the spherical surface. The surface patina is whitish- grey in colour. The diameter is c.20 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. One sided of the musket ball is slightly flattened, probably as a result of impact. The surface patina is whitish- grey in colour. The diameter is c.16 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface patina is mid- grey in colour with some small white patches. The diameter is c.15 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface patina is mid- grey in colour with some small white patches. The diameter is c.17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from AD 1600 to AD 1800. A casting sprue is visible on one side of the musket ball. The surface patina is very smooth and is pale gray in colour. Diameter 14 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from AD 1600 to AD 1800. One side of the musket ball is very slightly flattened, possibly as a result of impact. The surface patina is very smooth and is whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from AD 1600 to AD 1800. One side of the musket ball is very slightly flattened, possibly as a result of impact. The surface patina is very smooth and is whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from AD 1600 to AD 1800. One side of the musket ball is slightly flattened, probably caused as a result of impact. The surface patina is smooth and is mid gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from AD 1600 to AD 1800. A casting sprue is visible on one side of the item. On the opposite side of the iten is a flattened are, probably caused as a result of impact. The surface patina is slightly pitted, but generally smooth and is whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 15 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating fromAD 1600 to AD 1800. The surface patina is pitted and whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 14 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating fromAD 1600 to AD 1800. The surface patina is smooth and whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating fromAD 1600 to AD 1800. The musket ball is spherical; a slight casting seam is visible around the circumference of the object and evidence of the casting sprue remains. The surface patina is smooth and whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 16 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating fromAD 1600 to AD 1800. The musket ball is spherical; a slight casting seam is visible around the circumference of the object. The surface patina is smooth and whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating fromAD 1600 to AD 1800. The musket ball is spherical; it has lightly flattened areas over the entire surface which may have occured post-depositionally. The surface patina is smooth and whitish- gray in colour. Diameter 17 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. A band of striations runs at a right angle to the strip, possibly caused as a result of travelling down the gun barrel when being fired. One side of the bullet is flattened, probably as a result of impact. The item has a smooth pale gray patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence.Part of the strip is missing on one side of the musket ball. A band of striations runs at a right angle to the strip, possibly caused as a result of travelling down the gun barrel when being fired. The item has a smooth whitish- gray patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 19 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. The item has a pitted surface and a drak gray patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. One side of the musket ball has a large circular indentation which may have been cuased by a tool forcing the bullet into (or out of) the gun barrel. The item has a mid gray patina and a pitted surface. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 20 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. One side of the musket ball is flattened bears a deep laceration. There is a band of striations running at a right angle to the raised strip, which may have been caused by the musket ball being incorrectly loaded and then fired. The item has a mid gray patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 18 mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The item is spherical in shape with a wide raised strip around the circumerence. One side of the musket ball is flattened, probably as a result of impact, and there are deep irregular grooves on the surface. The item has a mid gray patina. This type of ball was used with a two groove rifle and probably dates to the mid 19th century. Diameter: 19 mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy coin. The coin is a halfpenny of George I (AD 1714 - 1727). The coin is very worn; it is probably a second issue halfpenny dating from AD 1719 to 1724; see Spink (2011) number 3660 for similar examples.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy weight of unknown date. The item is circular in plan. The profile is rectangular; both the uppoer and reverse faces are flat. There are no markings, decoration or stamps visible on the item. It measures 40.5 mm in diameter and 5 mm in thickness and weighs 64.57g (2.28 ounces). The weight could date from the Roman to the Post Medieval periods as hand made lead weights of similar have been in use for centuries.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy weight of unknown date. The item is circular in plan. The profile is sub-D shaped; the convex upper face is domed with a flattened top and the reverse face is flat. There are no markings, decoration or stamps visible on the item. It measures 40 mm in diameter and 7 mm in thickness and weighs 74.70g (2.63 ounces). The weight could date from the Roman to the Post Medieval periods as hand made lead weights of similar have been in use for centuries.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Modern 19th century copper alloy penny token for William Cox's iron foundry in Taunton, Somerset.Obverse description: Blacksmith working at an iron forge. Obverse inscription: TAUNTON PENNY TOKEN. Reverse decription: completely worn and illegible: Reverse inscription: [A POUND NOTE FOR 240 TOKENS PAYABLE AT MESSR]S. COX'S * [IRON FOUNDRY] Diameter: 34 mm. Withers No: 1125, Davis Somerset No: 121

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy token of Powell type 2. The item is circular in shape and both front and reverse faces are flat. The front face has a raised border of pellets and a B at the centre. The reverse is plain. The token is bent over and there is a slight fracture at 11 0'clock, which is probably the result of post depositional deamage. Diameter: 26 mm.Lead tokens are hard to date as they were usually produced locally for a wide range of purposes, a broadly Post Medieval date is suggested because of th use of a letter int he design.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A copper alloy livery button of 19th century date. The button is circular in plan with a slighly raised or convex front and concave reverse. The front face has a raised decoration at the centre of a cat (or possibly a leopard or panther or similar) sitting left with a forward facing head; around its neck is a collar with an adjoining chain. The back face is plain; at the centre are the remains of an attachment loop which has broken away and is missing. The surface of the front face has been coated with a white metal such as silver or tin; there are no traces of this surface treatment on the reverse.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The weight, which resembles a trade weight, is circular in plan and has a raised rim on the upper face. The upper face has three sub-circular indentations in a line at the centre; it is not clear whether these marks are intentionally stamped. There are also faint traces of two linear lines of herring bone pattern; one runs from 4 o'clock up to 12 o'clock and the other runs from 7 o'clock to 12o0'clock, where it meets the other herring bone line. A single groove or scratch mark runs across the length of the face, roughly dividing the face in half. The reverse face is flat and has a two sub-circular indentations; there is a scratch mark at the centre which broadly resembles the letter H. It is not clear whether any of the markings are intentional. Diameter: 32 mm; Weight: 23.13g (0.815 ounces).

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy trade weight. The weight is circular in plan and has a raised rim on the upper face. The upper face has a circular indentation, probably for a plug in the centre; no official stamps or markings are visible. The reverse face is flat and plain; at the centre is a raised circular dimple. Diameter: 19mm; Weight: 6.13g (0.216 ounces).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy two-piece rectangular buckle frame.The frame is rectangular in plan with rounded corners on the outer side of the frame; the inside edge of each side has an inward facing curve. At each end of the spindle hole, the curve is decorated with oblique grooves. The frame is drilled at the centre to take a seperate spindle. The spindle and pin are missing.  A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003: 102 no. 654) which is dated from c. AD 1690 to 1720.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval copper alloy D-shaped buckle frame. The front face is raised and decorated with a series of oblique grooves. The back face is flat and undecorated. The pin is missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003: 11 no. 19) which is dated from c. AD 1250 to 1500. Egan and Prichard (2002; 90, no 397) list a buckle frame of similar form, but without the oblique grooved decoration, which is from an archaeological context dated c. AD 1330 to 1380.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post medieval silver hammered coin. The coin is a sixpence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 to 1603). The coin is dated 1596. Key mintmark; Spink (2011) number 2578B.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval copper alloy single loop undecorated buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1300 to 1400. The buckle is D-shaped in plan and has a notched lip at one side, where the pin would have rested. The pin is missing. A broadly similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2002) number 72, p 20.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy two-piece buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1660 to 1720. The buckle is oval in shape and is undecorated. At the centre of the top and bottom of the frame is a hole, which would have held the central spindle in place. The spindle and pin are now missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2002) number 600, p 97.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper alloy terminal knop or finial likely to be from a spoon. The knop is in the form of an acorn. A similar example can be seen in Egan and Prichard (2001:252) number 774, which is dated from AD 1400 to 1450.?

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy buckle frame fragment. The fragment is from a rectangular buckle frame with rounded edges. The front of the frame is decorated with a continuously running single line of circlets; the reverse is plain. The fragment is likely to be from a shoe buckle, dating from c. 1720 to 1790. See Whitehead (2003), number 679, p 106 for a broadly similar form.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. 1600 to 1800. One side is unevenly flattened due to impacting against a hard surface. The diameter is 21mm. The musket ball is grey in colour and the surface is abraided but generally smooth.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. 1600 to 1800. One side is slightly flattened due to impacting against a hard surface. The diameter is 18mm. The musket ball is grey in colour and the surface is abraided but generally smooth.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. 1600 to 1800. One side is flattened due to impacting against a hard surface. There are striations around the centre. The diameter is 20mm. The musket ball is grey in colour and the surface is abraided but generally smooth.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. 1600 to 1800. The two hemispheres of the musket ball are off-centre due to being mis-cast; there is a half-moon indentation visible, which was presumably caused by from a casting tool. The diameter is 16mm. The musket ball is grey in colour and the surface is abraided but generally smooth.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The weight is domed at the top and has a flat base measuring 41mm in diameter. There is a circular hole running from the top to the bottom of the weight.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A heavily corroded copper-alloy Roman sestertius of Commodus (AD 175-192), probably as Caesar under Marcus Aurelius dating to the period c.AD 177-180 (Reece period 8). Uncertain reverse depicting a standing female figure left, possibly Libertas holding pileus and sceptre or similar type. Mint of Rome. For the possible reverse type Cf. BMC p. 675 no. 1684; RIC III p.341 no. 1588.See attached composite image for detail.Diameter: 28.6mm. Thickness: 4.3mm. Weight: 12.7g.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A lead alloy item which is likely to be a Post Medieval musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The musket ball has been squashed flat on one surface, probably as a result impacting against a surface; the opposite face is rounded, creating a C-shaped profile. The musket ball is D-shaped in plan. The patina is whilte- gray in colour.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver hammered coin. The coin is a halfgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 - 1603), without rose or date and has two pellets behind bust. The mint mark is an escallop, which dates the coin from AD 1584 - 1586. Spink number 2579 (2011 edition).

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval gold thimble of 18th century date. The base of the thimble is circular in plan and measures 13.5mm in diameter and has a lip which rolls outwards. The walls of the thimble taper slightly towards the top, where the diameter measures 12mm. The outer surface is covered in small indentations. The very top of the thimble is domed and has a series of small impressions arranged in concentric circles.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Medieval to post-Medieval leg/foot from a cast copper-alloy cooking vessel. The leg is trapezoid in cross-section throughout its length, wider at the front than the back and becomes gradually wider and thicker from the top to the foot. On the front there is a central vertical rib ending in a thick projection at the foot. The base is concave and the top is very irregular and worn. Together with air bubble holes in the back and base this sugegst a crude casting or possible mis-casting. It measures 95.39mm in length, 61.51mm in width, 41.04mm in thickness and weighs 429g.Crudely made cast copper alloy vessels were widely used from c.1200-1700 for serving and cooking. Butler et al (2009:4) suggest there were four main types of leg used. This is a type A which they suggest was widespread in the Medieval period, but examples are known into the early 17th century.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy dupondius, probably of Domitian (AD 81-96) or Trajan (AD 98-117), reverse illegible. Mint of Rome. The apparent legend with GERM above the head suggests Domitian or early Trajan.

properties.title: TOGGLE
properties.description: A post medieval togle or dress fastener dating to the period c. AD 1600 - 1800. The toggle is pointed oval in shape with a circular cross-section. It has a cylindrical shank projecting from one side which terminates in teo circular loops positioned side-by-side.It measures 25.87mm in length, 22.32mm maximum width, 3.37mm minimum width, 8.03mm maximum thickness, 2.67mm minimum thickness and weighs 8.07g.This object is one of a group of artefacts which were originally identified by Ralph Jackson and Sally Worrell as cosmetic pestles, dating from the late Iron Age or early Roman period, AD 100 - 200. However, there is a growing body of evidence to suggest that at least some of these items are in fact clothing fasteners; toggles similar to those on a duffle coat. The date of these toggles is still unknown as none have been found in dated contexts.See Jackson (2010: 6) who discusses this form of object. Comparable examples illustrated in this publication are nos. 513 & 593.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A Post Medieval gold mourning finger-ring, dating from c. AD 1660 - 1720. The ring has a D-shaped section and is plain on the exterior. The interior is engraved with the inscription: 'Blessed are the ded which die [in] the Lorde'. The inscription is taken from the Book of Revelation, chapter 14; verse 13. Some of the original black enamel remains.In the absence of an identifiable maker's mark it is hard to be absolutely certain about the date as this is a type which runs from the mid-17th century into the early decades of the 18th century. However, the use of a moralising Biblical inscription and the lettering style suggest a date in the 17th or very early 18th century, and therefore the balance of probability indicates a date pre-1716.Finger rings of similar form have been attributed 17th century dates, for example: 2007 T5 (GLO-EF2971); 2007 T333 (GLO- 195C52) (TAR 2007 p151 &p 396).Dimensions: Diameter: 19mm; Thickness:1.5mm; Width: 4mm; Weight: 4g

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy trough for cage birds, often referred to as a 'bird feeder'. The item is D-shaped in section, being flat at the back and rounded at the front of the vessel. The sides gently taper downwards to the base. The front is decorated with two horizontal moulded lines. Egan (2005) lists four examples of birdcage troughs which were for 'holding water, green plants or seed for cage birds'. According to Egan, earlier 15th to 16th century troughs are decorated whilst plainer examples continue until the late 17th century. As this item has little decoration, it is more likely to be of a mid to late 17th century date.

properties.title: POWDER MEASURE
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy powder measure dating from c. AD 1600 to 1700. The powder measure is now squashed and mis-shapen, however it would have originally had a cup-like appearance, having a closed circular base with straight sides and being open at the top. Towards the base are the remains of two semi-circular attachment loops at opposite sides to each other. The powder measure would have been attached to a belt (bandolier) via a cord through these loops.

properties.title: POWDER MEASURE
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy powder measure dating from c. AD 1600 to 1700. The powder measure is now squashed and mis-shapen, however it would have originally had a cup-like appearance, having a closed circular base with straight sides and being open at the top. Towards the base are the remains of two semi-circular attachment loops at opposite sides to each other. The powder measure would have been attached to a belt (bandolier) via a cord through these loops.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Modern silver halfcrown of George V (AD 1910 to 1936), dating to 1929. Spink (2011) number 4037. Added as part of assemblage.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Modern silver sixpence of George V (AD 1910 to 1936), dating to 1935. Spink (2011) number 4041. Added as part of an assemblage.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Modern silver threepence of George V (AD 1910 to 1936), dating to 1919. Spink (2011) number 4015 or 4016. Added as part of assemblage.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Modern silver shilling of George V (AD 1910 to 1936), dating to 1921. Spink (2011) number 4023. Added as part of assemblage/local history project.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy livery button. The button is circular in plan; the front face is slightly concave, the backface is convex and has a circular attachment loop at the centre. The front face has a square topped shield with an animal's head (possibly a lion) facing left, above. The shield is divided into half from top to bottom. The left half of the shield has two diagonal lines, within which are three stars.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy tombac button. The button is octagonal in plan; the front face is decorated with a rose motif. The back face is slightly raised at the centre where there are the remains of an attachment loop. A similar button can be seen in Bailey (2004), p 53, figure 9.106, which is dated to the 18th century.

properties.title: DAGGER
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper alloy sword or dagger pommel. The pommel is circular in plan with rectanguar section and rounded sides. The front and backface both have sixteen grooves emanating from the centre outwards to the outer circumference. There are the remains of an iron dagger tang in the aperture at the centre on both faces. The patina is mid green and the surface is abraided . A similar item, which is dated from c.AD 1450 to AD 1700, can be seen on the database at: WMID-7E94F2.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy weight likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The weight is disc-shaped and is circular in plan; both faces are flat. The upper face has a raised curvilinear decoration (possibly some of it is lettering) around the outer edge of the circumference. The lower face is plain. The weight weighs 1.3 ounces.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy object; possibly a weight and likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The object is circular in plan and is dish-shaped. One face is convex, whilst the other face is concave, creating a C-shaped profile. There are no markings, stamps, or decoration visible on the object. The object weighs 2.9 ounces.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy disc; probably a weight and likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The object is circular in plan with a shallow D shaped profile; one face is flat and one face is convex. There are no markings, stamps, or decoration visible on the disc. The object may be a lead weight, possibly for used as a curtain or dress weight. The object weighs 1.6 ounces.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy disc; probably a weight and likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The object is roughly oval in plan and has two flat faces. There are no markings, stamps, or decoration visible on the disc. The object may be a lead weight, possibly for used as a curtain or dress weight. The object weighs 0.9 ounces.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy disc; probably a weight and likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The object is roughly circular in plan and has two flat faces. There are no markings, stamps, or decoration visible on the disc. The object may be a lead weight, possibly for used as a curtain weight. The object weighs 2.6 ounces.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead alloy disc; probably a weight and likely to date to the Post Medieval period. The object is roughly circular in plan and has two flat faces. There are no markings, stamps, or decoration visible on the disc. The object may be a lead weight, possibly for used as a curtain or dress weight. The object weighs 1 ounce.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A lead weight of unknown date. The weight is conical in shape, having a cicular base and sides which taper to a point at the apex. There is a circular perforation running throughout the weight from top to bottom. The weight weighs 10.4 ounces.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver hammered sixpence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 to 1603). The coin is dated 1578. Fifth issue; Greek cross mint mark; Spink (2011) number 2572.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy asymmetrical buckle, dating from c. AD 1575 to AD 1700. The buckle frame has one rounded end and one rectangular end, with an integral strap bar at the centre. The rounded end has a lobe at the centre of the inner edge. There is a slight notch on the inner edge of the rectangular side, probably for a pin rest. The pin is missing.A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 91, number 599.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy trapezoidal buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1620 to AD 1680. The frame has knops at each corner and a point at the centre of both short sides. There is a small knop at either end of the integral strap bar. The recurving hook of the pin remains intact, wrapped around the strap bar; the point of the pin has broken away and is missing. Part of one of the loops of the frame is also missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 84, number 523.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy trapezoidal shoe or knee buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1660 to AD 1720. The frame has moulded grooves at either end of the spindle and a lobe on the inner edge of either side of the spindle hole.The back is plain. The iron chape (now corroded) survives around the spindle. There are traces of silvering or tinning on the surface. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 99, number 616.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy trapezoidal shoe or knee buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1660 to AD 1720. The frame has raised moulded scroll decoration at either end of the spindle, a pin rest at one side of the spindle, and a single groove running around the outer edge of the frame. The back is plain and there are traces of file marks. The spindle and chape are missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 98, number 610.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.AD 1800. One hemisphere is completely flattened, probably caused as a result of impacting against a surface. The other hemisphere remains rounded. The surface patina is generally smooth and is mid- gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.AD 1800. The musket ball is banded around the circumference with striations at right angles to the banding, probably caused as a result of travelling down the gun barrel. The surface patina is smooth and is whitish- gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.AD 1800. The surface patina is slightly pitted and is dark gray in colour. Diameter 14mm.

properties.title: BULLET
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern lead alloy single belted bullet with wide raised strip around the circumference, probably dating to the 19th century. This type of bullet was used in a two groove barrel. The ball is slightly mis-shapen; probably as a result of impacting against a solid surface. The patina is pale gray in colour. Diameter 19.20mm.

properties.title: BULLET

properties.title: MUSKET BALL

The surface is generally snooth and the item is whitish-gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL

The surface has striations and indentations and the item is mid gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern small calibre lead alloy spherical bullet 'shot' or 'hail shot' measuring 14.35mm in diameter. Traces of banding with striations at 90 degree angles are visible on the circumference and one end of the item is indented and mis-shapen, probably as a result of impacting against a solid surface. The surface patina is generally smooth and is white in colour.

Slight traces of a casting seam can be seen around the circumference and the item is flattened on one side, probably as a result of impacting against a solid surface. The surface patina is very smooth and is white in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to AD 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened, probably as a result of impacting upon a solid surface. The surface is very smooth and is white in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to AD 1800. There are several deep sub-oval and sub-circular indentations on the surface of the item. This may be due to improper casting, or could be tool marks. The surface has a pale gray patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to AD 1800. The surface is evenly burred and pitted and is pale gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to AD 1800. The surface patina is very smooth and is white in colour.

Otherwise, surface patina is mainly smooth with some pitting and is whitish gray in colour.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy mount. The mount has a central lobe, which is partly broken and missing on one side, and a slightly raised linear moulding at each end. The reverse is plain with two integral lugs or spikes for attachment. The mount probably dates from AD 1600 - 1700.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver seal matrix of seventeenth to eighteenth century date. See Treasure report excerpts below for details.Description: A silver seal matrix with engraved oval die. The base of the handle is octagonal in section; the rest of the handle is broken away and is missing. The face of the oval die is somewhat worn and the engraving is not clear in some places. At the bottom is a square topped shield; within the shield is an engraving of a double-headed eagle with open wings. Above the shield is an engraving of what appears to be a helm, above which is a fist clenching a bird's leg. The shield is bordered by an ornate foliate design on both sides of the shield. An oval beaded border surrounds the whole design.Dimensions: Die length: 19.5 mm; Die width: 17 mm; Overall height: 8mm weight: 4.08g.Discussion:  The arms on the face of the matrix may be those of the Worth family: 'Argent an eagle displayed with two necks sable beaked and legged gules', the crest 'an arm erect vested argent gloved ermines, holding an eagle's leg couped at the thigh or' (Burke, 1136).A similar silver seal matrix from Devon, dated to the late seventeenth century, with a similar overall form (but different die engraving) can be seen on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database: DEV-A0F834 (2014 T334).Conclusion: Due to its age and precious metal content, this item would qualify as treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy halfpenny of George II (AD 1727 - 1760). The coin is worn. Probably young laureate and cuirassed bust type, dating from AD 1729 - 1739.  For a similar example, see Spink (2011) p 403, number 3717.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: An unknown item of uncertain date; possibly a Post Medieval cauldron leg, or perhaps a lead weight. The object is made of lead alloy and is cylindrical in shape with a circular section. At one end it tapers to a rounded point; at the other end the item is flat. Given the shape and appearance of the object, there is a possibility that the item was used as a 'make-shift' replacement cauldron or skillet leg. However, the item could also be a handmade lead weight or similar.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy book clasp. The clasp is roughly rectangular in plan; it tapers at the hook end and splays outwards at the opposite end. The sides and the splayed end are scalloped for decoration. The hook end is missing the integral recurving hook due to a break. The front of the object, now worn, is decorated with slight traces of a running criss-cross pattern across the entire surface, creating diamond shapes. Each diamond appears to be bordered by a single row of pellets. However, the pattern is now difficult to discern. At the splayed end is a stamped ring and dot pattern. The back face is plain and undecorated; there appear to be two small circles, which may be the traces of integral rivets, now broken away and missing. The clasp probably dates from 15th to 17th centuries. A broadly similar example: YORYM-6F00B9, can be seen on the PAS database.

properties.title: NAIL
properties.description: A substantial copper alloy nail of unknown date. The head of the nail is oval in plan and is slightly domed; the shank has four sides which taper towards a point. The point is slightly bent over and the head is slightly mis-shapen which has probably occured due to use or after deposition. Dimensions: Overall Length: 54mm; Length of head: 30mm; Width of head: 23mm; Thickness of head: 3mm; Width of shank:8.5mm Thickness of shank: 6.5mm; Weight: 22g.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A possible Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy item which is possibly a weight or an extremely flattened musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The item is eliptical in profile; and both faces are rounded. Dimemsions: Diameter: 23mm; Weight:26.70g.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A possible Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The item is circular in plan with smooth domed surface on one face. The sides slightly taper inwards to the opposite face and project beyond the flat surface to form a lip or a dish. There are no stamps or markings visible on the surface. Dimensions: 46g; Diameter: 26mm; Height: 13mm.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A possible lead alloy weight, dating from the Roman to Modern periods. The item is broadly circular in plan with a flat face at the bottom and slightly convex raised surface on the top face. The iten is very abraided. Dimensions: 22.38g; Width: 25.5mm; Length: 24.5mm; Thickness: 7.02mm.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy weight, weighing 1 and a half ounces. The weight is disc-shaped; it is circular in plan with a flat face at the top and bottom. The top face has a raised design at the centre, which is now not possible to ascertain due to the object being worn. The lower face has letters scratched into it; it is not possible to read them due to wear the letter O (or number 0) is still visible. The weight probably dates from c. AD 1600 to 1800.

properties.title: TOBACCO HOLDER
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy knop from the lid of a tobacco holder. The knop is circular in overall shape and has six raised knops around the outer edge; at the centre is a six-petalled flower with a circle at the centre. The back is flat and undecorated and there are traces of an integral rivet for attachment to the lid.The item probably dates from AD 1600 to 1800.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy pistol shot dating from c AD 1600 to 1800. There item is spherical in overall shape and there is a sub-circular indentation at one side which may have been caused by the musket ball being pushed down the gun barrel with an implement. The patina is whitish-grey in colour.

properties.title: BULLET
properties.description: A post medieval lead alloy domed bullet dating from c AD 1600 to 1800. The item is flat at one end and rounded at the other. The centre of the bullet has striations, caused when travelling along the gun barrel. The patina is mid-grey in colour.

properties.title: HARNESS MOUNT
properties.description: An incomplete Post Medieval copper alloy openwork bridle boss, or horse harness mount. Part of the mount has broken away and is missing; around 60 percent of the object remains.The mount is circular in shape overall and it is domed with a central raised circular knop at the centre. Surrounding the knop are three openwork designs in the form of petals (presumably there was a fourth design in the missing section). Surrounding the openwork petals, a moulded scrolling design runs along each side of the petal towards the outer circumference and recurves inwards.Further towards the outer circumference are two sub-oval openwork shapes (presumably there were another two on the other side). There are the remains of two knops on the outer edge of the circumference. The underside is undecorated and there are no means of attachment visible on the object. The mount probably dates from AD 1600 to 1800. Dimensions: Diameter: 45mm; Height 14mm.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy cauldron, posnet or skillet leg. The leg is D-shaped in section; it is curved at the front and flat at the back. The top of the item swells out to its widest point about at third of a way down the object; the item them tapers towards the foot to a rounded point. The item s worn and abraided; it is likely to date to the 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy oval buckle frame with integral central bar.The buckle frame is undecorated and the pin is missing. This style of buckle dates from c. AD 1650 to 1720. See Whitehead (1996), p48, number 278 for a similar example. Dimemsions: Length:26. mm; Width: 20.5mm.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy rectangular buckle frame with integral central bar.The buckle frame is decorated with two linear grooves running parallel around both sides and ends of the frame, with decorative grooved diagonal lines in between the two grooves. The pin is missing and part of the frame has broken away, although still present. Dimensions: Length:42 mm; Width: 40mm.This style of buckle dates from c. AD 1600 to 1700. See Whitehead (1996), p78, number 479 for a similar example. There are examples from contexts of c. 1350-c. 1450 in London (Egan and Pritchard 1991, nos. 447 and 450), but also one from a context of c. 1550-1590 in Moulsham Street, Chelmsford (Goodall in Cunningham and Drury 1985, 43, fig. 26, no. 10; see p. 17 for calendar dates).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy double looped buckle frame with intact pin wrapped around the integral central bar. The frame has a moulded knop at either end of the central bar. This style of  buckle dates from c. AD 1500 to 1650. See Whitehead (1996) , p 54, number 307 for a similar example.

properties.title: BARBED AND TANGED ARROWHEAD
properties.description: Knapped flint barbed and tanged arrowhead dating from the Late Neolithic to Early Bronze Age (c. 2700 BC - c.1600 BC). The arrowhead is bifacially worked and sub-triangular in plan with slightly convex sides and a small chip at the point. There are two round ended notches in the base, flanking the central tang with a barb at either side. The tang is wider and longer than the barbs and has a rounded end. One barb has lost it's tip, the other is complete with angled ends coming to a point at the base (obliquely shaped). The arrowhead has semi-invasive semi-abrupt parallel retouch down both edges and across the point on both sides, with an unretouched area in the centre of both sides. The flint is pale grey with some medium grey areas. It is 33.2mm long, 24.0mm wide and 4.5mm thick; it weighs 3.42 grams.

properties.title: PATTEN
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern iron shoe patten, probably dating from AD 1720 onwards. The patten is oval in plan and has an integral projection one long end which rises upwards and spans outwards at 90 degrees. There would have been a second projection at the other long end, which is now missing. The object is squashed on one side and the whole object is badly corroded. The patten would also have had a wooden platform which is now missing. In some remote and rural areas, pattens were in use until the 20th century.Goodall, I (1973:63) comments that the single and double riveted raised terminals were characteristic of pattens. The "rivets passed through a wooden patten or sole. Shoes were secured by straps to these pattens, which raised the wearers' feet above dirt and mud. Pattens with iron rings were used during and after the 17th century, the earliest known reference is 1625, and the type with the crinkled edge is thought to be superseded by the plain oval hoop by c.1720." (ibid).

properties.title: PATTEN
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern iron shoe patten, probably dating from AD1720 onwards. The patten is oval in plan and has an integral projection at each long end with both projections rising upwards and spanning outwards at 90 degrees. The projections are now diminished and the whole object is badly damaged due to corrosion.The patten would also have had a wooden platform which is now missing. In some remote and rural areas, pattens were in use until the 20th century.Goodall, I (1973:63) comments that the single and double riveted raised terminals were characteristic of pattens. The "rivets passed through a wooden patten or sole. Shoes were secured by straps to these pattens, which raised the wearers' feet above dirt and mud. Pattens with iron rings were used during and after the 17th century, the earliest known reference is 1625, and the type with the crinkled edge is thought to be superseded by the plain oval hoop by c.1720." (ibid).

properties.title: HOARD

properties.title: HOARD
properties.description: Robertson 2000, 107-108 no. 483:"26 Sept. 1717"Last night Dr. Walkercalled upon me, and amongst other Discourse, told me that there have been dug up at Exeter, not long agoe, about half a Bushell of Roman Coyns, most silver, from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus. He gave me one of them, a very fair one of Trajanus Decius, with DACIA on it. He says most of them are fair. He says Mr. Reynolds, who is schoolmaster of Exeter, and hath them, designs them for the University."-T. Hearne's Collections, in Oxford Hist. Soc. Publ., XLIII (1902), 93Other brief references to the hoard by Hearne suggest that it was found in 1716.W. Stukeley, Itin, Cur. (1724), 151, described the find thus:"A pot of Roman coyn of two pecks was dug up two years agoe [sic], near St. Martin's Church. I saw some of them in Dr. Musgrave's possession, of Gordian, Balbinus, Philippus, Julia Maesa, Geta, Gallienus, and the like. Mr. Loudham, surgeon in this city, has many of them amongst his curious collection of antiquitys, MSS. etc. Mr. Reynolds the schoolmaster is a great collector and preserver of such learned remains."Dr. J.G. Milne, in NC, 1948, 219-23, discussed the above references, and also the entries of gifts of coins from the hoard in the Benefactors' Book of Corpus Christi College, Oxford. These coins, 17 in number, are in Ashmolean Museum, Oxford.Dr. Milne pointed out that W.T.P. Shortt, Sylva Antiqua Iscana (1840), vi, "stated that Reynolds' coins were in the possession of the Dean and Chapter of Exeter. They are still in the Cathedral Library, and with them there is an account of the find and a list of the coins by Mr. Reynolds which accompanied his gift..The character of the find can be determined with much probability from this detailed story. The flooring of chalk and sand, apparently some three feet below the modern surface, and with two later floors over it, can be taken as certainly Roman; and as the coins were buried two feet below this in a leaden urn, they appear to have formed a concealment hoard.If the Corpus coins and the single pieces shown to Hearne are added to the list given by Reynolds, the total of identified specimens is as follows:"Claudius I 1 (b.)Trajan 1Severus 5Julia Domna 2Caracalla 2Geta 2Elagabalus 7Julia Paula 1Julia Soaemias 1Julia Maesa 2Severus Alexander 7Julia Mamaea 2Maximinus 2Gordian I 1Gordian III 20Philip I 13Otacilia 2Philip II 2Trajan Decius 7Etruscilla 1Herennius 4Hostilian 1Treb. Gallus 8Volusian 6Aemilian 1Valerian I 9Mariniana 2Gallienus 98Salonina 6Valerian II 2Saloninus 3Postumus 21242"The coins given to the Dean and Chapter by Reynolds were probably selected specimens: there are no duplicates in his list. So the preponderance of coins of Gallienus and Postumus would probably be even more marked than appears in the figures above, which, if the statement that the urn contained about half a bushel is correct, would not cover a tenth of the whole."N. Shiel, in P.T. Bidwell, The Legionary Bath-house and Basilica and Forum at Exeter, (1979), 167-79, reviewed the earlier accounts, which led him to date the discovery to 1715. He also listed 87 ant. in Rougemont House Museum (now Royal Albert Memorial Museum), Exeter, 207 den. and ant. in Exeter Cathedral Library, and 16 ant. in Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, with types, sizes, and die axes, and gave reasons for the belief that these came from the Exeter, 1715/6 hoard:Den. Ant. TOTALCathedral Exeter Mus. Cathedral Ashmolean Trajan 1 1Severus 5 5Julia Domna (under Severus) 1 1Caracalla (under Severus) 2 2Geta 2 2Elagabalus 5 1 6Julia Paula 1 1Julia Soaemias 1 1Julia Maesa 2 2Severus Alexander 6 6Julia Mamaea 2 2Maximinus 2 2Gordian III 4 16 4 24Philip I 4 9 2 15Otacilia 3 1 4Philip II 2 1 1 4Trajan Decius 1 5 6Etruscilla 1 1Herennius 2 2 1 5Hostilian 1 1Treb. Gallus 5 7 1 13Volusian 5 5 1 11Aemilian 1 1Valerian I 12 10 22Mariniana 1 1Gallienus (joint reign) 6 4 1 11Gallienus (sole reign) 19 86 2 107Salonina (joint reign) 2 1 3Salonina (sole reign) 7 2 1 10Valerian II 3 2 5Saloninus 1 1 2Postumus 13 20 3330 87 177 16 310(den.)(1 deified)In addition, there were 1 Claudian AE (copy) in Exeter Cathedral Library, and another in the Ashmolean Museum, said to have come from this hoard.The total no. of coins listed was summarised by N. Shiel, op. cit., 169 and appeared to come to 312, instead of 310, with 109 instead of 107 ant. attributed to Gallienus. However, the detailed lists seem to come to only 310. Again, the coins in Exeter (Museum and Cathedral) were given running nos. which go up to 295, but there is no no. C151, which reduces the total in Exeter to 294.Examined, 84 ant. only in Exeter Mus., 109 in Cathedral Library, 1978 (ASR)There appeared to be minor differences between the lists of N. Shiel and ASR."

properties.title: HOARD
properties.description: Robertson 2000, 139-140 no. 616:"The hoard "was found in 1977 scattered over a small area of a site in Rack Street. It consists of six legitimate pieces together with nineteen or possibly twenty copies, the uncertainty being caused by the fragmentary nature of a few coins. The latest legitimate coins are those of the Tetrici and none of the copies appears to be based on anything later than this. The majority of the coins show no signs of very much circulation. Several of the flans are chipped but there are no pieces of very small module. These factors, together with the absence of any copies based on Claudian commemorative issues, combine to suggest that the copies were produced in the early 270's and the hoard deposited not long afterwards..There are no die links between any of the copies."The coins, all ant., were:Ant.Gallienus (sole reign?) 1Victorinus 4(2 b.)Claudius II 1Tetricus I and II 10uncertain radiates 3frag.s 5204or 11 (9 or 10 b.)or 4 (b.)or 6 (b.)+ 5 or 6 frags.-N. Shiel, in Proc. Devon Arch. Soc., 36 (1978), 256-8, types, wts., sizes, die axes20 coins + 5 or 6 frags. in Exeter MuseumExamined, 1978 (ASR)"

properties.title: HOARD
properties.description: Fused lump of 10+ base metal coins. The hoard is a fused in a lump which has been squashed as if extruded through a narrow gap. Perhaps the result of concealment in a building which has subsequently burnt down. None of the uncertain number of coins can be identified but they are of the size of debased radiates or Constantinian nummi. Weight = 80.05g and max length = 75mm.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2012 T848Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-4E4BE6

properties.title: HOARD
properties.description: Robertson 2000, 11 no. 52:""The hoard was discovered in a sealed demolition deposit during the excavation of some timber buildings in the area outside the south gate, that is to say outside the limits of the legionary fortress. The buildings appear to have been used as stores or workshops and were not barrack blocks..The circumstances of discovery suggest a temporary concealment above ground was the intention of the depositor, perhaps in a wall or ceiling. The context is a demolition layer which indicates that demolition must have been going on at some time after 73 in this area. As the majority of the coins are little worn, and as the group has the appearance of having been deposited no great time after the date of the latest issue it would appear that there was demolition work taking place in the mid seventies. This squares very well with the evidence of coin finds from Exeter as a whole which shows a marked gap in the money supply at this period such as would be concomitant with a military withdrawal in the mid seventies."There were 2 sest., 6 dup. and 3 Asses:Sest. Dup. AssesClaudius 2 (copies)Nero 1Vespasian 2 62 6 3N. Shiel, in Proc. Devon Arch. Soc., 36 (1978), 256-8, and Ms. notes, 1978, types, wts., sizes, die axes; cp. N. Shiel, in CH V (1979), 48, no. 112, omitting As of Nero11 coins in Royal Albert Memorial Museum, ExeterExamined, 1978 (ASR)The As of Nero, and 5 of the 6 dup. of Vespasian, were minted at Lyons, the latter in AD 72-3."

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy asymmetrical mount, dating to the 17th century. The reverse has the remains of two integral lugs at the back for attachment.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Victorian teaching coin, dating from c. AD 1843. The obverse of the coin bears the uncrowned head left of Prince Albert (later Edward VII, AD 1901 - 1910) and reads 'HRH ALBERT P.W.' The reverse reads: '12 PENCE MAKE 1 SHILLINNG'. The coins were produced in sets of 10 denominations and were used for teaching pupils to reckon with currency.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A  post-medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The item is broadly rectangular in plan with one end tapering to a trefoil terminal. The other end appears to have broken away and is missing. The sides are scalloped. The front face of the object is decorated in an eloborate scrolling foliate design and there are traces of gilding visible on the surface. At the terminal end is a single circular rivet hole. The back face is plain and there are the remains of two integral rivets facing inwards towards each other.

properties.title: BLADE
properties.description: A Neolithic flint flake. The flake is broadly leaf-shaped in plan and has an eliptical section. Both ends have snapped away. The dorsal side shows traces of blade removal scars; the ventral side has ripples from the bulb of percussion. There are signs of retouching along the edges. The flint is dark brown in colour with grey mottles.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is flattened on one side, probably as a result of impact. The surface is heavily pitted and the patina is a dark grey colour. Diameter: 24mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medievial lead alloy fragment; possibly a mis-cast musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The item is D-shaped in section and is comma-shaped in plan. One face has the appearance of one hemisphere of a musket ball; the opposite face is slightly concave at the centre. The surface is smooth and has a whitish-grey patina.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Post Medieval ceramic handle an rim fragment from a North Devon or South Somerset ware jug. The handle is abraided; there are slight traces of a green-brown glaze on the interior of the rim.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper alloy single looped D-shaped buckle frame dating from c. AD 1250 - 1650. There are no traces of decoration on the frame and the pin is missing. The curved part of the frame is thinner than the straight side in some places, suggesting use or wear.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy sub-rectangular small shoe or knee buckle frame with drilled holes to take a seperate spindle, dating from c. AD 1690- 1720. The spindle and pin are missing. The buckle is curved and has a C-shaped profile.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy sub-rectangular shoe or knee buckle frame with drilled holes to take a seperate spindle, dating from c. AD 1720- 1790. The spindle and pin are missing.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy cauldron leg. The leg is D-shaped in section. The outer face has three ribs; the back face is flat and plain. Length: 57mm; Width: 46mm; Thickness: 25mm.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy cauldron or skillet leg. The leg has four faces and is rectangular in section. In plan, the cauldron leg is rectangular, tapering slightly towards the foot. The foot projects outwards at an angle. Length: 85mm; Width: 15mm; Thickness: 10mm.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy pistol shot, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The pistol shot is spherical in shape, one side is flattened slightly due to impact against a hard surface. The patina is a mid-grey colour.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy pistol shot, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The pistol shot is spherical in shape, one side is flattened slightly due to impact against a hard surface. The patina is a mid-grey colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. One side of the musket ball is flattened as a result of impact; the other hemisphere has not been damaged and has remained smooth. The patina is a whitish-grey colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL

The musket ball may have been mis-cast during the casting process, or possibly the irregularity occured as a result of impact. The patina is a mid-grey colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The surface is smooth with occasional lacerations and the patina is a mid-grey colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The surface is smooth with occasional lacerations and the patina is a whitish-grey colour.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: An incomplete copper-alloy single-loop buckle of Medieval date.Only the inner end of the frame remains, its top and bottom sides diverging towards the missing outer end. The plate has been folded double around the axis bar; it is sub-rectangular in plan and has a transverse pin slot adjacent to the frame's axis bar. A copper-alloy rivet with hemispherical head is situated at the non-frame end and holds the two sides of the plate together. No trace remains of the pin, and the buckle is heavily corroded.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy sextfoil triple rose mount. The front face of the mount is decorated in the form of a triple rose. The reverse is plain and has three integral lugs; one at the centre and two at opposite ends. The central lug and an end lug are bent inwards towards each other; the other end lug has broken away.

properties.title: SUNDIAL
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy pocket sundial. No further details recorded.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy cloth seal. The seal consists of two circular discs with a connecting tab. The seal is folded over so that the two discs meet. Traces of an off-centre stamp remain on the outer face of one disc; possibly the letter 'P' with a 'C' below to the right with a cross within the recess of the 'C'. The other disc is blank. The cloth seal probably dates to the 18th century.

properties.title: APOTHECARY WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy apothecary's weight. The weight is square in plan and rectangular in section and is engraved on both sides with the traditional symbol for the apothecary's unit of measure 1 drachms. The weight probably dates to the 17th century. Length: 15mm; Width: 13mm; Thickness:2mm; Weight: 3.68g

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval 1 ounce trade weight of Charles I (AD 1625 - 1649) or Charles II (AD 1660 - 1685). The weight has a raised rim on the upper side and sligthly flared sides. It bears three official marks, the ewer for the Founders Company who approved them, the sword for the Guildhall of London, and a crowned letter C. Diameter: 33mm, Thickness: 4mm, Weight: 26.86g (0.947 ounces).

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy asymmetrical mount. The item is undecorated and there are no signs of gilding. At the back of the item are two outward facing lugs for attachment. The mount probably dates from c. AD 1600- 1700.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy pistol shot, measuring c. 9mm in diameter. The surface is generally smooth, except for one deep notch. The item has a light grey patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The surface is burred and has a mid-grey patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The musket ball is flattened on one side, caused by the object impacting against a hard surface. The surface is generally smooth and has a whitish-grey patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The surface is generally smooth and has a whitish-grey patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball. The musket ball has two semi circular impressions caused by cutting the sprue off with nippers. The surface is generally smooth and has a whitish-grey patina.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The weight is conical in shape with a circular perforation at the top for suspension. The base is circular and has a circular indentation at the centre.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The overall shape of the object is teardrop-shaped. There are traces of an iron suspension loop at the top.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval lead alloy weight. The weight is conical in shape with domed top. The base is circular and has a circular indentation at the centre.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy coin, possibly a halfpenny of William III (AD 1694 - 1702). See Spink (2011) page 371, number 3554. The coin is extremely worn, therefore it is not possible to identify further. Diamer 29mm, thickness 2mm.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy coin, possibly a halfpenny of George I (AD 1714 - 1727) or George II (AD 1727 - 1760). The coin is extremely worn, therefore it is not possible to identify further.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver hammered coin. The coin is a halfgroat of Charles I (AD 1625 - 1649). The coin has been clipped around the circumference slightly and the surface is worn; the coin is also pierced. The Sun initial mark dates the coin from AD 1645 - 1646. See Spink (2011) page 283, number 2836 for a similar example.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver hammered coin, The coin is a sixpence of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 - 1603). The coin has been clipped around the circumference and the surface is worn and pitted. The coin is dated to AD 1578.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver hammered coin, The coin is a halfgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 - 1603). The coin has been clipped around the circumference.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Silver Roman Republican Denarius of the moneyer M. Volteius. Mint of Rome, 78 BCObv. Laureate head of Jupiter rightRev. [M.VOLTEI.M.F]; Capitoline Temple of Jupiter Optimus MaximusRRC p. 399, no. 385/1. Reece Period 1

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A medieval gold finger-ring, with a raised octagonal fluted bezel set with an oval turquoise. The slender hoop is D-shaped, and slightly distorted. The ring probably dates to the 14th century.Non-destructive X-ray fluorescence analysis of the ring at the British Museum indicates a gold content of approximately 83%. The stone has been identified by Raman Microscopy as turquoise. The ring weighs 2.23 grams.The form of this ring is unusual. The closest comparable example is a ring in the British Museum with a hexagonal bezel set with an emerald, but on this ring the bezel is bevelled on the lower edge (O M Dalton, Catalogue of Finger-Rings in the British Museum (London 1912), no 1769.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: An incomplete Medieval to Post Medieval cast copper alloy cauldron leg, dating to between AD 1200 and AD 1800. The leg has an old break, and is D shaped in cross-section. The foot has a smooth, rounded design below a bulbous collar. The reverse side is flat and plain. The surface is worn and abraded, of a pale olive colour with areas of green patina and traces of black residue or lacquer. A similar item is published by Brian Read, History Beneath Our Feet (1995), page 95, No. 591.Length: 38.41mm. Width: 25.26mm. Thickness: 16.48mm. Weight: 47.28g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post-medieval gold crown of Charles I (AD1625 - AD1649), mint mark; Crown; Tower mint, under Charles I (1635-1636).Obverse description: Group D fourth bust facing left with value mark V behind.Obverse inscription: CAROLVS.D:G.MA:BR:FR.[ET]HI:REX (Charles by the Grace of God King of Great Britain, France and Ireland).Reverse description: Garnished oval royal shield dividing crowned C R at sides.Reverse inscription: CVLTOR [SVI] DEVS.PRO.TEGIT (God protects His worshipers).References: Spink 2715, North 2185.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is an as or dupondius of first or second century date. Both faces of the coin are very worn. The patina is dark green andt the surface is pitted. 28mm diameter; weight:11.46g.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern copper alloy mount in the form of the Roman god Mercury. The forward facing head of Mercury is designed in the classical style with long flowing locks of hair cascading around the face. The eyes are lenticular with realistic eyelids and eyebrows above. The nose is straight, flaring out slightly towards the nostrils. The lips are slightly parted. The chin is slightly rounded; the neck is not represented. At tthe bottom of the mount is a bow, possibly representing a cloak usually tied at the neck. At the top of the head are a pair of wings, one on each side. Wings are often used to represent the god Mercury. The back is hollow and there are the remains of three integral rivets for attachment; one each side of the head near the wings, and one at the centre of the base. it is highly likely that the mount is Victorian, despite the mount repersenting a Roman god.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper-alloy mount. In plan, the mount is shaped in a trefoil design with a small knop at the top and a stem with two small leaves at each side below. Both faces ar flat and undecorated. There are no visible traces of integral rivets, rivet holes or other means of attachment. The mount probably dates to the 16th century.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: An incomplete Post-Medieval copper alloy spoon, probably dating to the late 17th or 18th century. The surviving fragment comprises of the end of the spoon's handle. This is broadly piriform in shape, tapering from 12.9mm wide at its rounded shoulders to 4.1mm, where it terminates in a worn break. In profile the top edge of one face of the handle thickens pronouncedly above the widest point of the shoulders, from 1.4mm to 3.8mm, creating a lip with a concave curve below it. The spoon terminates in an elaborated knob, comprising of a large central section, 6.1mm in diameter and hexagonal in cross section, flanked by a pair of narrower transverse collars, and terminating in a small finial at the top. The surface of the spoon is undecorated.Overall dimensions: length 45.6mm; width 12.9mm; thickness 6.1mm; weight 3.92g.Although previously misidentified as Roman cosmetic items, such as nail cleaners (see for instance, the similar looking objects published by Crummy, 1983: 58), these objects have since been reidentified as Post-medieval spoon handles, with complete examples known to be held in the Museum of London's collections (objects A10625 and A3934).

properties.title: HOOK
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper-alloy hook, possibly for a sword belt. The hook consists of a rectangular apeture at the top with an integral recurving hook at the bottom. The hook tapers to a blunt point at the end. The hook was possibly used on a harness or other equipment, or possibly  due to its shape and size.

properties.title: HOOK
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper-alloy hook. The hook consists of a circular ring at the top with an integral recurving hook at the bottom. The hook splays out at the end. It has not been possible to find an exact parallel; it is more likely the hook was used on a harness or other equipment rather than a personal dress accessory (for example worn on a belt) due to its shape and size. Diameter of ring: 37mm; thickness of ring: 5mm; width of hook: 12mm; thickness of hook: 3mm; overall length: 45mm.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval cast copper-alloy rowel spur fragment. The fragment consists of one side with figure of eight terminals at the front. The neck is slightly downward turning; the rowel and other side are missing. A similar example can be seen in 'The Medieval Horse and its Equipment' number 333, p138- 139.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A Prehistoric small flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flake is broadly triangular in plan, tapering to a blunt apex at one end. There is a small amount of cortex remaining on the dorsal side.The flint is dark to mid grey in colour.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A Prehistoric small flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flake is broadly triangular in plan, tapering to a blunt apex at one end. The ventral face is smooth. Blade removal scarring is visible on the dorsal side, this side has become abraided, possibly after deposition.The flint is dark brown in colour with small white flecks.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A possible Prehistoric flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flint is pale grey with white mottles in colour.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A Prehistoric small flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flake is broadly triangular in plan, tapering to a blunt apex at one end. The ventral face is smooth. Blade removal scarring is visible on the dorsal side.The flint is dark brown in colour.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A Prehistoric utilised flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flake is broadly triangular in plan, tapering to a blunt apex at one end. There is some evidence of retouching along the long sides. The flint is dark brown in colour. A small amount of cortex remains on the dorsal side.

properties.title: DEBITAGE
properties.description: A Prehistoric utilised flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (4000 to 800 BC). The flake is broadly rectangular in plan, tapering to a point at one end. There is some evidence of retouching along the edges. The flint is pale grey to white with dark grey patches in colour. A small amount of cortex remains at the end of the tapered end.

properties.title: RETOUCHED FLAKE
properties.description: A Prehistoric retouched flint flake dating from the Neolithic to Bronze Age period (c. 4000 to 801 BC). The flake is broadly rectangular in plan, with a point at one edge, which may have been used as an awl. There is some retouching around the edges. The flint is pale grey to white and has dark grey patches.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy button. The button is decorated on the front with a six circles representing petals. Spaced evenly around the outside of the flower are six triangles representing leaves. The flower possibly represents a rose. The back of the button is plain and undecorated and has is an integral attachment loop with a sub-circular perforation at the centre. The button probably dates from c. AD 1600 to AD 1700.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval uniface lead-alloy token. The token is circular in plan, both faces are flat; one face is plain, whilst the other is decorated. The decorated face has a voided long cross, which may intentionally mimic the long cross coinage of the time. The surface patina is grey in colour.

properties.title: SCRAPER (TOOL)
properties.description: A Prehistoric end scraper of Neolithic to Bronze Age date (c.4000-801 BC). The flint is broadly square in plan. The cross section is almost triangular as one side is tapers significantly. Both faces are smooth and have not been knapped. Three of the edges have been squared off to give 90 degree sides, whereas the fourth side angles inwards.There is a possibility this may be a post-medieval to modern gunflint from a flintlock pistol, but the edges on gunflints tend to be more uniform and gunflints are usually trapezoidal in plan. The tapering end of this piece suggests that the scraper has snapped in the middle. Furthermore, when turned over to the ventral face, retouching is visible on the edge of the tapering end, suggesting the item has had a secondary use as a blade.

properties.title: RETOUCHED FLAKE
properties.description: A Neolithic to Bronze Age retouched flint flake.The flake which has been retouched around the edges; it is broadly rectangular, with one straight end and the opposite end rounded to a blunt point. The ventral face is smooth, with a bulb-of-percussion and ripples visible on the surface. The dorsal face has blade removal scars visible on the surface. The colour of the flint is mid brown to mid grey.

properties.title: CORE
properties.description: A flint core dating to the Mesolithic period (c.10,000 to 4001 BC). The core is roughly rectangular in plan and both ends have irregular breaks. Blade removal scars are visible on the surface. This core would have been used to produce microliths. The flint has a patinated white surface.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy cloth seal, probably of 17th century date. The cloth seal is comprised of two circular discs linked by a rectangular tab. The two discs have been folded towards one another with the tab acting as a hinge. The face of one disc has an outer border of pellets arranged around the circumference. Within the border are the numbers '16 4 5 00' (with the 4 above the other numbers). The 4 has a long stem which extends into the number 5 below it. In turn, the bottom of the number 5 extends below, forming a double curve which possibly represents the letter 'S'. This curving line interlnks with the capital letter 'H' below. Therefore possibly forming the initials 'H S'. the numbers possibly represent the year- perhaps 1600 or 1645. The face of the other disc has no discernable markings.

properties.title: BLADE
properties.description: A Prehistoric flint blade dating from the Neolithic to the Bronze Age period. The item is rectangular in plan and has a trapezoidal cross section. The ventral surface is smooth and the dorsal surface has a thin rectangular removal scar. The edges have been retouched. The flint is mid grey in colour.

properties.title: LEAF ARROWHEAD
properties.description: A flint leaf-shaped arrowhead dating to the Neolithic period. The item is roughly triangular in plan (originally leaf-shaped but only half remains) and has an elongated lenticular cross section. The edges are lightly retouched. The flint is a mid to pale grey, with areas of white. It is possible the arrowhead may have been snapped in half deliberately.

properties.title: SPATULA
properties.description: A Medieval to Modern worked bone item, possibly a spatula or handle fragment. The item is broadly leaf-shaped in plan; it tapers to a blunt point at one end. The other end is slightly wider at the point where it has broken. The cross section is lenticular. In profile, there is a slight curve towards the blunt pointed end, which may be due to the original shape of the bone material. The surface of the object has been polished smooth; there are no decoration or other markings visible.

properties.title: HAIR PIN
properties.description: A Roman copper-alloy hair pin. The knop and upper section remain, the item would originally tapered to a point but this section has broken away and is missing. The top of the knop is flat and circular in plan, measuring 5mm in diameter; the knop is then waisted, after which it swells again, followed by a second waist which then widens outwards to a collar. The shank is circular in section, measuring c.2mm in diameter, and widening towards the knop. Just before the second collar of the knop are a series of decorative lines running around the circumference of the shank. The item would have been worn by women to hold elaborate hairsyles in place and probably dates from approximately c. AD 43 to AD 410.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver halfgroat of Charles I, (1625-1649).Obverse: CAROLVS D G MAG B[R FR] ET HIB REX; crowned bust facing II behind bust.Reverse: IVSTITIA THRONVM FIRMAT ; garnished oval.Group D, fouth bust. Initial mark possible anchor, (1628-9).

properties.title: CUFF LINK
properties.description: Treasure case 2014 T490: Disclaimed, return to finderDescription: Silver cufflink. The discs are circular in plan with down turned edges, now bent out of shape in places.
