The upper surfaces are stamped from behind with a clasped hand motif with sleeves showing, surmounted by a crown and with two small hearts with a pellet above each located below (Lewis form 1, type C). The background has a stippled effect. The reverse of the discs have a 'D' shaped silver loop attachment in the centre with a long oval silver loop between the two halves. The connecting loop has been stamped with a maker's mark; only two pairs of uprights can be discerned, two straight, the other pair oblique.Dimensions: Each disc is 16.8mm in diameter, 2.2mm thick and the loop between is 17.8mm long. Overall weight: 2.57g.Discussion: Other similar cufflinks may be found on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database and reported through the treasure process, including KENT-E2E596 (2014 T166) and BH-D24317 (2011 T316). The type, Lewis's Type C, is little known this far west (Lewis 2014, 6-7).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin of Constantine I dating to the period AD 310 to 312 (Reece period 15). ADVENTVS AVG reverse type depicting Prince riding left, right hand raised, left holding up spear, on horse which is pawing a seated captive on the left, minted at London, AD 310-312, RIC VI p.134, no.133.

properties.title: SEAL
properties.description: A modern lead-alloy bag seal, probably of early 20th century date. The seal is circular in plan and there are traces of writing (now worn) around the circumference.

properties.title: STRAP END
properties.description: A medieval copper-alloy strap end. The item is sub-rectangular in plan, widening at one end. No further details recorded.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy cinquefoil (five petalled) mount or stud. The mount is convex and the front and concave at the back, forming a C-shape section. The front has a moulded decoration at the centre of a five petalled flower with a circle at the centre, probably representing a rose. At the back is an integral lug or spike for attachment; it is square in section and tapers to a point. The mount probably date from c. AD 1600 - c. AD 1700.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Modern copper- alloy half penny token of the Rose Copper Company issued at Birmingham and Swansea, dating to AD 1811 (on token) Withers (1999) no.238 to 272.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy furniture mount in the form of a six-petalled flower. The item has flat faces on both sides and is undecorated. There is a rectangular-shaped perforation at the centre for attachment. The mount probably dates from c. AD 1675 - AD 1725.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper-alloy double-loop buckle frame with integral central bar. The buckle probably dates to around AD 1350 to AD 1650. A small amount of the pin remains wrapped around the cenral bar. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003:54), number 310.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy sub-annular buckle frame with integral central bar. The from of the buckle has a moulded decoration of raised knops interspresed with a raised linear running pattern. The back of the buckle is plain. The buckle probably dates to around AD 1650 to 1720. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003:48), number 280.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy rectangular buckle frame with integral central bar. The outer edges are bevelled. The buckle probably dates to around AD 1570 to 1700. A similar example can be seen in (Whitehead 2003:75), number 461.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy buckle frame with asymmetrical design and integral central bar. The buckle probably dates to the period  c.1575 to 1700 (c.f Whitehead 1996: 90, no.651).

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy belt fastener in the form of an S-shaped snake. On each side of the fitting is a raised circular moulding, representing eyes. The scales of the snake are represented by small raised circular dots on both sides. The item has a mid-green patina and at the neck, where the head curves over, is a red-brown lump of corrosion. Compare IOW-832BD6, SWYOR-64EEF7 and SWYOR-50EC92 (from which the following information is derived).Similar examples are illustrated in Gordon Bailey's Detector Finds 3 (1997: 20-21). Bailey states that the 'snake form belt hooks' became popular during the 16th century, where an example can be seen in the portrait of Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester, in about 1575. The fastener was part of a sword belt, and was used in place of the normal buckle. It is likely that these strap fittings would have been tinned or gilded. The snake belt hook would seem to have fallen from fashion by the 17th century, and remained so until the end of the 18th century, when it was favoured by the military (ibid.: 20).

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper-alloy mount. The mount is roughly shield-shaped at the centre, tapering to a point at one end. At the opposite end is an elongated knop, which splays outwards at the end.  At the back are the remains of two integral lugs, one positioned at each end. The item is worn and abraided and there are no traces of decoration or gilding visible.

properties.title: FERRULE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper-alloy item. The item is possibly a ferrule from a walking stick. The item is now squashed flat but appears to have originally been a circular ring. The exterior surface is decorated with a series of stamped symbols, and with no apparent pattern, are spaced at irregular intervals. The shape of each stamp is of two crosses joined by a line at across the top.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy weight. The weight is roughly conical in shape; it has a flat oval base with sides that taper upwards. A circular perforation runs from the top to the base. This hole is presumably where string or wire attachment was threaded in order to act as a handle or suspension loop for the weight.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy weight. The weight is roughly cube-shaped in that the it is square in plan and section. On both the top and bottom faces of the object is a square recess with a small circular perforation. The hole is presumably where string or wire attachment was threaded in order to act as a handle or suspension loop for the weight itself.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface patina is a dark gray colour with some small white patches. The diameter is c.17mm.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval cast copper-alloy cauldron or posnet foot fragment (probably). The fragment is roughly oval in plan; one end is flat where it has broken away and the other end is rounded. The item has a D-shaped section at the broken end. The item is worn and abbraided; it is possible it is a fragment of a foot from a small cooking vessel.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A copper-alloy finger ring of Roman to Post Medieval date. The bezel is an elongated oval shape, narrowing at the shoulders to the thinner hoop. The hoop is oval in plan; at the end opposite the bezel, the hoop broadens to a slight point on the exterior. The finger ring is worn and abbraided and there are no traces of gilding or decoration visible. The ring is very small and was probably intended for a child.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy farthing trade token dating to AD 1667. Obverse: A. TAVNTON .FARTHING 1667. At the centre is a 'T' on a tun (a large barrel). Reverse: BY THE CONSTABLES 1667. At the centre is a castle.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman cooper-alloy coin (possibly). The coin is possibly an as or dupondius dating from AD 43 to 260; it is extremely worn on both sides and therefore cannot be identified further.

properties.title: BELL
properties.description: A Post Medieval cast copper alloy crotal bell. The bell is spherical, has been cast in one piece and has a two holes at the top. There is an integral rectangular suspension loop, with a sub- circular hole at the centre. There is cast curvilinear 'sun-burst' decoration on the lower hemisphere. The bell is 40mm high and 29mm wide at the centre. Approximately half of the lower hemisphere is broken and is missing. The sun-burst pattern, also often described as stylised petals, was in use on crotal bells during the 16th to 17th centuries, so this bell dates from c AD 1500 to AD 1600.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A Late Iron age to Early roman possible Tankard handle or potential horse-furniture fitting, probably dating to c. 100 BC - AD 100. The object has an elongated-oval plan, 19.2mm wide by 69.3mm long, it is sub-rectangular in cross section, with rounded ends, 5.8mm thick. The object is largely flat to the plane, but with either end narrowing into a rear-ward projection, sub-circular in cross section, both terminating in patinated breaks. The front of the object is engraved with a double-scroll motif, with large central terminals and forming a pair of opposed trumpet-shaped fields in the negative space. The engraved scrolls are inlaid with red enamel.Dimensions: Length 69.3mm; width 19.2mm; thickness 13.7mm; weight 32.0g. The form of the object is suggestive of an identification as a vessel handle, with the perforated plates at either terminal that would have held it to the vessel now lost. The style of decoration and use of red enamel would both be suggestive of a Later Iron age or early Roman date range. Spratling (1972: nos. 359-377) publishes a range of tankard handles, and most appear comparable in general form, although none are identical. Compare also Jackson (1990: nos. 119-120) and NMS-8E40B7, on this database. However this example lacks the noted curvature seen on other examples, and could conceivably have served as a decorative horse furniture-fitting.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post medieval hammered Irish silver sixpence of James I (1603 - 1625). The coin dates to between AD 1603 and 1604. First coinage, Mintmark: Bell. The coin is bent, and has a dark grey patina.Obverse description: Crowned bust right. Obverse inscription: IACOBUS.D:G.ANG:SCO:[FRA.ET].HIB:REX. Reverse description: Crowned harp. Reverse inscription: TVEATVR.VNITA.DEVS.Diameter: 23.52mm. Thickness: 0.65mm. Weight: 1.82g.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Medieval to Post Medieval copper alloy mount. The mount is circular in plan; it is C-shaped in section and has a raised central boss at the front and a concave hollow at the back. There are the remains of two integral lugs, or perhaps a central bar, at the back for attachment.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A post Medieval copper alloy cauldron leg. The leg has three toes and a collar at the top. It has a D-shaped section. the item is very abraided.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The item is spherical in form and it measures 20mm in diameter and weighs 38.41g. There is some pitting on the surface of the musket ball and the patina is a dark gray colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy musket ball dating from c. AD 1600 - 1800. The item is spherical; there is a flattened area on one side which has porbably occured as a result of impacting upon a surface. There is some pitting on the surface of the musket ball and the patina is a whitish gray colour.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy double loop buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1500 - 1650. The frame has a notched rounded point on each side of the strap bar. There is a small knop on the frame above and below the strap bar. the strap bar is very thin, possibly due to wear, and has broken in one place. The pin is missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p55, number 316.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy trapezoidal buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1620 - 1680. The frame has rounded knops at the corners and a lobed protrusion on either side of the strap bar. The pin is missing.  A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p83, number 522.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Medieval copper alloy annular buckle frame, dating from c AD 1250 - 1450. The frame is annular in plan and has the remains of an iron pin bent around part of the frame. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 17, numbers 34 - 38.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy single loop sub-rectangular buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1500 - 1650. The frame has one straight end and one rounded end with a lobed knop. The pin is missing. A similar example can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 28, number 145.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy asymmetrical buckle frame, dating from c. AD 1575 - 1700. In plan, the frame has one rectangular end and one rounded end with a central strap bar. The pin is missing. Similar examples can be seen in Whitehead (2003), p 91.

properties.title: CUTLERY
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy cutting wheel from a post-medieval pastry jigger, dating from around the 18th century. Both faces are flat with radiating grooves and ridges. The cuting edge forms a zig-zag shape in profile. It is pierced centrally for an axis bar which would have been secured to a handle. Similar examples can be seen in 'Old Cooking Utensils' by David J Eveleigh (Shire LIbrary Classics), p 29. Diameter:31 mm; Thickness:2.5mm; Weight: 9.74g

properties.title: STAMP
properties.description: A late post-medieval to modern copper-alloy tool, probably a finishing tool for book binding. It has a blade of rectangular cross-section which expands gradually from a width of 11.4mm at the stop to 20.5mm at the cutting edge. It attains its greatest width before the cutting edge, travelling straight down towards this edge which is largely straight. The stop referred to is sub-circular and slightly dished to accommodate the handle. It measures up to 16.9mm across but has been broken to one side of the tang and is mostly missing here. The central tang is of rectangular cross-section and tapers from a maximum width of 5.5mm. It is truncated after 16.1mm after what appears to have been old damage.It has a dark-brown patina over a red-brown metal and has been bent slightly to one side at the cutting edge.The object has been identified by Susan Chandler at ASE as a finishing tool used during book binding of a type dating to c. AD 1750-1850. It can be compared with LANCUM-D04963 on this database.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy weight dating from c. AD 1540- c. AD 1900. The object weighs 4 ounces. The item is conical in overall shape; the base is flat and circular and the sides taper to a point at the top. At the top are traces of iron suspension hoop. Diameter of base: 22.5mm; Length: 42mm.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead alloy weight dating from c. AD 1540- c. AD 1900. The object weighs 125g, so it was probably originally intended as a six ounce weight. The item is conical in overall shape; the base is circular with a slightly rounded concave face. The sides taper towards the top. The top of the object is flat and circular in plan. A circular perforation runs through the whole length of the object. Presumably strong twine or wire was pushed through the hole for attachment to weighing scales and/or storage. Diameter of base: 28mm; Diameter at top: 15mm; length: 25.5mm.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The musket ball is roughly spherical in shape. Overall, the surface is smooth with some slight pitting. The patina is whitish gray in colour.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval shot dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The shot is roughly spherical in shape. The surface is pitted and the patina is pale gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The musket ball is flattened on three sides and there are two deep linear grooves atr the centre of the object.The surface is uneven and pitted and the patina is pale gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The musket ball is D-shaped in section; being flattened on one side as a result of impact, however, it was originally spherical in form. The surface is smooth and the patina is pale gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is spherical in shape and the surface is burred and pitted.The patina is whitish gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item has been flattened on one side and is D-shaped in section. The surface is pitted and has a whitish gray patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is spherical in shape. The surface has several shallow linear lacerations, which probably occured after deposition. The surface is otherwise smooth and has a whitish gray patina.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy pistol shot, dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is spherical in shape. There are faint traces of a mould line around the circumference. There is a roughly semi-circular shaped impression on the surface. The surface is smooth with a mid gray patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800. There is a broad raised strip around the circumference. One side of the musket ball is completely distorted, probably as a result of impact after firing. The surface patina is mid gray. The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The musket ball is spherical in shape and has a slightly pitted surface. The patina is mid gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball has a D-shaped section, having been flattened at one side probably as a result of imapct after firing. There is a broad raised strip around the circumference and what is probably a casting sprue, now squashed flat, at one point on the broad strip. The surface is smooth and has a mid gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball is spherical in shape and has a broad raised strip around the circumference. The surface is smooth and has a mid gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball is spherical in shape and has a broad raised strip around the circumference. There is a large semi-circular impression at one point along the broad strip, which may indicate removal from the barrel with an implement known as a 'worm'. The surface is smooth and has a whitish gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, probably caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface is smooth and has a mid gray patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. One end is flattened slightly, probably as a result of impact after firing. At the same end is a deep linear groove. There are linear striations at right angles to the band, caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. The surface is smooth and has a whitish gray patina.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy pistol shot, dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800.The item is spherical in shape. The mould line and casting sprue are visible. The two hemispheres are offset. The surface is smooth and the patina is dark gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800.The musket ball is spherical in shape. A faint mould line is visible and there are traces of a casting sprue. The surface is slightly pitted and there are some small lacerations which may have occured after disposition.The patina is mid gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball is spherical in shape and has broad raised strip around the circumference. The surface is smooth and has a whitish gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball is overall spherical in shape and has broad raised strip around the circumference. One side is damaged and partially flattened, possibly as a result of imapct after firing.The surface is smooth and has a light gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is spherical in shape. The surface is slightly pitted and there is a half-moon shaped dent on the surface and the patina is mid gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is circular in plan and D-shaped in section. The flattening that has occured on one side is probably as a result of imapct after being fired. The convex surface has a circular dimple which has resulted from the mould not being filled properly during casting. The patina is whitish gray in colour.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy item, probably a musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item is mis-shapen and is roughly hexagonal in plan and has a lenticular section. The surface is burred on one side; the other is comparatively smooth. The patina is mid gray in colour. The musket ball has presumably become mis-shapen and flattened as a result of impact after firing.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item completely flattened at one side, giving a D-shaped profile. The flattening presumably occured as a result of impact after firing. The surface is relatively smooth and has a mid gray patina.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy shot, dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800.The shot is overall spherical in shape and measures12.5mm in diameter. There are slight traces of a mould line running around the circumference and a casting sprue is still attached at one end. Overall the surface is smooth and has a whitish-gray patina.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800.The musket ball is overall spherical in shape and has broad raised strip around the circumference. There are two grooves at one side along the broad strip; there is also a dent in one of the hemispheres. The surface is smooth and has a light gray patina.The broad strip suggests that the musket ball was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball dating from c.AD 1600- AD 1800. The item completely flattened at one side, giving a D-shaped profile. The flattening presumably occured as a result of impact after firing. The surface appears worn and slightly pitted.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1700- AD 1800. The musket ball is mis-shapen and flattened at one end, presumably as a result of impact after firing. The broad raised strip around the circumference suggests this was for use with a two groove rifle and is probably of a post 17th century date (with thanks to Dr Glenn Foard).

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are pronounced linear striations at right angles to the band, caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel. One end is flattened, probably as a result of impact after firing.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are linear striations at right angles to the band, caused as the ball travelled down the gun barrel.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is banded in the centre around the circumference and one end is flattened due to impact; at the same end are two deep grooves or cut marks. Length:16.5mm; Width: 16.5; Weight: 25.04g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is overall spherical in shape with a smooth surface and pale gray patina. Diameter: 15.5mm; Weight: 22.12g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is overall spherical in shape with a smooth surface and pale gray patina. One side of the musket ball has a deep laceration c.14mm in length, which may have been made intentionally in order to maximise damage when fired. On the same side is a flattened area, suggesting impact. Diameter: 16.5mm; Weight: 26.06g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is 'banded' i.e. it is flattened in a band around the circumference. There are linear striations at right angles to the band, caused as the ball travelled down the barrel. Length: 18.5mm; Width:15.5 mm; Weight: 28.76g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is roughly spherical in shape and has a very smooth surface with a light gray patina. The mould line can be seen feintly around the circumference. One of the hemispheres has is slightly flattened, indicating an impact; at the same point is a linear laceration measuing 9mm in length. Diameter:18.5 mm; Weight: 36.54g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c.AD 1600 to c.1800. The musket ball is roughly spherical in shape. The surface is uneven and the mould line can be seen around the circumference. Diameter:17 mm; Weight: 29.48g

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A Post Medieval lead-alloy musket ball, dating from c. AD 1600 to 1800. The musket ball is roughly spherical in shape and the surface is smooth overall. A faint mould line can be seen around the circumference. One of the hemispheres has a small half-moon shaped dent. Diameter: 19mm; Weight: 37.75g

properties.title: DRESS HOOK
properties.description: Description: A Post Medieval silver-gilt dress-hook with decorative openwork design of sixteenth century date. The body of the dress-hook is asymmetrical; the hook end is rectangular in form with an integral decorative trilobe and recurving hook protruding from the straight side. At the opposite end is an arcaded element with a foliate scroll terminal. The backplate appears to be sheet silver, soldered on to the cast body.Dimensions: Length (including hook): 28.80mm; Width: 16.41mm; Thickness: 5.75mm.Discussion: A similar dress hook was found at Kingsbridge, Devon (Treasure reference number: 2006 T646/ PAS database number: DEV-89F942). In the report for 2006 T646, Dora Thornton noted that the dress hook was: 'A common type for 16th C copper alloy fittings, less often found in silver.'Consequently, in terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Author: Danielle Wootton, Devon Finds Liaison Officer

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A corroded cast lead token of post-medieval date with initials T . A // ?T on one side, and the initials A H on the other (Powell type 2) both within a raised border at the circumference, now slightly battered.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A medieval to postmedieval lead alloy token. The token is circular in plan and has a design on the obverse and a plain reverse. The design on the obverse is a circle at the centre divided by a long cross, with  four inward facing semi circles in each angle. It has not been possible to find an exact match for the design, but it is consistent with designs on lead tokens of the medieval and postmedieval periods which often had circles, stars, crosses, pellets, petals and other such designs on one or both faces.  The token was found whilst undertaking work at St Mary Steps Church in Exeter. The original church dates from c.AD 1150, it was later rebuilt during the 1400's and is famous locally for the Matthew the Miller clock (originally made 1619 -1621) which is set into an exterior wall.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Treasure report: Description: post-medieval composite silver shoe or knee buckle . The frame of the buckle is cast with an integral cross bar/ spindle. On the frame and on each side of the bar there are three transverse grooves. The chape is silver sheet folded around the bar to form a hinged plate; in plan is has straight sides which tapers to a semi-circular end. At the end of the chape is a circular void which may have held a decorative stud. On this side is also a maker's mark 'ER'. The reverse of the buckle is plain.Dimensions:Length: 28.19mmLength of oval component: 21.20mmWidth: 19.19mmThickness: 2.03mmWeight: 5.2gDiscussion:Similar example scan be found from Thornham, Norfolk (PAS ID: SWYOR-1E7C11, 2010 T536) and Boughton, Northamptonshire (PAS ID: NARC3268)Consequently, in terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Janina ParolAssistant Treasure RegistrarThe British Museum

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmeideval silver hammered coin. The coin is a half crown of Charles I (1625 - 1649). The star mintmark dates the coin from AD 1640 to 1641.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver hammered coin. The coin is very worn and cannot be identified further.

properties.title: STUD
properties.description: A medieval to postmedieval copper alloy stud. Viewed in plan, the head is circular and flat. At the back of the item, an integral lug projects from the centre.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver hammered coin. The coin is a Scottish twenty pence of Charles I (1625 - 1649).

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A medieval copper alloy tear drop-shaped mount. At the centre of the back of the object, there are two outwardly projecting lugs for attachment.

properties.title: TOY
properties.description: A postmedieval to modern cast copper alloy miniature cannon, used as a child's toy. The barrel is cylindrical in plan; the sides taper towards the muzzle. The barrel is hollow and circular in section. The two projecting lugs (trunions) on the barrel would have attached to a block or stock. The item probably dates from the 18th to 19th centurues.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A medieval to postmedieval copper alloy mount. In plan, the mount is roughly circular and on the front face a flower with twelve petals around the circumference is represented with six circular knops at the centre. The back face is undecorated add has two lugs, one at either side of the item, for attachment.

properties.title: SWORD BELT
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy sword belt hanger, dating from c. AD 1600 to 1700. In plan, the plate is roughly rectangular in shape; the top has two curved indentations which form a point at each end and a point at the centre. There are two small circular rivet holes; one still has a rivet attached. At the bottom of the plate is a circular hole, presumably there was a matching circular hole on the opposite side, which has now broken away. At the bottom of the item is an integral ring.

properties.title: HOOK
properties.description: A Post Medieval to Modern copper alloy cup hook. The shaft is circular in section. Part of the shaft is bent upwards at an angle, forming an 'L'shape. One end of the object has a broad flat circular terminal. The iron staining visible on the end is the remains of the iron screw whereby it screwed into wood (pers comm, Gary Crace, March 2016).

properties.title: KEYHOLE FITTING
properties.description: A postmedieval to modern copper alloy keyhole escutcheon plate. In plan, the plate is oval, with a keyhole at the centre. Both faces are flat and undecorated.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver hammered coin. The coin is a penny of Elizabeth I (1558 - 1603). Similar to Spink  2580 (2011 edition). Image from finder.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A medieval to postmedieval lead alloy token. The token is disc shaped with two faces. One face has a series of straight lines arranged so that they cross in the middle, in  a schematic star shape. The other face is plain.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A post-medieval silver coin. This coin is a shilling of William III (1694-1702), dating to 1697. See Spink reference 3497-3519.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A medieval copper alloy purse bar attachment loop. in plan, the item is tear-shaped with a rectangular collar. There is a circular perforation at the centre, measuring 8.5mm in diameter. Underneath the collar is a small circular protrusion. Both faces and sides of the item bare traces of file marks. The attachment loop may be for an item other than a purse bar, such as a casket handle securing loop or similar.

properties.title: STRAP END
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy strap end. The item is sub rectangular in plan, with a projection at one end containing a rivet, and at the other end are the remains of a double arching projection (now partially broken); the profile of the item is rectangular. One face has a raised circular knop; the other face is plain and undecorated. Both faces have three rivet holes with the rivets remaining. The end with the riveted projection is open -ended, presumably this is where a leather strap or belt was attached between the two sheets. The other end is closed.

properties.title: TAP
properties.description: A post-medieval copper alloy tap handle, now broken; the straight horizontal top and part of the circular-section stem survive. T-shaped handles such as these are known from 18th-century taps, which may come from barrels, cisterns or plumbing.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A medieval to post medieval copper alloy double looped buckle frame with integral central bar. The pin is missing. The buckle frame is dated to AD 1350-1650 and is similar to number 310 in 'Buckles 1250 -1800' by Ross Whitehead.

properties.title: FURNITURE FITTING
properties.description: A Post Medieval copper alloy furniture fitting. The item is an escutcheon plate; it is oval in plan with two sub-circular protrusions at the top, and a figure-of-eight key-hole in the centre. The front face is flat with grooved decoration; the back face is flat and undecorated with traces of orange iron corrosion.

properties.title: DRESS FASTENER (DRESS)
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy hooked clasp or eye fastener of 17th century date. The front face is convex with a moulded relief scallop shell design. There are the remains of three integral attachment loops; one (still intact) at the top of the shell, the other two (now broken) are placed at each side of the shell. There are the remains of a rectangular attachment loop at the bottom of the fastener (now broken).The fastener is Read class A type 6. Please see Hooked-clasps & Eyes, Brian Read, Portculis Publishing 2008, page 174 No 657 and 659 for similar examples. The fastener probably dates from AD 1600 to 1700.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: A copper alloy Roman hinged knee brooch fragment. Part of the tubular wings and bow survive; the foot, catchplate and pin are missing. The brooch is abraided and no decoration is visible. The bow is circular in section.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is an as or dupondius of first or second century AD date. The coin is very worn and cannot be identified further.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is an as or dupondius of first or second century AD date. The coin is very worn and cannot be identified further.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: A copper alloy rowel spur fragment, of medieval to postmedieval date. The fragment consists of one side and the remains of the rowel box; the other side and the rowel are missing. Rowel spurs first came into use during the 13th century and had largely replaced the prick spur by the 14th century.

properties.title: FLAKE
properties.description: A prehistoric flint flake of neolithic to bronze age date. The ventral face has a bulb of percussion with radiating ripples visible on the surface, demonstrating that the flint has been struck. The dorsal face has traces of blade removal scars. There are traces of retouching visible on the edges of the dorsal face. The flint is mid brown-grey with large, paler mottles.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Roman sliver coin. The coin is a denarius is cut or broken in half. The coin is very worn, and can be dated to the first or second centuries AD.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver hammered coin. The coin is an Edwardian type penny, dating from AD 1279 to 1377. The coin has been clipped around the edges.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Medieval silver hammered half groat The coin is an Edwardian type half groat, dating from AD 1279 to 1377.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver hammered cut halfgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 - 1603). The coin has been cut in half.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver hammered penny of Elizabeth I (AD 1558 - 1603). The coin has been clipped around the edges.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: A medieval to postmedieval lead alloy uniface sub-circular token. The token has a cross in relief on the front face; the back face is plain.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy trade weight. The weight is disc-shaped and circular in plan. The reverse is flat and plain. The front has a cupped border, so that the centre of the weight is inset. The centre is stamped with a variety of letters arranged around and within a stamped circle; the letters appear to read D E and O N (or possibly OZ for 'ounce'). A stamp in the form of a sword is also visible, this is the symbol for the city of London. The item weighs 13.51g and is the equivalent to 0.47 ounces.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Medieval to Postmedieval copper alloy mount. The mount is cruciform in plan. The front face is decorated with raised moulded decoration; around the border is a scrolling foliate decoration, in the centre are nine circlets forming the shape of a lozenge. There is a knop at the end of each arm. At the back is an integral square-sectioned spike or lug for attachment to a leather strap or similar.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver sixpence of William III (1694- 1702). The coin is very worn; traces of the King's bust, right are just visible on the obverse. The coin has been bent twice into an 'S' shape; during this period, it was popular to turn coins (usually sixpences) into 'love tokens' as a keepsake.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A postmedieval silver sixpence. The coin is very worn and no details are visible. The coin has been bent twice into an 'S' shape; during this period, it was popular to turn coins (usually sixpences) into 'love tokens' as a keepsake.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy button. The button is circular in plan. The front face is decorated with a simple floral design made up of five dots arranged around a central dot, with six protruding leaves. The back face is flat; there are traces of an integral attachment loop, which has broken away and is now missing. Buttons of this type are of 18th century date (1700's). Please see reference below for similar examples.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A postmedieval tombac pimple button. The button is circular in plan. The front face is slightly raised towards the middle, forming a pimple at the centre. The back face is flat; there are traces of iron corrosion on the back, this is, presumably, evidence of the iron attachment loop, which is now missing. Buttons of this type are of mid-17th century date (1650's). Please see reference below for similar examples.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A copper alloy postmedieval buckle frame, with part of pin remaining. The buckle frame is trapezoidal in shape. One end of the frame has two mouldings with a knop at the top and one at the bottom; the other end of the frame has four mouldings with one extending tear-drop shaped knop each at the top and the bottom. The buckle dates from around AD 1620 to AD 1680. See reference below for a similar parallel.

properties.title: PIPE (SMOKING)
properties.description: A Victorian silver ferrule from a pipe stem, dating to AD 1887. The ferrule is rectangular in plan and has four sides. The end nearest to where the pipe bowl was positioned is decorated with a serrated or pinked edge; the other end is straight. A rectangular piece of wood with a sub-circular hole is still intact within the silver ferrule. One side of the ferrule is stamped with the maker's mark of 'EB- WB' and is also stamped with three small hallmarks. The maker's mark stands for' Edwin and William Barling' of London, who were pipe makers at the time. With thanks to the finder for information on the pipe makers.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A cast copper-alloy object, probably representing a mount and dating from the Roman or post-Medieval periods.The piece takes the form of a moulded anthromorphic mask. Measuring 24.3mm in length and 24mm in width, the front face is convex and the back face hollow. The front face has moulded decoration, the cherub-like head has a halo of wavy hair with a central curl on its forehead. The face is oval in plan, with circular indented eyes and a projecting triangular nose. The cheeks are rounded and the mouth is small and possibly pouting. The reverse is rough and undecorated it is likely to have originally been soldered to possibly a copper-alloy vessel of some kind. (Notes from PAS record SF-FAF633)

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A copper alloy circular unifaced coin weight for the quarter noble. The weight dates from the late 15th century AD. One face of the weight is stamped with a lis surmounted by a crown, with a rounded hole punched centrally between the two, all within a double-ringed border. English weights were made according to an Act of Parliament of AD 1421; this type of weight was probably discontinued around AD 1471. The weight weighs 3.11gms or 0.11oz.

properties.title: PLAQUE
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy plaque. The plaque is heart-shaped and flat in plan. The front face is engraved, the back face is plain. On the front face are engraved pictures of various brushes and implements, with the following inscription:E SheenCHIMNEY SWEEPER[...] Jack (or possibly Silk or Sack or similar) Cleaner CandFIRE DEFENDEREXETERThere are three small holes for attachment; two at the top and one at the bottom. The plaque may have been attached to the tradesman's cart or similar.

properties.title: JEWS HARP
properties.description: A medieval copper alloy jew's harp fragment. One of the two arms survive, there are grooved lines running vertically along the arm on one side, the other side of the arm is plain. The top of the jews harp has two curves,suggesting that it would have originally formed a trefoil shape. On the outer edge of these two curves are two knops; at the end of each knop are four small sub-circular indentations. It is possible that these indentations held semi-precious stones or coloured glass. This is a Jew's harp of unusual form and Brian Read suggests a 14th or 15th century AD date (pers comm with finder 17/4/13).

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A medieval copper alloy uniface coin weight for a quarter noble, probably dating to the 15th century. The weight is circular in plan and both faces are flat. One face has a symbol of a ship, the other face is plain. Weight 1.39g; diameter 11mm.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: A postmedieval copper alloy cauldron foot. The foot has three toes and is D-shaped in section. The item is very worn.

properties.title: MUSKET BALL
properties.description: A postmedieval lead alloy spherical musket ball, dating from c. AD 1500- 1800. The musket ball measures c.17mm in diameter.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A copper alloy medieval coin weight for a noble or possibly a half noble of 15th or 16th century date. It is circular in plan with a diameter of 13mm, and weighs 3.07g. The front face depicts a ship with a mast, the back face is undecorated. The object is worn, and has possibly been deliberately reduced in size around the edges, therefore the original weight of the object would have been heavier.

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: A cast copper alloy implement, of unknown function and possibly Roman or Anglo-Saxon in date. At one end, the implement is square in shape with four sides; it gently tapers to a point at the other end, becoming circular, rather than square in section. There is an incised cross or saltire ('X') at the square end, possibly used as a stamp, or for decoration. The four sides are decorated with an incised cross, which is bordered by two horizontal lines above and below the cross. At the tapering end is a circular piercing, presumably through which string was passed in a loop in order to hang up the implement for safekeeping.This object has been seen by PAS finds advisors Sally Worrell and Kevin Leahy. Worrell suggests (pers comm, March 2013) that the item is not a Roman stylus or a stamp, but that the item 'looks like a very exuberantly decorated Roman object', and points out that saltires are known as a decorative method on Roman objects. Leahy also belives the item is not a stylus, nor a pot stamp, reporting that 'the only surviving pot stamps are made from bone and the evidence at Cleatham suggested that each was only used on one pot making the use of wood likely.' Leahy goes on to suggest that another possibility could be 'a leather worker's stamp but decoration looks too crude from this function, leather stamps seem to have been neatly cut'. Leahy postulates that it could be a similar object to those that Anglo-Saxon ladies suspended from their belts, particularly the 'Hercules club' pendants..However, on checking Meaney's book [could not find a parallel]'. (pers comm, March 2013).

properties.title: COIN HOARD
properties.description: A fused lump of Late Roman base metal coins. Please see the extract from the Treasure report (below) for further details.Report for H.M. CoronerThis report will consider these coins with respect to the criteria laid down in the Treasure act (1996): Namely, their age, precious metal content and whether the coins can be said to come from the same find.Description of the coinsThe hoard is a fused in a lump which has been squashed as if extruded through a narrow gap. Perhaps the result of concealment in a building which has subsequently burnt down. None of the uncertain number of coins can be identified but they are of the size of debased radiates or Constantinian nummi. Weight = 80.05g and max length = 75mm.DiscussionOn the balance of probabilities, this find is likely to consist of ten or more base metal coins of an antiquity greater than 300 years, and thus qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Richard AbdyDept. of Coins and MedalsBritish Museum16.05.2013

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: Treasure report on a silver Seal Matrix:Description: A postmedieval (16th or 17th century) silver seal matrix with engraved oval die; part of the hexagonal conical handle is intact. The die is engraved with a coat of arms which consists of a shield containing a chevron between three animal heads erased. The heads may represent griffins or possibly wolves. Surrounding the shield is a scroll, linked to the scroll is a stylised decoration at each side of the shield, which may represent a stylised fish hanging from a line by the mouth, or perhaps a wreath of grapes, or similar.Discussion: The handle would probably have included a suspension loop at the end, as with similar seal matrices of this period. The arms cannot, at present, be identified with a specific family.Dimensions: Die length- 15.5mm; Die width- 14mm; Overall height- 6mmDue to its age and precious metal content, this item would qualify as Treasure under the Treasure Act 1996.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: A Romano-British cast copper alloy knee brooch, dating from c.AD 150 to c.AD 225. The catchplate and pin are missing; the brooch is otherwise intact. In profile, the bow projects out from the head at almost a ninety -degree angle, and then abruptly downwards. On the front of the bow, at the centre, is an oval shaped inset which is possibly glass paste, enamel or a white gemstone. Above this is a smaller hole, where, presumably another stone was set (now missing). There is a moulded decoration both above and below the central white stone. There are further moulded decorations where the bow joins the head. At the back of the bow are traces of the catchplate which has broken away. The brooch has closed tubular wings and part of the axle survives suggesting that the brooch was hinged rather than sprung. At the top of the head is a protrusion, which may be the remnants of a head loop, as seen on some varieties of Romano-British brooches which are thought to have been worn in pairs. There are traces of gilding visible on the surface of the brooch. Taking into account that the brooch was originally gilded and decorated with insets, this would have been a very decorative brooch. Length: 42mm; Width (at bow): 9.5mm; Thickness of bow: 5mm; Breadth of head- 23mm; Weight 12.24g

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman silver coin. The coin is a denarius of Septimius Severus (193 - 211), INDVLGENTIA AVGG IN CARTH type dating from about 204 AD. The coin reverse shows Dea Caelestis holding a thunderbolt and sceptre seated facing forwards on a lion leaping over water which gushes from a rock on the left. See Sear number 6285.The coin is probably a contemporary copy which has a silver wash. Some of the surface has worn away, revealing a darker core with patches of orange rust.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A medieval gold finger ring with an inscription on the exterior. Below is the Treasure report for the item:DescriptionA medieval gold finger-ring, the hoop in the form of a flattened band, inscribed * all : T : ioe : : in : T : god: ('all joy in god'). The two T letters probably signify the Tau cross, the symbol of St Anthony, who was thought to protect against St Anthony's fire, or holy fire, a form of ergot poisoning.DimensionsDiameter: 21mm.Width: 4.5mm.The find therefore qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996 in terms of both age and precious metal content.Beverley S Nenk, Curator, Dept Prehistory & Europe, British Museum

properties.title: DIE
properties.description: Roman to postmedieval lead alloy die. The die has six sub -rectangular sides, on one of the sides, it is possible to see four dots, and five dots can be seen on another side.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is a fourth century nummus of the house of Constantine.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is a fourth century nummus of the emperor Valens (364- 378 AD). SECVRITAS REI PVBLICAE reverse type.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is an as or dupondius of first or second century date.The coin is too worn to identify further.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is a fourth century nummus of the house of Constantine. Two soldiers with one (?or two) standards reverse type. Reece period 17.  The coin dates from 330- 341 AD. Possible Lyon mint.

properties.title: POT
properties.description: Two pottery sherds: 17th century, South Somerset pottery, fragment of handle and 18th century South Somerset pottery fragment of bowl rim. Handle fragment has green slip with sgraffito decoration. Bowl rim has two decorative indented dashed lines just below the rim.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Postmedieval copper alloy coin. The coin is a rose farthing (type 2) of Charles I (1625- 1649 AD). On the obverse of the coin is a single arched crown over crossed sceptres; on the reverse is a crowned single rose. The coin dates to c. 1636 - 1644 AD.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Postmedieval copper alloy buckle. One half remains of a double loop buckle. A similar example can be seen in 'Buckles 1250 -1800' by Ross Whitehead, page 54, number 303; another example is illustrated in 'Buckles through the Ages' by Chris Marshall, page 14, number 50, which is dated to the late 16th century (see below for reference details).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Postmedieval copper alloy buckle fragment. The fragment is part of a double loop frame with a moulded scallop motif at each side of the frame. A similar example can be seen in 'Buckles 1250 -1800' by Ross Whitehead, page 65, number 404. Another example is illustrated in 'Buckles through the Ages' by Chris Marshall, pages 13 & 14, number 43, which is dated c. 1550- 1650 AD (see below for reference details).

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: Post-Medieval gold posy ring. The ring is a plain band with a D-shaped section, undecorated on the exterior. The interior of the ring is engraved with the motto 'Let vertue rule affection'. The hoop has been slightly damaged, causing the hoop to be a little misshapen.As the hoop is slightly flattened, the original diameter of the ring is likely to be around 18mm. A very similar ring (2010 T440), from a neighbouring parish in Devon, was reported in 2010. The two rings have a very similar weight and diameter (2010 T440 weight- 2.04g; diameter 18mm). The rings both bear the same inscription and are written in a similar style. However, 2010 T440 bears a mark of a 'W' within a diamond; there is no maker's mark visible on 2011 T670. In absence of an identifiable maker's mark this ring cannot be dated to pre-1711, and as such falls outside the provisions of the Treasure Act 1996.

properties.title: POT
properties.description: Bronze pot leg, 16th - 18th century. Piece of a cast bronze pot leg with decoration. A single band has been cast above elongated curved mounds which cover the diameter of the pot leg. The break occurs through the mound decoration.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Copper alloy double loop buckle, 1500 - 1650. Double loop is in a oval shape with a lobed knop at either end of the strap bar. See Ross Whitehead 'Buckles 1250-1800' page 54, number 304 for similar.

properties.title: BELL
properties.description: Copper alloy crotal bell, 17th century. The bell is cast and joined together creating a raised median band. The top of the bell has two circular sound holes with single linear lined decoration in the form of a sunburst. The bottom halve of the bell can not be seen. Damage to the crotal bell has left a crack from one of the sound holes, down through the median band and into the base halve.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: A Post Medieval gold posy ring. Please see Treasure report below for details.Date: Probably 17th century - 18th CenturyDescription: The ring is a plain band with a D-shaped section, undecorated on the exterior. The interior of the ring is engraved with the motto 'Let vertue rule affection'. The hoop has been slightly damaged, causing the hoop to be a little misshapen.Discussion: As the hoop is slightly flattened, the original diameter of the ring is likely to be around 18mm. A very similar ring (2010 T440), from a neighbouring parish in Devon, was reported in 2010. The two rings have a very similar weight and diameter (2010 T440 weight- 2.04g; diameter 18mm). The rings both bear the same inscription and are written in a similar style. However, 2010 T440 bears a mark of a 'W' within a diamond; there is no maker's mark visible on 2011 T670.Weight: 1.81gLength and width: 17.7 mm x 19.5mmMetal content: In absence of an identifiable maker's mark this ring cannot be dated to pre-1711, and as such falls outside the provisions of the Treasure Act 1996.Danielle WoottonFinds Liaison Officer

properties.title: HORSE TRAPPING
properties.description: Modern horse brass fitting, probably dating to the early 20th century. It is stamped with the words on three lines; 'COLES/ MAKER/ OTTERY'. This record has been added as it is of local interest and contributes to the history of Ottery St Mary, Devon.

properties.title: POT
properties.description: Postmedieval pottery rim sherd of North devon coarseware from a jug. The sherd has a dark brown glaze on the interior. The exterior is decorated with imprints which are created by the potter making indentations into the clay with their thumb. A similar example can be seen in 'Medieval and Postmedieval Finds from Exeter 1971-1980' by John Allan, p 153, fig 67, number 2.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is very worn. It can be dated from the mid first to the second century AD.

properties.title: PIPE (SMOKING)
properties.description: Post-medieval clay pipe bowl, burnt after use

properties.title: PIPE (SMOKING)
properties.description: Post-medieval clay pipe bowl with large stem hole, probably locally made

properties.title: FLAKE
properties.description: A notched flint blade, probably Neolithic in date.The blade is sub-crescentic in plan, of triangular cross section and has a single notch, located near to the proximal end, where there is a bulb-of-percussion.

properties.title: SCRAPER (TOOL)
properties.description: A flint scraper of probable Neolithic date. The tool is roughly 'D' shaped in plan and has been made from a secondary flake. There is a flat thumb platform on top and abrupt retouch to the distal end.

properties.title: PIPE (SMOKING)
properties.description: A post-medieval clay pipe, patterned with masonic type glove, heart and rye pattern. The distal end of the stem has probably been lost.

properties.title: WATCH
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy pocket watch winder, with traces of gilt

properties.title: KEY (LOCKING)
properties.description: Post-medieval to modern copper-alloy barrel tap key.The oval bow is set at 90 degrees to the shaft. The bit is located at the base of the shaft and comprises a triangular-sectioned socket.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper-alloy handle from a chafing dish of late medieval to post-medieval date. The handle consists of a short rectangular element, which passes through a looped lug which it retains. From both ends of which emerge longer sides splay out at obtuse angles. These longer elements curve round at the basal corners and are connected by an incurved side. This sub-trapezoidal handle form has been classified by Lewis (1975) as his Type D1. The lug is thick and oval, with a collar at its attachment end. The handle is covered in diagonal file marks.The object measures 51 by 50 mm by up to 5 mm thick Similar handles can be found illustrated in Margeson (1993, 80; nos 489, 490).

properties.title: JEWS HARP
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy jews harp. The loop and parallel arms are of lozenge-shaped cross section, and there is a depression at the top of the loop, at which point the now-missing tongue would have been attached.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: Two medieval to post-medieval copper-alloy fragments from purse bars, terminal elements of Williams Class J, found together so presumably from the same bar. The bars probably have a circular cross-section for their entire lengths. They terminate in expanded spherical knobs decorated with engraved twisting grooves. Both have been bent at an angle at their other ends; they were probably broken at their junction with the block as a result of old damage.  Within the grooves the patina is notably dark and may be the remnants of a coating.Length: 48mm; Width: 12mmA similar purse bar can be found illustrated in Ward Perkins (1993, 167; fig. 52, no. B3). Purses of similar form but with globular terminals of a form similar to contemporary bells were found on the wreck of the Mary Rose which sank in 1545 (Gardiner and Allen 2005; fig. 3.7).

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A fragment of a cast copper-alloy pendent frame from a purse of late medieval to early post-medieval date. The fragment is curved, and broken at both ends where it would have been suspended from the purse bar. There are two circular sewing holes in the frame to attach it to the fabric of the purse. This upper face of the frame is shallowly rounded and at right angles to the attachment rim, looking like an inverted 'L' in cross-section. This upper surface is incised with trio of lines in a cross-hatched or lattice pattern. Some of these engraved lines retain niello. In the lozengiform gaps between the lines there is often a zig-zag motif done in wrigglework.This fragment measures 74 mm long by 10 mm wide and is 5 mm thick.The typology used for this decorated frame, referring to the Museum of London's collection, is Type A1, which is dated to the 15th century (see Ward-Perkins 1993, 164; fig. 51). Read (2001) illustrates a similar example on page 130, fig.84, no. 908, which is dated from c.1450-1500.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: A fragment of a copper-alloy medieval purse bar of Williams Class A2. One of the bar's arm's terminals survives, together with the separate rove at the terminal. From the lower side of the arm a semi-circular attachment plate protrudes, thinned compared to the arm, and perforated off centre; the arm is broken just beyond this tab as a result of old damage. On the faces of the arm, on a slightly thinned field, are the engraved letters 'EM' on one side, and 'N' on the other. The arm thickens towars the terminal, from which extends a waisted prong around which the flaring rove is located.Length: 39mm ; Width: 14mm ; Thickness: 10mm.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: Post-medieval silver spoon handle. Stamped 'ID' and handpunched 'ID', 'RT', and '1795'

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy pot fragment with two rivets.

properties.title: CAULDRON
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy cauldron or skillet leg.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: A cast copper-alloy leg from a medieval to post-Medieval cauldron or similar vessel.At the top of the remaining piece is a broad transverse ridge; below this is the foot, in which vertical grooves and ridges create the impression of multiple  toes.The foot has a flat underside.

properties.title: TOY
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy toy cannon

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy thimble

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy sewing ring, open at the top.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy thimble

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Post-medieval sheet copper alloy thimble with hand punched indentations

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Post-medieval sheet metal copper alloy thimble

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Medieval copper alloy beehive thimble

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval four ounce lead trade weight, stamped 'NA' & 'D........N'

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy coin weight for one guinea. Stamped '5' & '8'.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy guinea coin weight stamped '5DW, 6GR'.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval cast copper alloy weight for a Portuguese gold quarter. Moidore 1740-70. Marked 'S D 6.9' - the value in English. Same stamp on both sides.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval square coin weight for a Unite of James I. On the obverse is the King to the right, holding orb and sceptre with the legend 'I.R BRIT'. The reverse has crown over 'X X II' over  'S', to the right of the crown is a small crowned 'I'. In 1612, the Unite was revalued from 20 to 22 shillings.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy trade weight for 1oz. It is stamped centrally with the initials GR surmounted by a crown. It is therefore for George I-IV and dates to 1714-1826. It has a raised rim at the edge with a groove towards it edge. The weight has a central punch mark surrounded by successive concentric striations from the manufacturing process.It measures 30 mm in diameter and up to 5.5 mm thick. No mass is recorded; the suggestion that this is for an ounce is retained from the original record.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy halfounce trade weight.The weight is broadly discoidal, but a circumferential rim defines a recessed central area in which there is a ring-shaped groove and incuse ewer mark.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy trade weight for 2 oz. It is stamped at the cardinal points with the shield of the London Guildhall at 12 o'clock, an initial V surmounted by a crown at 3 o'clock, double struck, a ewer dividing the date 1826, in two equal parts, now worn, at 6 o'clock, and a capital letter A, for averdepois, at 9 o'clock. It is therefore for Victoria, and dates to 1837-1878, the end date given by the substitution of V for VR in 1878. It has a raised rim at the edge which has been squashed at one point. The weight has an engraved inner circle across which some of the marks extend slightly.It measures 36 mm in diameter and up to 9 mm thick. No mass is recorded; the suggestion that this is for an ounce is retained from the original record.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy 1oz cup weight, used for bullion. A stamp of a lion, representing the Goldsmith's company is stamped on the interior of the base.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy circular 1 ounce trade weight dating to 1879 to 1891 with a thick raised rim. It is stamped 1 / OZ. with the numeral at the centre of the weight within an engraved inner circle. Above this is the word DEVON, the letters in a circle, encircling X/1. Either side of this latter, set at an angle is the shield of the London Guildhall, to the left, and a crowned G, to the right. Either side of the letters OZ, at a similar angle, is a capital A and a ewer, respectively.The trade weight is 29 mm in diameter and up to 7 mm thick; unfortunately no mass was recorded.The dating is based on the reorganisation of the local weights and measures districts to coincide with local police divisions in 1879. X1 was a newly created district relating to Woodbury (part of Exeter) (http://www.maths.lse.ac.uk/Personal/norman/DEV.pdf). Such districts only lasted until 1891.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy weight.The discoidal weight has three concentric grooves on its upper surface and an incuse pellet at the centre; stamped over these grooves, in negative relief, are the uppercase letters ' B M,' with a crown above.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy trade weight of Charles I or II

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy trade weight from the reign of Charles I (1625-1649) or Charles II (1660-1685). The weight is circular with a wide raised rim on the top. Its front has numerous concentric rings from manufacture around a central punch mark and groove.It is 33 mm in diameter by up to 6 mm thick.  Unfortunately no mass has been recorded.It would have originally been part of a set of weights and bears official marks showing it was made in London and verified by the founders' company allowing it to be used in markets and shops as an official weight. A crowned letter C (for Charles I or II) and the sword of St Paul (for London) are clustered at around 12 o'clock, an ewer (for the founders' company who had a Royal charter to verify trade weights) is located at 6 o'clock.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy disc-shaped trade weight. At the centre is a stamped Plantaganet crown and there are three grooved concentric circles on around the outer edge.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is sub-rectangular in plan, with inward-bowing long sides and a projecting knop at either end, the right-hand one surrounded by a V-shaped moulding.The nature of the reverse is uncertain as this piece was recorded from a photograph.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A Post Medieval cast copper alloy mount. In plan, the mount is shaped like a flower with six petals radiating from a central raised circle. The reverse of the mount has two lugs for attachment.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount with tinned, flat, upper surface and bevelled edges.The central portion of the mount is sub-trapezoidal; a smaller trapezium projects from the base of this central area; an oval portion surmounts it and this,in turn, is surmounted by a trapezoidal knop.As this find was recorded from a photograph, nothing is known about the reverse.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is of elongated-sub-cordate  shape and flat section. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is not known.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A copper-alloy hooked strap mount of post-medieval date.The attachment plate is shield shaped and contains the in situ remains of two corroded iron rivets. The hook extends downwards from the base of the plate, the junction between the two elements marked by a side loop and the remains of a second, opposing, loop.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount takes the form of a flower head and is sub-circular in plan. On the upper surface, a moulded central pellet is surrounded by a ring of five further such pellets; several longer, curved, petals form a circumferential border. As this find was recorded from a photograph, the nature of the reverse is unknown, but it appears to have at least one integral rivet.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is in the form of a quatrefoil, with four smaller projections between the four main petals. The upper surface is convex. As this object was recorded from a photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The central portion of the mount takes the form of a flower head with moulded petals. At opposing ends of the sub-oval centre, there is a projecting lobe.A single integral rivet survives on the reverse.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is sub-triangular in plan, with a 'bulge' at the centre of the horizontal end.Two integral rivets project from the reverse.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy toggle.The upper portion of the object is oval in plan, with a convex upper surface and has a collar at both the top and bottom ends. Immediately above the bottom collar, there is a single perforation, probably representing a rivet hole. A narrower arm projects straight downwards from beneath the lower collar; this arm terminates in an oval head with flat upper surface.

properties.title: DRESS HOOK
properties.description: An incomplete post-medieval copper-alloy dress hook with a punched (presumably intended to be pierced) circular plate, integral rectangular loop and long hook. It is unclear as to whether the recurving hook is complete. At the opposing end the loop is missing part of its corner; otherwise it seems to have a bevelled outer edge, as does the hook. The plate, located between these elements, is circular with a thin raised cross and central pellet on its front; the ends of the arms meet a raised circular border. Outside this border the edge is beaded apart from below the loop where the beading is far smoother and less pronounced. In each quarter of the cross on the plate are four circular piercings, one close to the centre and three on the outer edge. On this example the piercings are either blind or filled with soil.It measures 32 mm long by 16 mm wide and 3 mm thick.There are various similar examples on the database including NLM-9DA783 and SOM-570111. Read (2008, 99; no. 370) illustrates a similar example and catogorises this type as Early Post Medieval Class E, Type 3 and suggests they date from c. 1500-1625, with most being used c. 1500-1550, with possibly some residual use into the 18th century. On the published example, not all of the holes have been pierced through the plate; none have here.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is roughly 'bow' shaped, having concave long sides between two sub-hexagonal ends. The flat upper surface retains traces of a white metal coating. Two integral rivets project from the reverse.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is circular in plan  and  decorated by an incuse equal-arm cross with tinned or silvered surface, traces of which survive. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A post-Medieval to modern copper-alloy mount, possibly for use on furniture.The head of the mount is of pointed-oval shape with a convex upper surface and an integral rivet on the reverse.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy mount.The mount takes the form of a relief-moulded or stamped flower head with six pointed-oval petals radiating from the centre and a series of rounded petals around the perimeter. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy mount .The head of the mount takes the form of a cuboid, the upper surface decorated by a saltire of ring-and-dot punchmarks. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the underside is uncertain.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A medieval topost-Medieval copper-alloy mount.The head of the mount is circular in plan, its domed upper surface covered in moulded pellet decoration. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: HOOKED TAG
properties.description: Part of a post-Medieval copper-alloy hooked tag.The surviving piece represents the upper part of the body from a tubular hooked tag. It has a U-shaped cross section with  two concave longitudinal panels on its upper surface, separated from one another by a grooved ridge. An openwork projection at the base is the start of the otherwise missing hook element.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
