properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy strap mount.The mount is rectangular in plan, its upper surface decorated by a longitudinal line of pelleted ovals, linked end-to-end, each with an incuse oval at its centre. Flanking this line are two parallel lines of partial grooved oval motifs with interspersing ring-and-dot symbols.The mount has a 90 degree downward bend at either end. The surfaces retain traces of a white metal coating.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount is acorn-shaped in plan, with a convex upper surface. The cupule is decorated with cross-hatched grooves and has a short stalk at the base. The projecting nut is smooth-surfaced, its outward-bowing sides converging towards an apex knop. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: A copper-alloy mount of probable post-Medieval date.The mount has been roughly cut from a piece of sheet metal and is in the shape of an isosceles triangle. Close to each of the three corners  is the in situ head of a copper-alloy rivet.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The head of the mount comprises a triangular plate with a series of transverse ridges and interspersing grooves on its upper surface.On the reverse are four integral rivets, one located at each corner, with the final one near to the centre. Two of the rivets have been bent over, presumably to secure the mount to the now-missing strap.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: A post-medieval copper-alloy book clasp.The object comprises two sub-rectangular plates, between which is part of a leather strap. The plates have inward-bowing long sides and flare at the top, where the upper plate bears feather-like indentations.The upper end of the top plate has broken, at the point of a row of three circular perforations, but the two plates remain held together by two in situ copper-alloy rivets. A third, larger, rivet is situated at the bottom end of the clasp, immediately above the narrower, rearward hook.

properties.title: CANDLE HOLDER
properties.description: A copper-alloy object which probably represents the ejector 'key' from an early-post-medieval candle holder. The upper part of the object comprises three joined loops, the uppermost of which is surmounted by a vertical knop. A grooved stem projects vertically downwards from the base of these loops.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: The upper plate from a late medieval to early post-medieval copper-alloy book clasp.The object consists of a sub-rectangular plate which flares towards a toothed top side and has a broad rearward hook at its base. There is a rivet hole near the top and one near the bottom, both of which are surrounded by concentric grooves. A short distance above the lower rivet hole is an irregular perforation which may be a casting flaw. A number of unidentifiable punchmarks decorate the upper surface of the plate.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: A copper-alloy plate from a medieval or post-medieval copper-alloy book clasp.The piece consists of a sub-rectangular plate which retains one of its long sides and is irregular on its opposite, damaged, side. The intact side is decorated by a border of punched double triangles.The intact bottom end has a broad rearward hook and two adjacent punched borders, one of pellets, the other of incuse rectangles.Located just off-centre is a rivet hole surrounded by concentric grooves.

properties.title: STRAP FITTING
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy strap mount.The piece is heart-shaped in plan and of flat section. On the upper surface, the edge has been obliquely grooved, creating a ropework border. Close to the top is the in situ head of a copper-alloy rivet. A depression, located a short distance up from the bottom point, was probably intended to mark the location for the attachment of a second such rivet, but this was never added.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy one-piece button with star and fleuret pattern, in negative relief, on the upper surface of the circular, plano-convex head.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post-Medieval lead-alloy button.The head is circular in plan, its domed upper surface decorated with a moulded flower head design comprising five petals around a central ring and pellet. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval copper alloy spherical button.The button is formed of two hemispheres, joined together at the middle, with a vent hole near the top. The apex wire loop has been soldered on.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy button.The head is circular in plan, its upper surface decorated with a stamped flower head design comprising a series of incuse crescentic petals interspersed with at least three ring-and-dot marks. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post Medieval copper alloy button. The button is circular in plan and is decorated on the front face with a sunburst pattern at the centre and a border of circlets around the circumference. The surface of the button is silvered with approximately 90 percent of the silvering remaining.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post-Medieval copper-alloy one-piece button.The umbonate head has a number of ring-and-dot punchmarks on its upper surface. The integral loop projects backwards from the hollow underside.

properties.title: BUTTON

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A copper alloy Post Medieval Royal Artillery button. The button is circular in plan and depicts three cannons above each other set within a shield, and three circlets within the top band of the shield.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A Post Medieval silver plated or tinned livery button showing the Drake family motif. The inscription reads 'ADVILLIO DIVINO'.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Modern silver plated livery button.The domed circular head bears a relief-moulded coat-of-arms in which a crowned lozenge-shaped shield is flanked by two unidentified supporters.On the reverse, arranged in two concentric circles, are the name and address of the maker: (illegible)SONS/CONDUIT ST/ 153 STRAND: LONDON.

properties.title: BUTTON

properties.title: BUCKLE

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A silver penny of Charles I, dating to the period 1625-1642. Tower mint under the king. This is  possibly a contemporary copy as the encircling is misaligned.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A modern button from the London and South Western Railway company (1838 - 1922).The button is made from three joined elements. The top of the head is circular in plan, domed, with a hollow undersideand folded rim. It bears a relief-moulded coat-of-arms, around which is the legend, 'LONDON & SOUTH WESTERN RAILWAY', extending clockwise from 7 o'clock. The back of the button comprises a circular plate with a ring of illegible text. The third element, the wire loop, has been attached by pushing the ends through a hole in the back plate.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post-Medieval to modern livery button.The domed upper surface of the circular head bears the relief-moulded image of an unidentified quadruped standing left on a rope, with a cross behind. A rim extends around the circumference and the surface has been gilded. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval silver-plated copper-alloy livery button with sailing ship design.The  galley, which is depicted sailing left, is a relief-moulded design and occupies most of the upper surface of the button's discoidal head. Much of the white metal coating survives.As this button was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is a dupondius of the emperor Vespasian (69 - 79 AD). Obverse: Bust/head right; Reverse: [SECVRITAS AVGVSTI S C]

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Gilt copper-alloy livery button with cockerel motif, post-Medieval in date.The head is circular in plan, its domed upper surface bearing the relief-moulded image of a cockerel standing left on a rope.A wire loop has been soldered on to the back, with a crown motif above and, surrounding, in a ring, the legend 'Firmin & Sons Strand London'.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A modern copper-alloy button, said to be from King's College Hospital, London.The head of the button is circular, its domed upper surface bearing a relief-moulded coat-of-arms, around which is an illegible legend. An attached wire loop is located at the centre of the concave reverse, surrounded by the name and address of the maker: 'FIRMIN & SONS/ 153 STRAND LONDON'.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval tombac button with partial hand engraving.The head of the button is discoidal, its upper surface decorated by an engraved design. Eight triangular panels, each with crossed-hatched infill, point inwards from around around  the edge, creating a star-shaped central area. At the centre of this star is a stylised sunburst, comprised of a ring-shaped groove, from which radiate several straight grooves. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval lead-alloy pimple button.The head is circular in plan,with an upper half of flattened-conical form, terminating in a moulded apex pellet. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the underside is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval engraved-patterned tombac button.The head of the button is circular in plan, its domed upper surface decorated by four abutting triangles with double groove sides and partial infill of angled grooves.As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post-medieval engraved white metal button.The circular head has a central boss, around which are concentric rings of  intricate engine engraved wavy lines. As this find was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: A post-Medieval white metal button with engine-turned design.The upper surface of the discoidal head bears an engraved flower head design. As this button was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON

As this button was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

properties.title: BUTTON

As this button was recorded from a single photograph, the nature of the reverse is uncertain.

The token is decorated with initials in capitals A H, on one side, and T D on the other.It has a white/grey patina and is complete.  It measures 22 mm in diameter and 2 mm in thickness.

The reverse of the medalion appears to be blank, apart from an illegible inscription, located on the slightly raised circumferential rim. There is no remaining trace of a suspension loop. This piece probably dates from the 18th or 19th century.

properties.title: SEAL
properties.description: Post Medieval Russian flax bale seal.The original record suggested a date of 1727 and this has been left although it is unusually early for such seals.Throughout the 18th and 19th centuries Russia was a prominent exporter of flax. Lead bale seals were used as a means of identification and as a component of regulation and quality control. Russian seals of this type were used as a means to monitor and ensure the quality of flax hemp products from Russia. They were applied individually by a port inspector and gave unique information like the inspector's name, the post where they worked, the name of the port, the initials of the previous grower/owner or agent, the quality and grade of the flax and the date it was graded (Sullivan 2000:211-227).

properties.title: SEAL
properties.description: Post Medieval Russian flax bale seal dated to 1820 on the seal.Throughout the 18th and 19th centuries Russia was a prominent exporter of flax. Lead bale seals were used as a means of identification and as a component of regulation and quality control. Russian seals of this type were used as a means to monitor and ensure the quality of flax hemp products from Russia. They were applied individually by a port inspector and gave unique information like the inspector's name, the post where they worked, the name of the port, the initials of the previous grower/owner or agent, the quality and grade of the flax and the date it was graded (Sullivan 2000:211-227).

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: Medieval or post-medieval lead cloth seal. 'T' over 'O' on one side, portcullis design on the other side.Egan (1985: 9) notes that the portcullis was "the main design for alnage seals in the late Tudor period... and continued in use into the early seventeenth century", however the design does appear to have occured on later seals, for example DENO-681C35 and no. 151 published by Egan (ibid: 178) from the reign of Queen Anne. The alnage taxation system ended in 1724 (ibid: 4).

properties.title: SHOE
properties.description: Post-medieval assortment of concealed items.This collection of concealed items was found within a section of cob-wall above the doorway of a Topsham townhouse. The collection includes three shoe fragments, shells and pebbles, pieces of clay pipe, bone, oyster shell, slag, coal, fragments of south Somerset Donyatt Ware, and a fragment of glass.The practise of placing a shoe within the structure of the walls, particularly over doorways or inside chimneys, was common in 16th and 17th century house building. As was the practise of concealing elaborate artefacts, or multiple associated artefacts, as 'witch deposits'. The University of Southampton website: http://www.concealedgarments.org suggests: "These objects may have been concealed as a protective device to ward off evil and other maleficent forces or they may have been used as counter-magic to deflect a curse or other negative circumstance, such as illness or economic blight considered to be the consequence of malevolent spirits or witches, e.g. the use of witch bottles, charms and curses. The objects may also have been viewed as 'lucky things', perhaps heirlooms from an ancestor or from another person considered to be spiritually powerful and so they were perceived as lucky for the household. Or did builders constructing or altering a building or the householders themselves just want to leave their 'mark'?"

properties.title: COIN HOARD
properties.description: 2008T102 Exeter, Devon REPORT TO H M CORONER Circumstances of Discovery On 8 February 2008, archaeologists working for Exeter Archaeology discovered 22 copper alloy coins during controlled excavations. The coins All of the coins were heavily mineralised and in extremely fragile condition. However, ten of the 22 could be at least partially identified. The earliest appears to be a copper as of Augustus (c. 23 BC-AD 14), while the latest identifiable issues are of the reign of Claudius (AD 41-54). Although the remaining 12 coins were far too corroded to allow any identification, there was nothing to suggest that the hoard post-dated the Julio-Claudian period. That said a later first century (or even second century) deposition date cannot be ruled out. This group is extremely unusual for a hoard of Roman copper alloy coins due to the inclusion of such early types.The coins can be summarised as follows: Augustus (probable) 1 Claudius 6 Antonia 2 Claudius (possible) 1 Uncertain 12 Total 22 Age, number and metal The coins easily satisfy the criteria of the Treasure Act with regard to their age, metal and quantity; being more than 300 years old, struck in copper alloy and being more than ten in number. Of the same find? The circumstances of discovery make it clear that the coins were all deposited together in antiquity. Furthermore, the archaeological context suggests that the coins were deposited as part of a cremation burial. A number of other Roman artefacts, including glass, pottery, metalwork and organics were discovered from the same archaeological context (comprising archaeological context nos. 3053-56). The material listed on the attached document should all be considered Treasure by association with the coins. Conclusion I conclude that this find constitutes a prima facie case of treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act (1996).Ian Leins Curator of Iron Age and Roman coins The Department of Coins and Medals The British Museum 10 June 2008

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy Roman coin. The coin is a sestertius dating to the first or second century AD. As the coin is badly worn, it is difficult to identify further. On the obverse is a head facing right. The head is possibly a female with a bun at the back of the head. THe two letters VC are visible around the circumference of the coin. The reverse, again badly worn, shows a standing draped female figurefacing right.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A copper-alloy Roman coin. The coin is very worn on the obverse, but it is just possible to see the emperor facing right, wearing a  radiate crown. The reverse is also worn, but it is possible to see the letters SC. In between these letters stands a figure with left knee bent, holding a sword, left. At the right of the figure is a long item, possibly a spear or a standard. The figure is slightly oddly proportioned, and therefore the coin may be a barbarous copy.

properties.title: BOTTLE
properties.description: Postmedieval fragment from a glass bottle. The circular fragment is dark green in colour and reads 'I Skinner 1736'. Bottles were provided with a seal for several reasons such as to indicate the contents of the bottle, to commemorate a well-known person, or to identify the owner of the bottle. In this example, the seal probably bears the name of the owner of the bottle. Further research may  identify 'I Skinner'.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: Postmedieval lead alloy cloth seal dating to the 17th century. The seal bears the London coat of arms with the words 'De Londino'. The seal was found during excavations at Exeter Quay House. The seal is interesting as it shows evidence of Exeter's once famous woollen cloth industry. The quay house was rebuilt in 1680 - 1681 so that cloth and other goods could be stored before they were loaded onto boats and shipped down Exeter canal. the seal shows evidence of trade between the city of Exeter and the city of London during the 1600's. A similar seal is illustrated in Geoff Egan's paper on Cloth seals please see reference for details.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin. The coin is a nummus of Constantine II as Caesar (AD 317-337). The coin was found by a primary school pupil from Devon. Information for schools:The coin was made between the years 330 and 335 AD. This makes the coin nearly one thousand and seven hundred years old.The obverse (or the 'heads') of the coin show Constantine 'the second' wearing armour on his shoulders. The emperor is wearing a laurel wreath on his head. The words on the coin are in Latin, which was the language spoken by the Romans. The words translate into English as  'Constantine Junior, most noble Caesar'. The reverse (or the 'tails') of the coin shows two Roman soldiers with two military standards. Military standards were tall poles with different symbols on. Different units of the Roman army had their own standard. In battle, one of the soldiers would carry the standard in front so that the other soldiers could follow him.The Latin words on the reverse of the coin translate into English as 'The Glorious Army'.At the bottom of the coin are some letters. These letters are important because they show where the coin was made. The letters or 'mintmark' show us that this coin was made in a place called Nicomedia. Nicomedia is the ancient name for a city now called Izmit, in Western Turkey.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Post medieval silver coin. The coin is a two stuiver piece, minted in Kampen, the Netherlands. The obverse depicts a lion advancing left in between a '2' and 'S'. The 'S' stands for 'Stivers'. The reverse of the coin reads 'CAM/PEN/1678'.

properties.title: TOILET ARTICLE
properties.description: Copper alloy zoomorphic fragment.possibly a nail cleaner- flat fragment in shape of animals head- possibly snake with forked tongue or bird with open beak. The head is decorated with ibncisions on both sides wit details of circular eye, three marks along the neck at the bottomand an incision along the indentation of the beak or forked tongue. As the terminal is quite sharp, it is possible that it may have been used for something like a nail cleaner.

The weight is worn, but it is just possible to see two leopards or lions either side of a ship with a flag. The other side of the weight is blank.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Probably a Late Medieval Venetian silver soldino probably of Doge Agostin Barbarigo (1486-1501). Late type (LAVS TIBI SOLI reverse type). The soldino was known as the galyhalpens (galley-halfpence) as it was brought by the annual Venetian trading fleets. The soldino was about the size of English halfpennies and was popular because of a contemporary lack of small change: soldini in fact occur as English finds more often than proper halfpennies of the period.

properties.title: CAULDRON

Traces of orange-brown glaze can be seen on the interior. There are no traces of sooting. The bowl is South Somerset ware type; the type can be seen illustrated in J Allan, p152, Figure 66, type 3F.

properties.description: Post medieval pottery fragment. The fragment is from the handle of a South Somerset ware chamber pot, dating to the 17th Century. The rim and the interior of the pot has a green/brown glaze with a zig zag pattern scratched in to the surface of the rim for decoration. See J Allan p 151, fig 65, type 6B for an example.

properties.title: SCRAPER (TOOL)
properties.description: A flint hollow scraper of probable Neolithic or Early Bronze Age date. It has been made from a tertiary flake (no cortex remaining on the dorsal surface) of dark greyish-brown flint. It is fresh and probably complete. Part of the bulb of percussion has been removed by retouch but the bulbar scar and clear ripples suggest the use of a hard hammer. One lateral side has been retouched to create a concave scraping edge. The retouch is short and abrupt.Dimensions: 36.3mm by 19mm by 7.1mmWeight: 4.9g

properties.title: BRACELET
properties.description: A Roman bracelet of simple circular form with a slender, circular-sectioned hoop. The three surviving fragments do not quite complete the bracelet. One of the fragments incorporates one end of the coiled slide, by means of which the bracelet was expanded or compressed.Although described by the finder as silver the bracelet is of copper alloy, with a very slightly tin-enriched surface.Date: 3rd-4th century AD.Dimensions: c. 45mm. diameter.

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: 2007 T117: Medieval gilded silver finger-ring from Pinhoe, Devon.Description: A medieval gilded silver finger-ring with flat hoop and separately applied quatrefoil bezel. The outside of the hoop is decorated with engraved patterns which are very similar to those seen on a 12th- to 13th-century gilded silver ring from Thearne, Yorkshire (2002 T301), featured in the PAS Annual Report, 2002. The quatrefoil decoration is similar to a16th-century ring from Parnham, Suffolk (2003 T319) which is featured in the PAS 2003 Annual Report. Two of the petals on the quatrefoil are broken away and the gilding has worn away in places.Date: 14th or 15th century,Dimensions: Diameter: 21mm Width: 4.3mm Thickness: 1mm Weight: 2.83gIn terms of age and as the object contains a minimum of 10% precious metal it qualifies as Treasure under the stipulations of the Treasure Act 1996.Danielle Wootton Archaeological Finds Liaison Officer for Devon 01/03/2007

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: Medieval gold finger-ring found during archaeological excavations at Princesshay, Exeter. Below is the treasure report for the ring. The ring was allocated the Treasure reference 2006 T52GOLD FINGER-RING FROM PRINCESSHAY EXCAVATIONS, EXETER, DEVON15th-century gold posy ring. The Norman French inscription 'mon coeur entier' ('my whole heart') is engraved on the exterior in blackletter, set with white enamel, of which fragments remain. A foliate design is engraved between the script. The interior of the hoop is plain.Similar rings have been reported to the Portable Antiquities Scheme, and are recorded in the Treasure Annual reports listed below. Another ring of similar date and form, found in Sherford, Devon is reported by Cherry (1991); a further example of this type was found at Woodbury, Devon, which is now held at the Royal Albert Memorial Museum, Exeter.Report by John Allan and Danielle WoottonDiameter: 18.5mm Thickness: 1.20mm Width: 3.77mm Weight: 3.37gReferences: Cherry, J. 1991, 'A gold ring from Sherford', Proceedings of the Devon Archaeological Society 49, p148 Treasure Annual Report 2003: 2003 T285 Treasure Annual Report 2004: 2004 T64.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: An incomplete cast copper alloy T-shape brooch of early Roman date. The brooch measures 22mm by 46.3mm by 7.5mm and weighs 16.3g. The broadly cylindrical wings conceal the axis bar for the (missing) hinged pin. The bow projects forward from the bow and narrows gradually to the point where it has broken. It is decorated with a flat broad ridge which has three grooved transverse lines adjacent to the break. The lower bow and catchplate are missing.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Post Medieval silver 8 Reales coin dating to 1689. The 8 Real was often referred to as a 'piece of eight' and has long been popularly associated with Pirates in literature and films. This coin was minted at the famous Potosi silver mine in Bolivia, one of several New World mints set up by the Spanish. Because the Spanish Real was a very stable unit of currency, the coins were used all over the known world. The obverse shows symbols of Spain: a cross with a castle in the top left and bottom right, and a lion in the top right and bottom left. On the reverse are two pillars, symbolising the Pillars of Hercules, or the Straights of Gibraltar. The pillars intersect three lines of text which read: Top line: P 8 VR (P= the mintmark, Potosi; 8= the denomination of the coin ie 8 reales; VR= the initials of the assayer, or person checking the silver) Middle line: PLUS ULTRA (A latin motto adopted by Charles I of Spain meaning 'Further Beyond'). Bottom line: VR 8 P (A repeat of the top line, but with the assayer initials and the mint mark the other way around)

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy dupondius, possibly of Hadrian (117-38), type uncertain, mint of Rome, 117-38.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy Roman coin. The coin is a Centenionalis of Flavius Magnus Magnentius (AD 350-353).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy Roman coin. The coin is an Contantinian Ae3 dating to AD 324-330.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy Roman coin. The coin is a Sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and dates to AD 161-180.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy rose farthing of Charles I.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Silver coin of the Indian State of Hyderabad: Nasir ad-Daula of Hyderabad (AH 1244-73/AD 1829-57), first series, issued in the name of the Mughal emperor Muhammad Akbar II AH 1244-52/Ad 1829-36).

properties.title: MICROLITH
properties.description: Mesolithic flint microlith. The microlith is obliquely blunted, and has been broken at one end. It would originally have measured about 35-40mm. Microliths of this size and form date to the early Mesolithic period, around 8000-7000 BC.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin of the Emperor Trajan.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: Late Roman copper alloy crossbow brooch, 63mm long and 42mm wide. The brooch is in fair condition with a brown patina and weighs 31.09 grams. The brooch begins with terminal knob which has a form made up of two pyramids joined together at the base. This has a protruding knop of similar form. This sits above a rectangular sectioned wing which has a stepped front edge, causing it to narrow towards the terminal knobs. These knobs are hexagonally sectioned with a sub triangular form similar to the central terminal. These knobs, which are integral, form the most complex part of the brooch. The bow is sub triangular in section, having a flattened front edge and is decorated only on this central part with diagonal incised decoration, resembling ropework. The bow is of similar length to the foot which tapers slightly outwards towards its base. This is decorated with two lines of sub rectangular depressions running down its outer edges. In between these there is faint decoration which appears to be a line of cup and ring incisions. The pin and the catchplate are intact. The brooch appears to be a composite of several known types.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy farthing trade token. The token, dated to 1664, was issued by Anthony Potter, a clothier in Exeter, Devon. Obverse: '*ANTHONY POTTER*' around the circumference; a pair of scales stamped in the centre. Reverse: '*IN* EXON* 1664*'; the initilas 'AP' stamped in the centre.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy farthing trade token dating to 1664. The token was issued by John Cogan of St Martin's Gate in Exeter. Obverse:'*IOHN COGAN* 64' stamped around the circumference with 'EXO' in the centre. Reverse:' *At St Martin's Gate' In the centre, the initial C is stamped above the initials I and B.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Post medieval silver hammered Spanish Real of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella of Spain (AD 1474-1504). The obverse bears the quartered arms of Castille and Leon and Aragon and Sicily. On the reverse is stamped a yoke (King Ferdinand's symbol) and a bundle of arrows (Queen Isabella's symbol).

properties.title: DRESS HOOK
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy dress hook.

properties.title: BOOK FITTING
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy book clasp.

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy 'Hans Schultz' jetton.

properties.title: APOTHECARY WEIGHT
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy apothocary's weight, weighing two scruples. The weight is a circular disc shape. Around the circumference, on either side, are the words 'Two Scruples' at teh top, and 'II * S' at eth bottom. In the centre, on either side, are markings which are too worn to decipher.

properties.title: HARNESS FITTING
properties.description: Iron Age to Roman copper alloy terret. The ring is oval in plan with two mouldings on the bar. Both sides of the ring are decorated with punched dot decoration on the side opposite the mouldings. There are traces of red enamel surviving on each side of the moulding. Around the outside edge are a series of incised lines running along the circumference. See PAS annual Report 2004/5 p32-33.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy coin of the House of Constantine.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy As of Trajan (AD 98-117.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Fragment of a nummus of the House of Constantine, AD 335-340Mint of Lyons or Arles, AD 335-340(10)/14mm; 0.86g; DA12Obverse: illegible; rosette diademed bust rightReverse: GLORIA EXERCITVS; two soldiers standing either side of one standard with Chi-Rho (P superimposed over X)Mintmark: off flanCondition: corroded, but little wear: Very FineReferences:RIC VII, p. 276, no. 395ffRIC VIII, p. 178, no. 4ff

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy As, probably of Vespasian (AD 69-79)Mint unknown, but probably Rome26mm; 6.92g; DA6Obverse: illegible; laureate head/bust rightReverse: illegible, S C; figure standing left, holding ?pateraCondition: very corroded

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy sestertius of the 2nd century AD, Hadrian to Marcus AureliusMint of Rome, c. 117-18029mm; 17.05g; DA12Obverse: illegible; bearded bust rightReverse:  illegible; figure standing left, at altarCondition: very corroded

properties.title: HORSE TRAPPING
properties.description: Medieval Copper-alloy horse harness stud in the shape of a trefoil.

properties.title: BUTTON
properties.description: Post medieval copper alloy button. Stamped with the letters 'ECS', probably refering to Exeter Cathedral School. A similar button is in the Royal Albert Memorial Museum archives.

properties.title: FLAKE
properties.description: Collection of seven flint flakes: 1)Pale grey flint 47mmx 5mm x 20mm 2)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 44mm x 30mm x 7mm 3)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 61mm x 33mm x 5mm 4)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 58mm x 30mm x 8mm 5)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 50mm x 30mm x 7mm 6)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 44mm x 14mm x 3mm 7)Mid brown flint with grey flecks 37mm x 15mm x 5mm

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: A copper alloy angel (ten shillings) coin weight from the reign of Charles I. The circular coin weight has a diameter of 17.6mm, a thickness of 2.4mm and weighs 3.76g. Its original weight would have been 4.2g (Withers and Withers 1995, p. 14). On the obverse there is a crown with X, for ten, and s for shillings beneath. On the reverse is a depiction of an angel. The coin weight must date from between the start of the reign of Charles I in 1625 and 1642, when the angel denomination ceased to be issued (Withers and Withers 1995, p. 68).

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: A copper alloy jetton produced at Lille, France in 1541. Mitchiner's no. 897 (p. 289).

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Small fragment of samian ware measuring 20mm by 10mm and 3mm in thickness.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Rim sherd of Saintonage ware with small traces of green glaze on the exterior. Probably of a 14th century date.

properties.title: LITHIC IMPLEMENT
properties.description: Small uniplatform core with two removal scars.

properties.title: TILE
properties.description: An incomplete Medieval ceramic inlaid floor tile, dating from AD 1300 to 1330, depicting a fish. The tile was originally square in shape with two flat faces and four sides. The tile is now broken into a broadly right-angled triangular shape with approximnately 50 percent of the tile now missing. The front face depicts a fish motif within a steeply arched border in cream slip; a round eye, slightly down-turned mouth and curved gill are depicted 'negatively' in brown. There are traces of lead glaze remaining on the front surface. The back face and sides are plain. This tile is highly likely to be from the nearby Medieval Priory of St Katherine at Polsloe, Exeter. John Allan identifies the tile as 'Allan and Keen design 25; the commonest form discovered at Polsloe Priory during excavations in 1976 - 1978. Monastery floors were sold locally as building materials, and often moved after the Reformation, which may reflect why the tile was discovered some distance from, yet still within the vicinity of the priory. Similar tiles can be seen in St Andrew's chapel in Exeter Cathedral. These tiles were certainly made close to Exeter, but the kiln site has not been found'. (John Allan, pers comm 22/4/14).In 2009 an archaeological evaluation revealed 9 Medieval tile fragments, dating from the 13th to early 14th centuries AD, which were discovered within the curtilage of the Priory (Parnell 2009: Exeter Archaeology Report Number 09.92). Medieval tiles such as this were produced by setting clay into a square frame, to form the square shape of the tile. Then the design or motif was stamped into the soft clay, forming an impression. The stamped impression was infilled with a white slip, and the whole surface was levelled off with a wire in order to reveal and define the motif, which would contrast in white against the brown clay background. The tile was then coated in lead glaze and fired in a kiln.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy rose farthing of Charles I (1625-1649). The coin is worn and fragments of it have broken away. The obverse depicts sceptres below c crown asnd the inscription :[CAROLUS] DG MAG [BRI] [FRA] ET [HI REX]. The reverse depicts a rose and is very worn. Spink number 3207.

properties.title: STYLUS
properties.description: Lead alloy object of unknown date, possibly a stylus. The four-faceted object flattens to a two-faced edge at one end, at the other end of the object, the four faces taper to a point.  Length 55.5mm; Thickness 5.29mm ; Width 5.90mm; Weight 12.12g. Another similar object (DEV-973C97) was found nearby.

properties.title: STYLUS
properties.description: Lead alloy object of unknown date, possibly a stylus. the object has four faces. One end is slightly flattened and wedge shaped, the shaft tapers to a point at the other end. Length: 50.5mm; Width 11.5mm tapering to a point of 3mm; Thickness 7.5mm. A similar object (DEV-973C97)was found nearby.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: Copper alloy 'seal top' knop from a spoon. A similar knop (in pewter) is illustrated in Egan 2005, p 116, number 570. Egan (2005, p118) notes that copper alloy spoons were usually flat stemmed with plain tops, or hexagonal stems with slip tops. This would make this copper alloy seal top spoon knop unusual. The seal top spoon in Egan was found with pottery dating between 1600-1750. It is therefore probable that this spoon knop is of a similar date. Length 35mm; Diameter (of 'seal')12mm; Weight 6.56g.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Elizabeth I silver sixpence; 3rd issue. Dated 1565. On the obverse is a crowned bust facing left with a rose to the right.The inscription reads: ELIZABETH.D.G. AN.FR.ET.HI REGINA (Elizabeth, by the grace of God, Queen of England, France and Ireland). On the reverse is a long cross fourchee, with the date '1565' above a shield. The reverse inscription reads: POSUI DEU(S) ADIUTOREM MEU(M). (I have made God my helper). A rose mint mark appears before both the obverse and reverse inscriptions.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Edward III silver groat. The inscription is difficult to read as the coin appears to have been double struck.It is possible to read 'EDWARD' on the obverse, the forward facing bust is surrounded by nine tressures and has four pellets in a diamond formation at each shoulder. The reverse is a long cross with three pellets in each angle at the centre. The inscription reads CIVITAS LONDON, the outer inscription has the legend: '[P]OSUI DEUS ADIVTORE MEUM'. (I have made God my helper).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Silver Penny of Charles I. Obverse: King's head facing left with the inscription: (CARO)LUS DG M. B. F ET. H: REX. (Charles, by the grace of God, King of Great Britain, France and Ireland).The reverse is very worn, however it is possible to read the letters 'IUSTIT'. The rest of the inscription would have read: IUSTITIA THRONUM FIRMAT (Justice strengthens the throne). Overall, the coin is worn and has been clipped.

properties.title: FIGURINE
properties.description: A Medieval copper alloy figurative mount, produced in Limoges, dating to c. AD 1150-1250. The body of the mount is consists of a transversely convex, sub-rectangular plate of copper alloy, rounded at one end. From the apex of the rounded end projects a sub-rectangular, three-dimensionally moulded human head, the eyes depicted by two small blue glass inlays. The figurine depicts a robed figure, with the folds of its robes highlighted with enamel inlaid decoration. Two parallel, longitudinal bands of pale blue enamel run down either side of the body; the central space is less clear, but appears to have contained sub-triangular cells, with two at the base surviving. One (on the left) contains plae blue enamel, the other red. The mount has two circular rivet holes, both slightly off centre to either side of the longitudinal median line.Dimensions: length 49.8mm; width 20.6mm; thickness 8.6mm; weight 10.78g.A very similar example from Salisbury is illustrated by Cherry (2001: 42) who notes that such figurines depicted saints or apostles, and were produced in Limoges between the late twelfth and early thirteenth century in order to be affixed to crucifixes and reliquaries. Another comparible example from London is published by Ward-Perkins (1940, plt. LXXXI, no. 3).

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A dupondius or as of Faustina II minted under Antoninus Pius and dating to the period AD 147 to 161 (Reece period 7). CONCORDIA SC reverse depicting Concordia seated left. Mint of Rome. RIC III, p. 193, no. 1393.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Sheet copper alloy sword or dagger chape probably dating between the 14th-16th centuries, but a 15th century date seems likely. There are two thin incised lines around the upper edge of the chape, and one just above the terminal knop. The finder has treated the surface with a varnish.

properties.title: STRAP END
properties.description: Cast copper-alloy strap end.  The sub-triangular terminal is fashioned to look like a tree. The circular body section has engraved lines, representing the roots of the tree, around an oval aperture. The underplate is still attached. Two rivet holes are found on the circular body and underplate. The underplate has a further two rivet holes just before the triangular ?tree? moulding, which are not found on the circular body. Viewed from the back, with the ?tree? facing upwards, the top left rivet hole still contains a rivet. See NMGW-3D3615 for a similar strap end; these are known as 'crescentic' strap ends and date to the 15th century.

properties.title: CASTING WASTE
properties.description: Copper alloy casting waste. This is a waste product from the metal casting process, but the date of the object cannot be determined. The object is conical in shape, and is hollowed at the larger end. Two small ?stumps? or arms of copper alloy project from the narrower end of the object.

properties.title: STIRRUP
properties.description: A late Anglo-Saxon cast copper alloy stirrup-strap mount, of Williams Class B. The stirrup strap mount is very worn, but is of an openwork design, with three pairs of apertures and an angled flange which projects backwards from the distal end. The remains of an iron rivet are present in the flange's left fixing hole, but the other fixing hole is incomplete. The upper fixing hole is also missing. The closest parallel in David Williams' Late Saxon-Stirrup Strap Mounts, is no. 504 (p. 104, fig. 64). This example, from Dorset, is better preserved and is decorated with animal heads.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Made in one piece casting. Consists of four points, with raised pattern on the front face. The pin used in to attach to leather still evident.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount in the form of a sexfoil, with domed centre and lobes. It has a single complete sharp-pointed lug. Date is uncertain, but it is probably late medieval to post medieval.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Copper alloy William III farthing, found in a cob garden wall. It is dated 1694.

properties.title: TILE
properties.description: Large fragment of tile, recovered during building work in Exeter. It is square, with an orange-red fabric and a bevilled edge. The pattern retains its yellow-green slip in places and comprises a quatrefoil with a square and dot in the centre. It is 13th to 14th century in date.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: Cast iron cannon ball, weighing just over one pound, probably linked to the Civil War. It is in fair condition.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: Cast lead token, with a six-petalled fleuret motif. There is a sinlge dot in relief between each petal. It is probably 16th to 17th century in date.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: Cast lead uniface token. It has a voided cross on the surface with chevron motifs in each quarter. It is probably 17th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy umbonate bridle-boss. It is in very poor condition, bent with part lost. It has a fleur-de lis at the centre, with openwork surrounding it and a moulded border. Four lobed knops remain and there may well have been up to ten more. It is 17th centruy in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Fragment of cast copper alloy hooked mount. It comprises most of the body, which would have been symmetrical. It has a trefoil bottom with bifid sides (one lost). There are the remains of iron rivets in two rivet holes, one at the top and bottom and curvilinear engraved lines on the surface. It is probably 16th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount. It is symmetrical in shape and almost bone-shaped. It has a narrow waist decorated with two incised lines. The sharp-pointed lugs appear complete. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: Fragment of cast copper alloy purse bar. It consists of a 51mm length, with both ends encased in iron corrosion. There is a single band in relief with corroded loop below for threads to connect the bar to the purse. It is late medieval to early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It protrudes from both sides to form places where the pin rested (now lost). The central bar is narrow and extends beyond the body of the buckle. It is late medieval to post medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount in the form of a heart or cordate. It has the remains of two lugs near the top on the reverse. The surface is covered with engraved or scratched zig zag lines. Date is uncertain, but it is probably 16th century.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy circular trade weight. It has a crowned C, ewer and sword of St Paul stamped on the surface. It is from the reign of Charles I or II, so can be dated 1625 to 1685.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single loop buckle. It is D-shaped, with a narrowed strap-bar and notched lip. The pin is lost. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy coin weight. All markings have been worn off. It is probably 17th century in date.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast lead circular trade weight. It is uniface, with a capital 'I' stamped on the surface and a second faint stamp, possibly fleuret. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount. It is symmetrical and comprises a bar with thickened ends and centre with transverse lines. Two lugs on the reverse are damaged. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A cast copper-alloy buckle, probably dating from the Late Medieval period. The double-oval frame has serrated edges and is in poor condition. For a parallel, see Read 1995: 62 - 63, no.319.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy coin weight, probably for a guinea. It is uniface, with '27' on the front surrounded by tiny stamped shells. It is 18th century in date.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy coin weight. It has a crowned XXX on the obverse and a shield within a beaded broder on the reverse.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy trade weight. It is stamped with the sword of St Paul, ewer and a crowned 'I'. It dates to James I reign (1603 to 1625).

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy trade weight, weighing 1 ounce. It is stamped with the sword of St Paul, ewer and a crowned 'I'. It is a weight of James I and dates to the 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Part of a single-loop D-shaped buckle. It is decorated with incised triangles and dots separated with plain bands. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: AMPULLA
properties.description: Remains of a cast lead ampulla. It is in poor condition and badly damaged, with only part of the flask remaining. No markings or decoration is visible. It dates from the medieval period.

properties.title: BULLA
properties.description: Fragment of a cast lead papal bulla. It represents half of the bulla, althought the face of St Paul can be seen. The reverse has the letters 'V' and 'S' across the middle and a faint 'B' above. The faint Roman numeral at the base is unclear, but would refer to the pope represented by the bulla. This may be a bulla of Pope Urban, but without the numeral it is unclear to which pope and date this belongs. However, as a large number of bullae of Urban VI have been found in Britain, it could possibly belong to him. It can  only be given a broad medieval to post medieval date.

properties.title: TOKEN
properties.description: Lead token, in poor condition. It has a single fleur de lys within a plain border. The reverse has ring and dot decoration, with a zig zag border. It is post medieval in date.

properties.title: POWDER MEASURE
properties.description: Lead powder-charger cap, cup-shaped with the remains of one lug. It is relatively unsquashed and in good condition. It dates to the late 17th century.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: Complete lead seal, possibly from cloth or grain. It is complete, with scratched marks on the front and the initial'N' amongst other unclear marks on the back. It dates from the 17th century, but is probably later.

properties.title: ROTARY KEY
properties.description: Cast copper alloy lever lock or rotary key. It has a dog-leg bit with a notch at the bottom. The handle is a pierced diamond loop, with a lobed knop. It is Roman in date.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: Roman brooch of the Hod Hill type. It is made of copper alloy and there appears to be traces of tinning or silvering on the surface. The head is plain, with a notch halfway where the pin would have been (now lost). There is a tansverse moulding below this and the bow is decorated with wide lateral lugs towards the middle. Between the lugs is a studded band between two grooved bands. Below this are two transverse mouldings and towards the foot a grooved triangle. A small amount of the catchplate remains. It dates to the 1st century AD and this type of brooch is often found on military sites.

properties.title: DRESS FASTENER (UNKNOWN)
properties.description: Cast copper alloy hooked dress fastener. It has a heart-shaped centre with symmetrical openwork. Below this is a moulded band. The sharp end of the hook is lost and the top has a circular piercing for attachment with an iron rivet still in place.  The surface shows the remains of tinning. It is probably late medieval to post medieval in date.

properties.title: STUD
properties.description: Cast copper alloy shield-shapped stud or mount. It has a single lug at the back and may have been attached to a stirrup-strap. The shield is slightly curved, with ?three lions passant guardant. There are traces of red enamel in the field. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Small dagger chape, made of sheet copper alloy. The top is serrated, with three triangular points and corresponding notches on front and back. The bottom of the chape ends in a lobed knop. The front is decorated with slight indentations and the back is plain, with a copper alloy rivet at top and bottom. There appears to be ?leather sandwiched between the front and back plates. It probably dates from the medieval period.

properties.title: DRESS FASTENER (DRESS)
properties.description: Cast copper alloy hooked dress fastener. It is circular, with moulded decoration in the centre within a border. It has a subrectangular attachment loop at the top. The hook is out of shape with the sharp point lost. The back is plain and concave. It is 15th to 17th century in date.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: Cast copper alloy spur rowel, in the shape of a five-pointed star. It dates from the mid 14th century.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: Cast lead seal matrix. It is in poor condition, with much of the seal lost. It has a rectangular section and the seal, when complete, was circular. The design is complicated, and may show a crest. The handle is circular and unpierced. It is probably 13th century in date.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy seal matrix, in poor condition. It has a round section and the seal is circular. The handle is a pierced trefoil, with rectangular openwork in the centre. The image is not clear, but it appears to depict a bird. It is probably a personal seal and dates from the medieval period.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Small dagger chape made of sheet copper alloy. It is plain, with two triangular notches at the top. The seam appears to be soldered and overlaps at the back. The bottom is rounded and well-finished. It is 14th to 15th century in date.

properties.title: DRESS FASTENER (UNKNOWN)
properties.description: Cast copper alloy clothing or dress fastener. It is symmetrical, lozenge-shaped with openwork. It has a rectangular attachment loop and at the other end a broken circular piercing also for attachment. It is 16th to 17th century in date.

properties.title: SPUR
properties.description: Cast copper alloy star rowel of five large points (one is lost) with five smaller points between. It dates from the medieval period.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy buckle chape with 'pitchfork' tongue or double-spiked loop. It has some tinning or gilding on the surface. It is early 18th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy oval double-loop buckle. It is plain, with a slightly narrowed central bar and curves upwards. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Part of a cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It comprises one loop, with the central bar and tongue in place. It is a trapezium, with a pointed side. The central bar is narrowed and has large lobed knops on each end. The surface is plain. It is probably early to mid 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy oval double-loop buckle. It is plain, with a narrowed central bar. The pin is lost. It is medieval to early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Part of a cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It comprises one loop, with the pin or tongue still in place on the central bar. The side protrudes to a point, with a groove for the pin, and there is a lobed knop on each corner. The central bar is narrowed, with small lobed protrusions. The surface has the faint remains of tinning. It is early to mid 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. It is a plain rectangle, with a small notch on one side where the pin would have rested. Its date is uncertain, but it probably dates to the medieval period.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is asymmetrical, having one rounded and one straight end. The rounded end has lobed knops  and the straight end is decorated with incised grooves. The central bar is narrowed and has slight protrusions on each end. It is probably a spur buckle and dates to the early to mid 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. It has a rounded front with a lobed knop. The sides are concave and the strap-bar narrowed. The surface is worn and pitted. It is 16th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: A cast copper-alloy double-loop buckle. The frame is asymmetrical, having one rounded and one straight edge. The rounded end has two lobed knops and the central bar is narrowed, with slight protrusions at each end. The straight end is decorated with grooved notches. It was probably used to buckle a spur to a boot and dates from the early to mid 17th century. This buckle is Marshall's Type IIB (1986: 15 - 16, no.7).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy oval double-loop buckle. It is plain, with a narrowed central bar. The pin is lost. It dates to the late medieval period.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle, possibly from a spur. It is a trapezium, with pointed sides. The central bar is narrowed and has bifid protrusions on each end. It is complete with the tongue or pin and is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Ornate cast copper alloy buckle, one half of a double-loop. The side protrudes to a point and the bar is narrowed, with fleuret knops. The decoration is worn, but appears to be foliate or fleuret. It is late medieval to early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy oval double-loop buckle, complete with copper alloy tongue or pin. The central bar is narrowed, with slight protrusions at each end. It is late medieval to early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle, trapezium, probably a spur buckle. It has a narrowed central bar, sides that protrude to a point and loped knops on each corner. There are very faint engraved notches where the pin (now lost) would have rested. It is early 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy circular buckle, with a central bar. It is fleuret having five 'petals', with the remains of the iron tongue or pin in place. Engraved lines can be faintly seen on the surface of the petals, which also have a plain border. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is assymmetrical, with one side rounded with lobed knops and the other side straight, with right-angled corners. This side is also decorated with incised lines and knops on each corner. The central bar is narrowed and the rounded side is slightly narrower than the straight edge. It is probably from a spur and dates to the 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Remains of a cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is highly decorated, with trefoil knops on each corner, bifid knops on either side of the narowed bar and in the centre of the remaining complete side. It may have come from a spur and is probably dated late 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy rectangular double-loop buckle. It is plain with a slightly narrowed bar. The corners are sub-rounded. It dates to the 17th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is plain, with a narrowed bar and curves slightly upwards. It is probably medieval to early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy loop chape from a late 17th to early 18th century buckle. It has a single spike, replacing the stud or anchor method of attaching the buckle to the shoe (Marshall, 1986, page 17).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy buckle. Spindle, now lost, would have been of another metal such as iron. There are drilled holes half way along each side to accommodate the spindle, and some iron corrosion. It is moulded where the spindle would have fitted. The ends are rounded. It is late 17th to early 18th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. It is quite worn, with a rounded front with lobed knop. The sides are slightly concave and curved inwards. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small rectangular cast copper alloy buckle, with double loops. It is plain, with a narrowed central bar and curved downwards slightly. The date is uncertain, but it is probably post medieval and may be a shoe buckle.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. It has slightly concave sides, a rounded front and a lobed knop, where the pin would have rested (lost). It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. The loop has slightly concave sides, a rounded front and a lobed knop. The strap-bar is narrowed. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. The loops are oval and the buckle plain, with a notch for the pin (lost). The central bar protrudes slightly, to form points. It is post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is rectangular, with square loops. The buckle is plain and the pin is in place. It is post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle. It has slightly concave sides and a rounded front with a lobed knop. The strap bar is narrowed. It is in fair condition and dates to the 16th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle with part of the plate. The buckle is D-shaped, with a notched lip and the pin is in place. The buckle plate is plain and made of sheet coppper alloy. It is medieval in date, probably 13th to 14th century.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is in poor condition, with corrosion obscuring any decoration. It is probably medieval or early post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast worn copper alloy double-loop buckle. It has a moulded fleuret, with four petals around a central circlet, on each loop and one at each end of the central bar. It is late 15th to 16th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It has a moulded trefoil on each loop and one on each end of the central bar. It is 16th to early 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy buckle with figure-of-eight loops. It has a moulded pyramidal knop on each loop. The  central bar is narrowed and the pin lost. It is late medieval to post medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Part of a cast copper-alloy double-loop buckle.The remaining side of the frame is broadly oval in plan and has an inward-pointing moulded trefoil knop. The central axis bar protrudes beyond the edge of the frame and retains its pin. The buckle dates from around the 17th century. A parallel is illustrated by Marshall (1986: 16,no. 41).

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy single-loop buckle, with pointed loop and remains of the forked spacer plate. It is complete with pin. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Part of a cast copper alloy double-loop buckle, possibly from a spur. One loop remains, with an engraved notch and transverse line across the width of the loop. It is a trapezium, with knops on each corner of the loop and a slightly protruding central bar. It is early to mid 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle, possibly a sword belt hanger. It is trapezoidal with a narrowed central bar that extends beyond the frame. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Tiny cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is plain, the pin is missing and it is slightly curved towards the top surface. The central bar is narrowed. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It has moulded trefoil knops on each loop and trefoil moulding at each end of  the bar. It is late 16th to early 17th century in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy D-shaped single-loop buckle, with a notched lip. The pin and buckle-plate are lost. It probably dates to the medieval or early post medieval period.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy oval double-loop buckle. It has the remains of tinning on the surface and also of the iron-wire pin on the central bar. It also has a notch on one of the loops, where the end of the pin would have rested. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: BUCKLE
properties.description: Cast copper alloy double-loop buckle. It is very worn and in poor condition. It has a moulded knop on each loop and at the ends of the central bar. It is probably late 16th or early 17th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount, in the shape of a stylised leaf or flower with stem. It has been gilded, and there is a lot of this remaining on the surface. The reverse is flat, with no signs of attachment hooks remaining. There is also some gilding on the back. It is probably post medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount, figurative and flat, in the form of a single flower with leaves. It was attached to leather or a garment with a single pointed lug, which is complete and bent. Its date is uncertain, but it is probably post medieval.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount, with foliate decoration. It has a flat back, with no remains of attachment hooks. The date is uncertain, but it is probably post medieval.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Silver sixpence of Elizabeth I. It is fourth issue and dates to 1578 or 1579

properties.title: JETTON
properties.description: Badly chipped late medieval continental jeton. It can only be give a broad 16th century date. Others have been found on the same site.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Worn foreign coin. Others have been found on the same site. It is dated 1760.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Halfpenny of William III.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Late Georgian gaming piece. It is in the style of an old quinea and was struck 'In memory of the good old days'.

properties.title: STUD
properties.description: Cast copper alloy decorative stud, with red enamel. It is 30mm in length, with the head having a diameter of 21mm. The head has six trumpet voids, of which three have red enamel. There are also three small circles filled with red enamel. Around each of the voids are incised lines, following the shape of the void. It is Continental, being unparalleled in Britain and is La Tene in style. A similar Continental La Tene stud, with red enamel decoration, was found at Silchester (Fulford, pers. com.)

properties.title: LITHIC IMPLEMENT
properties.description: Polished flint axe. It is 151mm in length, 24mm wide at the butt end and around 55mm at the cutting edge. The cutting edge is asymmetrical and the whole axe is symmetrical in section. The flint is very pale and des not appear to be local to Devon. The axe retains a good polish on one side, which is particularly high towards the cutting edge, with the other side poorly patinated, with calcination more noticeable. The axe has retained some faceting and there is some damage to the cutting edge.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: A Post-Medieval Silver halfgroat of Elizabeth I (AD 1558-1603), probably dating to AD 1582-1603. Third coinage, Uncertain initial mark. North (1991: 137) no. 2016.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Post Medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I dating to 1568 (on coin). Initial mark: Coronet. Mint of London (Tower). North (1991:134) no.1997.

properties.title: CLOTH SEAL
properties.description: The remains of twelve lead cloth seals and one complete example. The complete cloth seal comprises one half with the name of the clothier (Waymouth Brothers) with a standing lion in the centre. The reverse denotes the length (18). The detached halves include six seals of the Waymouth Brothers and five denoting lengths (10, 11, 40, 36 and 6 or 9). A seventh depicts a bear. All are 17th century in date.

properties.title: SHOT
properties.description: Seventy-two lead musket and pistol balls collected from one field over time. They vary in weight from 6grams to 51grams. Those of note include balls of 0.5 and 0.75 calibre and those that show damage, from firing and from impact. Several have the remains of the sprue. They are all post medieval in date, though some may be later.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: A cast brooch of lead alloy. The brooch resembles a flower head, with the top surface of curved lines giving the impression of petals. There are no indications of fixings on the back of the brooch, so the pin may have been hinged at one point (which appears broken) and rested where there is a mark on the opposite side. It is probably Medieval in date. Similar brooches were found in excavations in London (Egan and Pritchard 1991: 253 - 254).

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: Fragment of an object, probably a figurine or possibly a plaything. It is  cast, of copper alloy and represents a bird's wing, with detailing on both sides. The feathers are clearly marked. At the shoulder is a small joint or tab, suggesting this  is a component that slotted into a main body and so cast in separate parts. Date is uncertain.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast lead trade weight, square and free-standing, with a small hole at the top. It is 49mm in height with a width at the widest part of 19mm. It weighs close to 4 ounces. Two of the opposing sides are indented and the body of the weight has a square section. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast lead trade weight, 3 ounce, conical and free-standing with an integral loop. It is plain, 44mm in height with a circular cross-section and a diameter at the widest part of 18mm. It is probably 12th to 13th century in date.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast lead weight, egg-shaped with a few incised marks on the surface. It is 37mm in length with a diameter of 29mm at the widest part. It weighs 206grams. Date uncertain, but probably post medieval.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Oval-shaped cast lead palm guard, for use by a leather worker to protect the palm whilst stitching. It is 59mm in length, 41mm at the widest part and has a maximum thickness of about 13mm. The domed surface is marked by one incised line at one edge and the flat underside has an indentation in the centre of the wider end. There are no other markings. It dates from the 17th to 19th century. See DEV-C7F0A5 and SF-F9D4D5

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Cast lead teardrop-shaped palm guard, for use by a leather worker. It is 62mm in length, 34mm wide at the widest point and has a maximum thickness of approximately 13mm. The domed surface has a large mark or nick and the underside flat surface is marked by incised lines and an indentation in the centre. It dates from the 17th to 19th century. See SF-F9D4D5

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Oval cast lead weight, with no markings. Probably dates from the post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Circular flat lead weight or token. There are no markings and date is uncertain although it probably dates from the post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Lead weight or token, with no markings. Probably dates from the post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Circular cast lead weight, flat with no markings. Date uncertain but probably dates to the post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Oval-shaped flat weight. It has no markings and probably dates from the post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Circular cast lead weight. It has no markings and probably dates from the medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Small lead weight or token. It has no markings and probably dates from the medieval or post medieval period.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast loaf-shaped lead weight.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Crude cast lead weight. Circular and flat, with no markings. Probably dates to the medieval or post medieval period.

properties.title: BULLET
properties.description: Cast lead bullet, cylindrical shape with conical head. Interior is hollow. Probably dates to the 18th or 19th century.

properties.title: BULLET
properties.description: Lead bullet, cylindrical body with conical head. Probably 18th or 19th century.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Crude cast lead weight. Cylindrical in shape with no markings.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Cast copper alloy leg from a cooking vessel. 57mm remains of the length. It has a single central rib and a D-shaped cross-section. It is broken at the point it joined the vessel and the end of the leg is rounded. It is probably from a skillet or small cauldron and late medieval or early post-medieval in date.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Cast copper alloy leg from a cooking vessel, possibly part of a failed casting. Only 52mm remain of the length. It probably dates from the 15th to 18th century.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Remains of a cast copper alloy leg from a cooking vessel. It is plain and slightly concave. In poor condition, it may have come from a skillet. As this type of vessel was in use for a long period of time, it may date from the 15th to 18th century.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Cast copper alloy leg from a cooking vessel. It is shaped like a lion's paw, with three ribs coming down to three 'toes'. 70mm in length remains of the leg. As this type of vessel was in use for a long time, it has a date range of 15th to 16th century.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Short, slightly splayed leg from a cooking vessel, probably from a large cauldron. It is made of cast copper alloy and has a sharp rib down the facing surface.It is D-shaped in section, with a length of 63.25mm. This type of cooking vessel was in use for a long time and so dates from the 15th to 18th century.

properties.title: VESSEL
properties.description: Cast copper alloy leg from a cooking vessel. It has a sharp rib on the front and a slightly concave back. The top of the leg shows the inside of the vessel. The cross section is D-shaped with the leg being short and slightly splayed. It possibly came from a large cauldron and is post medieval in date.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Square flat copper alloy coin weight, for weighing two shilling pieces. The obverse has a crowned XXII (II is missing) and the reverse, although very worn, has 'BRI' for Britain and a stamped 'W' in the bottom right to show the maker. It is late 17th to early 18th century in date.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy coin weight. It is uniface, with the image of an angel with outstretched arms spearing a dragon. It is the weight of an angel (early type) and is post medieval in date.

properties.title: COIN WEIGHT
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy coin weight. It is uniface, with a ship with crowned head with shield and sword in the centre, with rose. It is the weight of a rose noble (the earlier type) and is post medieval in date.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: Fragment of cast copper alloy purse bar (London Museum Medieval Catalogue Type A1). A length of 27.5mm remains. One of the terminal ends, it has a circular cross-section. The surface is decorated by nielloed cross-hatching and there is a small part of the integral flange, for attachment of the cloth bag, with a single rivet hole remaining. It is late 15th century in date.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Large trade weight (1 ounce)of Queen Anne. Made of cast copper alloy, it has four stamps on the surface; a crown, capital A, the sword of St Paul and ewer. There are scratch marks on the underside. It is early 18th century in date.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy flat circular trade weight (0.25 ounce). It has three stamps, including the sword of St Paul, denoting that this is a London weight. The letters 'OE' or 'BE' shows the issue, but it is unclear what it is. The other stamp is possibly a crowned 'WM' suggesting William and Mary but again this is unclear. It is late 17th century in date.

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy object in poor condition. It is possibly a horse harnass pendant and has the remains of a suspension loop at the top. It is shield-shaped and thickened by corrosion or encrustation products. There are no marks or decoration visible.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy lozenge-shaped mount. The top surface has been tinned or silvered. Symmetrical, it has a central cross with a raised boss, surrounded by a beaded border. Within the border and between the arms of the cross are openwork circles. It is 26mm in length and at each end of are trefoils or worn fleur de lis. It is 20mm wide and on both sides are small protrusions, worn with one broken. The back is plain with a central, complete pointed lug or shank. It is medieval in date.

properties.title: DRESS FASTENER (DRESS)
properties.description: Cast copper-alloy toggle of Post-Medieval date. It has a pointed oval part surmounted by a post with a double circular eye fitting.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy flat circular trade weight (0.5 ounce) with crowned GR. It is late 18th to 19th century in date.

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
