properties.description: Cast copper alloy object, 39mm in length, that possibly formed part of a purse frame. It consists of a 24mm length with a circular section attached to a sub rectangular piece, which is hollow. It may have formed part of the loop from which the frame and body of the bag hung. It is  probably medieval to post medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy mount, with integral lugs (one broken). It is 18mm in length and a symmetrical 'axe' shape. The surface is undecorated and the underside has one complete lug bent towards the middle of the back. It may have been a horse-harnass mount and is probably post medieval in date.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: A thimble made of sheet copper alloy. it is 21.5mm high and has a diameter of 17mm at the base, which is damaged. Probably made by hammering out the sheet metal, it has vertical  triangular indentations over the main part of the thimble and over the rounded crown. The base has a plain band 4mm thick underneath a ridge extending  the diameter of the thimble, though this band is very damaged. It is Medieval to post-Medieval in date.

properties.title: SEAL
properties.description: Lead customs seal. From Holland, one side has the letters 'R & A'(for Dutch Customs and Excise) with '102' (the control number?)beneath stamped on it. This is surrounded by part of a beaded border. The other side has a lion rampant with a sword inside a shield with a crown (now worn) above. This represents the House of Orange. Dated after 1815, this is a common find and from any type of exported Dutch goods.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount, with integral and complete hooked shank. It is worn and the decoration is faint, but it appears to consist of a floral motif with a central boss surrounded by four petals with each petal divided by the arms of a cross. Symmetrical, it has a length of 20mm and is 18mm wide. It is medieval to post medieval in date.

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: Small cast copper alloy Roman brooch. It is T-shaped, with short wings. Attached to each end of the wing is a small lug, which the spring would have fixed to (now lost). The wing has a curved section and it may be that the pin hinge would have been visible and so a feature of this otherwise plain brooch.

properties.title: WEIGHT
properties.description: Cast lead weight, circular with an indentation in the top surface. There may have been an image or value in this space, but it is now unclear. It weighs 49grams and has a diameter of 30mm. It is post medieval in date.

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: Unidentified cast copper alloy object. It is 48mm in length and asymmetrical. One end is pointed and the other squared and open. Each end is decorated by incised lines. The surface has eight protrusions; four along the spine of the object and two on each side. The underside is rough with two hollows separated by a solid section. It is highly decorative, but its purpose, use and date are unknown.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy hooked mount, with separate rivet. The main body is shield-shaped, with a hook below, now broken. The top is surmounted with a pointed projection. The mount is in poor condition and not complete. The surface appears undecorated, though is blackened and the underside is rough and unfinished. It is probably post medieval in date.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: Cast copper alloy seal matrix. Oval in shape with a hexagonal cross-section handle surmounted wioth a trefoil suspension loop. It is in very good condition. An Elizabethan merchant's seal, it has the initials 'I B' with two stars either side. Below is a double XX linked beneath by a small crescent. Above the initials is a 4 denoting this was the seal of a dealer in cloth. It is late 16th to early 17th century in date.

properties.title: SEAL MATRIX
properties.description: Cast copper alloy seal matrix, circular and in perfect condition. It has a hexagonal cross-section handle with a trefoil suspension loop surmounted by circular loop. The seal depicts Mary Magdalene kneeling with a pot of ointment and Christ standing holding a staff with penants.  The letters are gothic and the inscription reads S[igillum] MAGDELE [---] PRO NOBIS ORA. This suggests the translation 'holy Magdalene pray for us'. It may not be the official seal of an institution, but who commissioned it and used it is unknown. It is late 15th to early 16th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Circular cast copper alloy object, possibly a mount or part of a brooch. The top surface is decorated with a swirled pattern that has traces of silvering or tinning on the raised parts. It is in poor condition, partly broken and there is no sign of any fixing attachment on the back. One edge has remains of a lip 4mm deep that may have fixed the object in position. The underside is rough and unfinished.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Figurative mount of cast copper alloy. The two lugs are lost, leaving small fragments showing their original position. The decoration is foliate, with a beaded band between the two outside flowers.  There is a third flower in the centre. The mount is surmounted with a circular loop, possible for suspension. Its date is uncertain.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount. It is U-shaped with crescent shaped openwork. It has one lug remaining. The edges are serrated and there is an incised line following the U-shape. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Sword or dagger chape of cast copper alloy with turned over edges.The top is serrated and the body has two raised bands across the front. These may have been silvered. The bottom is finished with a globular knop. A small thin fragment attached to the back at the bottom of the chape is possibly the remains of a backplate. It is late 15th to 16th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount, with two complete lugs. It is U-shaped with circular protrusions on the inside 4mm from each terminal. It is 29.5mm in length and 27mm wide. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Small chape, probably from a dagger. It is flat, made of cast copper alloy and has turned over edges. It has a single hole on the body of the chape, possibly for a rivet. The top is surmounted with a trefoil with a circular indentation or rivet hole. Either side is cut away to form two points. It is probably late medieval in date.

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Cast copper alloy sword chape. It is 54mm in length and is flat with turned over edges. It has a serrated top edge above openwork of circles and one trefoil. There is a plain band below. Below this, on the main body of the chape, is a openwork quatrefoil, with one elongated lobe. The bottom edge is finished with a knop. It is late 15th to 16th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Flat, symmetrical mount with two complete lugs. Each end is bifid and the centre of the mount waisted. It is decorated with a silvered curvilinear with dot motif at each end and where these meet at the centre, there appears to be a small face. The lugs are complete, tapered but bent over. It is 39mm in length and is post-medieval in date.

properties.title: THIMBLE
properties.description: Small thimble, made in two pieces of sheet copper alloy. It is 14mm high and the inside diameter of the base is 10mm. The cap is coming away from the cylinder. There is a 4mm band at the base before the rows of regular transverse indentations. The cap is covered in concentric circles of indentations, although most are unclear as this part of the thimble is in poor condition. Its small size suggests this was the thimble of a child or small adult or possibly a toy. It is post-medieval in date.

properties.title: TOY
properties.description: Toy gun made of cast copper alloy. It is complete and in very good condition. It has an overall length of 78mm. The handle is bell-shaped and decorated on each side by three dot and circle stamps. The stock is complete and there are a further three dot and cirlce stamps on the body of the gun. There is a touch hole on one side of the top of the barrel and the barrel is bored, with a hexagonal section. The top of the barrel is decorated with two rows of dots running in wavy lines along the lenght. There are also two sets of a pair of grooved lines half way down the top of the barrel. 17th century

properties.title: BROOCH
properties.description: T-shaped bow brooch, made of cast copper alloy. It is incomplete, with the wings, bow and a small piece of the catchplate remaining. The wings are 30mm wide and the brooch has a complete legth of 38mm. The pin (now lost) would have ben atttached by a hinge mechanism and a V-shaped cut in the centre of the underside of the wings shows the position of the hinge. The front of the wings are decorated by a diagonal groove running from each terminal to the top of the bow where it joins the wings. This is clearest on the left wing and very faint on the right. The section of the bow is D-shaped. The front is decorated by a large central ridge running down the length of the bow, flanked on each side by a groove. A small pice of the catchplate remains atached to the foot of the bow, although the very tip of the bow appears to be lost. It is Roman in date. AD 1st - 2nd century.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Roman copper alloy nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to AD 330-335 (Reece Period 17). Constantinopolis commemorative issue with reverse design of Victory on prow. Minted at Trier.

properties.title: COIN
properties.description: Late third century barbarous radiate. Crude.

properties.title: STIRRUP
properties.description: A late early-medieval stirrup-strap mount of Williams's Class A Type 10B. Made of cast copper alloy, it is sub-triangular in shape. It has a common right angle flange, with the corroded remains of two iron rivets in place. This corrosion has slightly affected the front of the mount. The apex loop is damaged and broken through. The mount is decorated by engraving and openwork and the pattern appears to be an interlaced zoomorphic design. It is worn, so the creature depicted is difficult to make out clearly. The openwork comprises two elongated kidney-shapes in the shoulders of the mount and six small circluar holes randomly placed. The two lower fixing holes not only have the remains of the two iron rivets, but there are possibly the remains of the iron fitting or strap on the reverse. There are traces of niello with the arched border.It measures 47.7 mm long by up to 32.4 mm wide by c. 3.8 mm thick, up to 9.7 mm thick at the flange. It weighs 22.82 gFor stirrup-strap mounts of Williams Class A, Type 10B see Williams (1997, 55-57; figs 37-38).  Though none are identical no. 195 approaches the form and design here.

properties.title: SPOON
properties.description: Writhen knop from a medieval spoon. Possibly made of pewter it is an oval ball-shape, with diagonal grooves incised into it all the way round following the curve. It is broken at the spot it joined the stem and is surmounted with a small globular knop. However, Read suggests, with a very similar knop from North-West Dorset, that it may possibly be inverted, and if so, is an example of the variation of the finial knop which is surmounted by a spire or spike (2001, pg. 92). It dates to the 14th to 15th century.

properties.title: UNIDENTIFIED OBJECT
properties.description: Unidentified object. It is made of cast copper alloy, two pronged or forked and the prongs are pointed. The prongs adjoin a T-shaped piece, which appears to have been broken at each of the T-bar arms, leaving 8mm. 3 mm thick and with a total length of 27mm, the surface has some small areas of gilding. Its purpose and date are unknown, however, it is similar to medieval strap ends with forked spacers.

properties.title: LUG (HANDLE)
properties.description: Pewter lug from a vessel or container, possibly from a soldier's field bottle. It has been deliberately cut from the vessel, leaving a cleanly cut small portion of the curved body. The lug is roughly square (12mm by 12mm), with a perforation for a cord through the middle. The perforation is 5mm in diameter one side and narrows to 4mm as it passes through the lug. It is post medieval in date and may be 16th century.

properties.title: DRESS COMPONENT
properties.description: Hooked mount with the remains of a single separate rivet and separate pendent fitting.The mount is convex, symmetrical and made of cast copper alloy. The closed hook is complete and suspends the mount from a trefoil attachment. A small pyramidal knop adorns one of the loops of the trefoil attachment. Below the hook are two moulded transverse collars surmounting the teardrop-shaped lobe. The mount is finished with a small triangular knop. It has a total length of 45mm and is 14.5mm wide at the widest part of the central lobe. The surface of the central lobe is undecorated and the corroded remains of the separate iron rivet can be seen in place, towards the bottom. This type of hooked mount is also classed as a dress fastener (Read, 2001) and would have had a back plate riveted in place to secure leather or fabric straps. It is 17th century in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Symmetrical cast copper alloy mount. It appears to be broken at the top, so may be the remains of a hooked mount. Beneath the damaged area are two ribbed bands, which widen to a third ribbed band surmounting the central teardrop-shaped lobe. This narrows to another ribbed band and a tapering point 11.5mm long. The mount has a total length of 36mm and at the widest point on the central lobe is 10.5mm in width. The surface appears undecorated, as the form of the mount is quite ornate. The underside is slightly concave, although the mount appears flat. Visible on the top surface and underneath of the tapering point is the remains of a separate iron rivet. It is probably post-medieval in date.

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: One arm of a purse bar. Made of cast copper alloy, it comprises a central block with an arm 83mm in length finishing in a T-shaped terminal with a pyramidal knop. It has a total length of 101mm long and is 13mm wide at the widest point (the T-shaped terminal). The central block is decorated on each face by random scratched lines and circles. An area of corrosion adjoins the central block and is probably the remains of an iron suspension loop and rove attachment.There are three holes through the arm, and three small pegs (ranging in length from 12mm to 15mm), in place and moveable. The arm is decorated on two of the faces by a wavy line along its length and a dot beneath each of the lines curves. It's date is uncertain and is does not appear to conform to London Museum (1940) typology. It is probably late medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Small mount in the shape of an asymmetrical eight-pointed star. Made of cast copper alloy, it appears plain. It has two lugs for attachment on the underside; one is complete, 6mm in length and pointed and the other is broken leaving  just 2.5mm of the lug remaining. The mount is 12mm in length and 9mm wide. It is post-medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Elongated lozenge (diamond) shaped mount with two integral pointed lugs. Made of cast copper alloy, it is 22.5mm in length and 9mm wide at the widest point. The sharp lugs were used to insert the mount into leatherwork and both are bent outwards through use. The surface appears undecorated and the mount is in fair condition. It is post-medieval and probably dated to the 17th century.

properties.title: STUD
properties.description: Lozenge (diamond) shaped stud or tack, with the remains of a thick, blunt shank. Made of cast copper alloy, it is 15mm in length and 11mm at the widest point. The surface is  worn and appears plain, although, as it is slightly domed, it is worn most along the raised area. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Bar mount, similar to DEV-05DE57, but complete with terminal lobes. Made of cast copper alloy, it has the remains of a separate copper alloy rivet through each of the terminal lobes. It is 17mm in length and 10mm at the widest part of the central lobe. It is decorated with three embossed ribs across the width of the central lobe and is in good condition. Bar-mounts were attached transversely in a row on straps (Egan, 1991, 209) and are shown in contemporary depictions on men's waist and sword belts as well as on horse harnass. It probably dates to 12th to 15th century.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy mount with two integral rivets or hooks. It is almost symmetrical, with one pointed end and a knop at the other end. It is 32mm in length, less than 1mm thick and 10mm at the widest point tapering to 2mm. The surface is uneven and it may be decorated, although this is unclear. The two rivets or hooks on the underside are pointed, to insert through leatherwork, and slightly bent over. It is probably dated, by looking at similar examples, from the 16th to 17th century.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Central lobe of a bar mount; the terminal lobes are broken off. It has a complete single integral rivet and a small piece of the fixing plate still attached. Cast in copper alloy, what remains is 13mm in length and 12 mm wide. The centre of the lobe is decorated with three embossed ribs. This type of find is a common find and many are documented. Sometimes the bar mount is attached to the strapend of which it formed part. It is medieval in date.    Refs. Read, B., 1995, History Beneath our Feet, pg. 68-69.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: T-shaped mount, made of cast copper alloy, with a six pointed star at the base of the T. It is 25mm in length from the top of the T to the tip of the star and is in fair condition. There is a damaged area across the T bar, suggesting a piece has been broken off and there are three 1mm circular stamps across the middle of this part of the mount. Three more circular stamps go down the length of the mount, with one forming the centre of the sexfoil star. There are smaller circular punch marks along the centre of each of the star's lobes and forming an oval on the surface of the main part of the mount. This oval is formed around the second of the larger punch marks. As it is highly decorated, the mount would have been on show, but it is not clear what it was attached to or how it was attached, as there are no traces of rivets or holes on the underside. It is probably medieval in date.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Small circular mount or stud. It is made of copper alloy, was probably cast and has a plain, flat head with a single, integral rivet. The rivet has a square section. The top of the mount has a shiny area, suggesting it may have been gilded. It would have been attached to leather or textile, as a decoration and is medieval in date.    Ref. Egan, G. and Pritchard, F., 2002, Dress Accessories 1150-1450, pg. 162-170.

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast copper alloy sexfoil mount, with the remains of a circular sectioned rivet on the underside. It is slightly domed around the rivet. The lobes are slightly pointed and again, like DEV-04D6C0, this gives the mount a star-like appearance. Ridges cross the surface between each lobe. A tiny shiny area in one of the ridges suggests the mount may have been gilded. The mount would have been decorative and attached to leather or fabric. It is medieval in date.      Refs. Egan, G. and Pritchard, F., 2002, Dress Accessories 1150-1450, pg.162

properties.title: MOUNT
properties.description: Cast sexfoil copper alloy mount. It is domed and concave, with an integral rivet, which has a square section. The mount is almost star-shaped, as each of the six lobes are slightly pointed. The top of the mount is flat and plain  and a ridge passes from this flattened area to the tip of each lobe. It is a robust mount and may have been attached to a piece of furniture or casket, rather than as part of a dress accessory. It is medieval in date.    Ref. Egan, G. and Pritchard, F., 2002, Dress Accessories 1150-1450, pg. 162

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: Elaborate quatrefoil-shaped horse harness pendant. It is cast and made of copper alloy. The suspension loop is complete giving a total length of 40mm. This harness pendant appears to be armorial and possibly shows a lion passant guardant on a black (Sable) square field with red (Gules) fleur de lis springing from each side. It is in fair condition, although the decoration is worn. It is very similar to an example from Reepham in Norfolk (Ashley, 2002). This type of horse furniture dates to the medieval period and this example is probably 14th century. Ref. Ashley, S., 2002, Medieval Armorial Horse Furniture in Norfolk, Norfolk Museums and Archaeology Service, pg.21, fig.21(212).

properties.title: HARNESS PENDANT
properties.description: Shield-shaped horse harness pendant. It is cast, made of copper alloy and has a small piece of the mount attached. This gives it a total length of 47mm and a width across the top of the shield of 23mm. It is in fair condition and on the front surface has patches of raised red enamel decoration and a trace of green. The decoration suggests it is an armorial harness pendant and possibly shows a lion rampant. The shield-shaped pendant is the most common form (Ashley 2002) and date to the medieval period. This example probably dates to the late 13th to 14th century.      Refs. Ashley, S., 2002, Medieval Armorial Horse Furniture in Norfolk, Norfolk Museum and Archaeology Service, pg.11, fig.11(61).

properties.title: SCABBARD
properties.description: Dagger-chape made of copper alloy. It is U-shaped, 41mm long and 29mm wide. A cast object, it has a shaped top edge, below which is openwork in the shape of an inverted tear-drop. The centre of the chape has trefoil openwork, with incised lines radiating from this to the outside edge. The back is left unfinished. The chape is finished at the bottom with a small square terminal knop. Common in the medieval period, this chape dates from the late 15th to early 16th century (London Museum, Medieval Catalogue, pg.280-288,plate no.LXXX,fig.88(8)).

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: One arm of a purse bar, broken at the point it would have joined the central block, made of copper alloy.It is 59mm long, has a circular section and is decorated with a 43mm section of incised criss-cross lines between two encircling grooves. One end shows an old, worn break and the other is rounded, with a groove 5mm from the end before the decoration. There is an integral attachment plate with two holes, from which the purse bag would have hung. It is in fair condition. This type of purse bar is medieval and dates from the late 15th to early 16th century (London Museum Medieval Catalogue, pg.158, fig.50).

properties.title: PURSE
properties.description: Central block from a purse bar, made of copper alloy. It is shield shaped and has stylised animal heads at junction with bar (missing) giving it a total length of 35mm and width of 15mm.The surfaces of both sides of the block are decorated; one with criss-cross lines and the other with lines radiating out from the point below the central loop (missing). The decoration is slightly raised and burnished black (niello). The rest of the surface is dull. The breaks are worn and old. A hole through the body of the block indicates the position of the fixing for the central loop. This type of purse bar is medieval; with parallels known from the late 15th to early 16th century (London Museum Medieval Catalogue, p.158, fig.50).

properties.title: FINGER RING
properties.description: Cast copper alloy finger ring depicting two clasped hands on the bezel. Clasped hands are frequently found on the class of Medieval love-ring known as ?fede? rings. The shoulders of the ring have four horizontal side projections and one vertical projection suggesting a cuffed forearm. The hand is modelled by a series of grooves defining the fingers and a deeper side groove forming the thumb. Two cross-grooves on one of the shoulders define the underside of the wrist of one arm. The hoop is plain and has a D-shaped cross-section.
